Spa Holdings 3 Oy, a limited liability company organized and existing under the laws of Finland (the “Issuer”), is offering (the “Offering”) €400 million in
aggregate principal amount of its % Senior Secured Notes due 2028 (the “EUR Notes”) and €250 million (equivalent) in aggregate principal amount of its
% Senior Secured Notes due 2028 (the “USD Notes” and together with the EUR Notes, the “Notes”). A portion of the proceeds of the Offering will be used
together with a portion of the proceeds from the Senior Term Facilities (as defined herein) and cash to refinance amounts that were incurred under the Bridge
Facilities (as defined herein), the proceeds of which financed part of the purchase price for the acquisition by the Issuer of the common shares of AhlstromMunksjö Oyj, a public limited liability company incorporated under the laws of Finland (together with its subsidiaries, “Ahlstrom Munksjö”), in a voluntary
public cash tender offer (ostotarjous), to repay a portion of Ahlstrom-Munksjö’s existing debt and other obligations and to pay the costs, fees and expenses
incurred in connection with the offering of the Notes.
The EUR Notes and the USD Notes will bear interest at a rate of % and % per annum, respectively. The Notes will mature on, 2028.
The Issuer will pay interest on the Notes semi-annually in arrears on and, commencing on . Prior to, 2024, the
Issuer will be entitled, at its option, to redeem all or a portion of the Notes by paying a “make-whole” premium. At any time on or after, 2024, the
Issuer may redeem all or part of each series of Notes at the redemption prices set forth in this offering memorandum (the “Offering Memorandum”). In addition,
prior to, 2024, the Issuer may redeem, at its option, up to 40% of each series of Notes (including the aggregate principal amount of any additional
Notes issued) with the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings so long as at least 50% of the original principal amount of the applicable series of Notes
(excluding any additional Notes), issued under the Indenture (as defined herein) remain outstanding. Prior to, 2024, the Issuer may redeem up to 10%
of the aggregate principal amount of each series of Notes originally issued (including the aggregate principal amount of any additional Notes issued) in each
calendar year at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount thereof. Additionally, upon certain events defined as constituting a change of control
triggering event or upon certain asset sales, the Issuer may be required to make an offer to purchase the Notes. A change of control triggering event, however, will
not be deemed to have occurred if a specified consolidated net leverage ratio is not exceeded in connection with such event. In the event of certain developments
affecting taxation, the Issuer may elect to redeem all, but not less than all, of the Notes. In addition, in connection with certain tender offers for the Notes, if
holders of not less than 90% in aggregate principal amount of the applicable outstanding Notes validly tender and do not withdraw such Notes in such tender offer
and the Issuer, or any third party making such a tender offer in lieu of the Issuer, purchases all of the Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders,
the Issuer or such third party will have the right to redeem the Notes that remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to
the price offered to each other holder of Notes. See “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.”
The Notes will be senior secured obligations of the Issuer, will rank senior in right of payment to all of the Issuer’s future debt that is expressly subordinated
in right of payment to the Notes and will rank pari passu in right of payment with the Issuer’s existing and future debt that is not so subordinated, including the
Issuer’s obligations under the Senior Secured Credit Facility (as defined herein). On the Issue Date, the Notes will be guaranteed (the “Original Guarantee”) by
Spa US Holdco, Inc. (“U.S. Holdco”). Subject to and in accordance with the Agreed Security Principles (as defined herein), the Notes will be guaranteed on a
senior secured basis within 120 days from the Business Day falling immediately after the date on which the Issuer actually receives unqualified title to one
hundred percent of the issued shares of Ahlstrom-Munksjö (the “Squeeze-Out Completion Date”) by the Post Squeeze-Out Guarantors (as defined herein) (the
“Post Squeeze-Out Guarantees” and, together with the Original Guarantee, the “Note Guarantees”). The Guarantors will also guarantee the obligations under the
Senior Secured Credit Facilities on a senior secured basis.
Subject to and in accordance with the Agreed Security Principles, the Notes will be secured on a first-priority basis, (i) on the Issue Date, by the Issue Date
Collateral (as defined herein); and (ii) within 120 days from the Business Day falling immediately after the Squeeze-Out Completion Date, by the Post
Squeeze-Out Collateral (as defined herein). The Collateral will also secure the obligations under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities on a first-priority basis. The
validity and enforceability of the Note Guarantees and the security and the liability of each Guarantor (as defined herein) and security provider will be subject to
the limitations described in “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Note Guarantees and the Security
_Interests” and “Risk Factors.” The security interests in favor of the Notes and the Note Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances._
This Offering Memorandum includes more detailed information on the terms of the Notes and the Note Guarantees, including redemption and repurchase
prices, security, covenants, events of default and transfer restrictions.
There is currently no market for the Notes. Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited for the listing of and permission
to deal in the Notes on the Official List of The International Stock Exchange (the “Exchange”). There can be no assurance, however, that the Notes will be listed
on the Official List of the Exchange, that such permission to deal in the Notes will be granted or that such listing will be maintained. The Exchange is not a
regulated market pursuant to the provision of Directive 2014/65/EU on markets in financial instruments, as amended from time to time.

**PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION**

performing certain activities related thereto. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Issuer has no
revenue-generating activities of its own, and no business operations, material assets or liabilities other than those
acquired or incurred in connection with its incorporation and the Transactions. As a result, no financial
information of the Issuer is included in this Offering Memorandum, except for certain limited as adjusted
financial data presented on an as adjusted to reflect certain effects of the Transactions. As of the date of this
Offering Memorandum, the Issuer owns approximately 90.6% of the Shares. After completion of the SqueezeOut, the Issuer will own 100% of the Shares. See “As Adjusted Financial Information” “Summary—Summary
_Consolidated Financial and Other Information As Adjusted Data of the Issuer” and “Capitalization.”_

**Ahlstrom-Munksjö**

All historical financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum is that of Ahlstrom-Munksjö
Oyj and its consolidated subsidiaries. Accordingly, unless otherwise stated, all references to “AhlstromMunksjö,” “we,” “us,” or “our” in respect of historical financial information in this Offering Memorandum are to
Ahlstrom-Munksjö Oyj and its subsidiaries on a consolidated basis.

**_Historical Financial Information_**

This Offering Memorandum includes our historical consolidated financial statements listed below (together,
the “Financial Statements”):

   - the audited consolidated annual financial statements of Ahlstrom-Munksjö Oyj and its subsidiaries as
of and for the year ended December 31, 2018 (the “2018 Financial Statements”);

   - the audited consolidated annual financial statements of Ahlstrom-Munksjö Oyj and its subsidiaries as
of and for the year ended December 31, 2019 (the “2019 Financial Statements”); and

   - the audited consolidated annual financial statements of Ahlstrom-Munksjö Oyj and its subsidiaries as

**_Comparability of the Financial Statements_**

_Presentation of Income Statement_

On January 1, 2020, we changed the presentation of our income statement to the function of expense method
from the nature of expense method, to align with our internal reporting. In the 2020 Financial Statements, the
comparative income statement information for the year ended December 31, 2019 has been restated according to the
function of expense method, to facilitate comparability, and is unaudited. The income statement in the 2019
Financial Statements and in the 2018 Financial Statements were presented using the nature of expense method. In
connection with the adoption of the function of expense method, certain minor reclassifications and changes in
names of income statement items have been made in the 2020 Financial Statements. Certain income statement items
previously reported within net sales, such as operative exchange gains and losses and operative foreign exchange
derivative results, were classified to other income statement lines. In addition, certain accounting policy alignments
were made between net sales and other operating income relating to previous acquisitions, and the income from the
sale of emission and other environmental rights previously classified in other operating expenses was reclassified to
other operating income. Due to these reclassifications, net sales for the year ended December 31, 2019 decreased by
€1.0 million and other operating income for the year ended December 31, 2019 increased by €8.6 million. The
reclassifications had no impact on our operating result or net result for the year ended December 31, 2019. In the
2020 Financial Statements certain income statement line items were renamed, such as net profit to net result and
profit before tax to result before tax. As a result, the 2019 Financial Statements and the 2018 Financial Statements
are not directly comparable with the 2020 Financial Statements or the 2019 comparative, unaudited, restated column
presented therein. In order to provide meaningful comparable financial information in this Offering Memorandum,
income statement information from the year ended December 31, 2019 is presented on an audited historical basis
when comparing to the financial information for the year ended December 31, 2018, and, otherwise, is extracted
without adjustment from the unaudited, restated comparative column included in the 2020 Financial Statements. See
also note 2 in the 2020 Financial Statements for further information.

xiii


-----

_Changes to Reportable Segments_

In 2019, we decided to implement a new business structure, which became effective on January 1, 2020, to
promote core business capabilities and sharpen strategic targets and align the business characteristics of each
business area. For periods after January 1, 2020, our five business areas comprise Filtration & Performance
Solutions, Advance Solutions, Industrial Solutions, Food Packaging & Technical Solutions, and Decor Solutions,
which five business areas also form our operating and reporting segments. For periods prior to January 1, 2020,
our five business areas comprised Filtration & Performance Solutions, Industrial Solutions, Decor, Specialties,
and North American Specialty Solutions. Our segmental reporting also includes Other and eliminations, which
includes head office costs comprising the group finance, corporate development, legal, research and
development, group communications, investor relations and group human resources.

In the new business structure, North America Specialty Solutions is integrated into the other business areas,
and businesses are partly reorganized to reflect our expansion in North America following the initial integration
phase of the North America Specialty Solutions business. The new business structure is comprised of sixteen
businesses that underlie the five business areas, as compared to fourteen businesses under our previous structure.
In the 2020 Financial Statements, we have restated our presentation of the financial information of our business
areas for the comparative year ended December 31, 2019 to reflect the new business structure and the restated
comparative business area information is unaudited. The business area financial information for the year ended
December 31, 2018 is presented based on our previous business areas and is therefore not comparable to the
business area information presented in the 2020 Financial Statements. In order to provide meaningful comparable
information in this Offering Memorandum, we present the financial information for the business areas for the
year ended December 31, 2019 based on the prior business areas when comparing to the financial information for
the year ended December 31, 2018, and, otherwise, based on the new business areas. See note 4 to the 2020
Financial Statements for further information on our new business area information.

_Segment Reporting Principles_

Our CEO, assisted by the Executive Management Team, is our chief operating decision maker. Operating
segments are determined on the basis of information reviewed by the CEO for the purposes of allocating
resources and assessing our business area’s performance. Each business area’s performance is assessed internally
on the basis of net sales and Comparable EBITDA. For internal management reporting purposes, Comparable
EBITDA is defined as operating result before depreciation, amortization and impairments and excluding items
affecting comparability. We define items affecting comparability as material items outside ordinary course of
business, such as gains and losses on business disposals, direct transaction costs related to business acquisitions,
costs for closure of business operations and restructurings including redundancy payments, one-off items arising
from purchase price allocation such as inventory fair value adjustments, compensation related to environmental
damages arising from unexpected or rare events and other items including fines (such as VAT tax audit fines) or
other similar stipulated payments and litigations.

For the year ended December 31, 2018 and following the acquisitions of Expera Specialty Solutions and
Caieiras, each business area’s performance was assessed internally on the basis of its net sales and Comparable
EBITDA, in each case pro forma for the acquisitions of Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras. Net sales, pro
forma for the acquisitions of Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras, is defined for internal management
reporting purposes as net sales giving pro forma effect to the net sales impact of the acquisitions of Expera
Specialty Solutions and Caieiras. Comparable EBITDA pro forma for the acquisitions of Expera Specialty
Solutions and Caieiras is defined for internal reporting purposes as EBITDA excluding certain items affecting
comparability and giving pro forma effect to the acquisitions of Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras. The pro
forma impact of the acquisitions of Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras on net sales and Comparable
EBITDA for internal management reporting purposes is presented as if Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras
had been consolidated to full-year results for the year ended December 31, 2018. See also “—Acquisitions and
_Disposals—Acquisitions of Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras” below._

_Acquisitions and Disposals_

consolidated financial statements from their respective dates of acquisition and are included in the statement of

_Reclassification of Certain Balance Sheet Items_

In 2019, we changed the classification of certain balance sheet items between interest-bearing and
non-interest-bearing liabilities. The comparative information as of December 31, 2018 has been restated
accordingly. The restatement as of December 31, 2018 from current borrowings to trade and other payables
amounted to €8.8 million. In 2019, lease liabilities were also reclassified from borrowings to a separate line item,
and lease liabilities as of December 31, 2018 were restated accordingly. The lease liabilities as of December 31,
2018 relate to finance leases in accordance with previously used IAS 17 (Leases) and the related interpretations,
which were replaced by IFRS 16 as of January 1, 2019. The restated information is unaudited.

_Changes to Accounting Standards_

We adopted the changes described below to accounting standards during the periods under review. These
other amendments did not have material impact on the amounts recognized in prior periods and are not expected
to significantly affect the current or future periods. See note 2 to each of the Financial Statements for further
information on accounting policies adopted during the relevant period.

_IFRS 16_

We adopted IFRS 16 (Leases) on January 1, 2019. IFRS 16 replaced IAS 17 (Leases) as well as the IFRIC
and SIC interpretations of IAS 17. The adoption of IFRS 16 resulted in almost all leases being recognized on the
balance sheet, as IFRS 16 eliminated the distinction between operating and finance leases. Under IFRS 16, the
lessee recognizes an asset (the right-to-use the leased asset) and a financial liability to make lease payments.
There are exceptions only for short-term and low-value leases. In accordance with IFRS 16, operating expenses
relating to leases are replaced by depreciation and interest expenses, resulting in changes to certain key metrics
including EBITDA. We adopted IFRS 16 using a simplified approach and thus comparative figures have not
been restated. The adoption of IFRS 16 increased the right-of-use assets under non-current assets by
€57.0 million, non-current lease liability by €44.1 million and current lease liability by €12.3 million in the
opening balance sheet as of January 1, 2019. The implementation of IFRS 16 had a positive impact of
€16.3 million on EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2019. See notes 2, 8, 9 and 12 to the 2019 Financial
Statements for more information.

_IFRIC 23_

We adopted IFRIC 23 (Uncertainty over Income Tax Treatments) on January 1, 2019. IFRIC 23 clarifies the
accounting for uncertainties in income taxes. As a result of the adoption of IFRIC 23, we recognized an
adjustment in an amount of €2.6 million in the opening balance sheet as of January 1, 2019 as a deduction in the
retained earnings and an increase in income tax liabilities. Our financial statements as of and for the year ended

xv

December 31, 2018 do not apply IFRIC 23. As a result, the results of operations for the year ended December 31,
2018 may not be directly comparable with the results of operations for the years ended December 31, 2019 and
2020.

_Impact of the Transactions_

On October 22, 2020, the Issuer launched the Tender Offer to acquire up to all of the Company Shares for
cash consideration equal to the Tender Offer Price. On February 4, 2021, following the first settlement of the
Tender Offer, the Issuer acquired approximately 81.0% of the Company Shares. On February 10, 2021, following
the settlement of the subsequent offer period, the Issuer acquired an additional 9.6% of the Shares. As of the date
of this Offering Memorandum, 2021, the Issuer owned approximately 90.6% of the Company Shares. After
completion of the Squeeze-Out, the Issuer will own 100% of the Company Shares. See “Summary—The
_Transactions—The Tender Offer.” None of the financial information in this Offering Memorandum has been_
adjusted to reflect the impact of any changes to the consolidated statement of financial position, consolidated
income statement and other comprehensive income (statement of comprehensive income), consolidated statement
of changes in equity and consolidated statement of cash flows that might occur as a result of purchase accounting
adjustments to be applied as a result of the Transactions. We will account for the Acquisition using the
acquisition method of accounting in accordance with IFRS 3 (Business Combinations). The application of
purchase accounting could result in different carrying values for existing assets and assets that may be added to
the statement of financial position, which may include intangible assets, such as goodwill, brands, rights of use,
contractual rights with franchisees leasehold rights and software, and different amortization and depreciation
expenses. Only certain limited as adjusted financial data of the Issuer is presented as adjusted to give effect to the
Transactions, including the Notes offered hereby. See “—As _Adjusted_ _Financial_ _Information”_ and
“Capitalization.” In the future, we may report our consolidated financial condition and results of operations at the
level of the Issuer, or at another entity, rather than at Ahlstrom-Munksjö. Due to these and other potential
adjustments, future financial statements for the Group could be materially different and may not be comparable
to our Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. See also “Management’s
_Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Factors Affecting the Comparability_
_of the Financial Statements—Impact of the Transactions” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and_
_Operations—An impairment of goodwill, other tangible assets or property, plant and equipment could have a_
_material adverse effect on our financial position or operating results.”_

**Non-IFRS Financial Measures**

This Offering Memorandum contains non-IFRS measures and ratios, including EBITDA, Comparable
EBITDA, Comparable EBITDA Margin, As Adjusted EBITDA, Operating Working Capital, Capital
expenditure, Maintenance capital expenditure, Cash conversion, Free cash flow, MOVC / ton, MOVC margin,
adjusted operating cash flow and other measures, which, in accordance with the “Alternative Performance
_Measures” guidance issued by the European Securities and Markets Authority (“ESMA”) are not accounting_
measures defined or specified in IFRS and are, therefore, considered alternative performance measures and as

xvi


-----

such comply with the ESMA guidance applicable to Ahlstrom-Munksjö as a listed company subject to EU
regulation. Such non-IFRS measures and ratios may not reflect accurately our performance, liquidity or our
ability to incur debt and should not be considered as a substitute to net result or any other performance measures
derived from or in accordance with IFRS, SEC requirements or any other generally accepted accounting
principles or as a substitute to net cash from/(used in) operating activities. The financial information contained in
this Offering Memorandum is not intended to comply with the reporting requirements of the SEC and will not be
subject to review by the SEC. As used in this Offering Memorandum, the following terms have the following
meanings:

   - “EBITDA” represents result before taxes, net financial items, depreciation, amortization and
impairment. The definition of EBITDA is compliant with ESMA guidance but is not intended to and
does not comply with the SEC definition of EBITDA as “Earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and
amortization”;

   - “Comparable EBITDA” represents EBITDA excluding items affecting comparability in EBITDA, such
as material items outside the ordinary course of business, such as gains and losses on business
disposals, direct transaction costs related to business acquisitions, costs for closure of business
operations and restructurings including redundancy payments, one-off items arising from purchase
price allocation such as inventory fair value adjustments, compensation related to environmental
damages arising from unexpected or rare events and other items, including fines (such as VAT tax
audit fines) or other similar stipulated payments and litigation, but excluding impairment losses in each
case, as further described under “Summary—Summary _Consolidated_ _Financial_ _and_ _Other_
_Information—As Adjusted Data of the Issuer”;_

   - “Comparable EBITDA Margin” represents Comparable EBITDA divided by net sales;

   - “As Adjusted EBITDA” represents Comparable EBITDA as adjusted for certain cost savings
programs, certain post-acquisition savings programs and a COVID-19 normalization, in each case, as
further described under “Summary—Summary Consolidated Financial and Other Information—As
_Adjusted Data of the Issuer”;_

   - “Operating Working Capital” represents inventories plus operative receivables before factoring less
operating payables;

   - “Capital expenditure” represents purchases for property, plant and equipment and intangible assets, as
presented in the consolidated cash flow statement;

   - “Capital expenditure to net sales ratio” represents Capital expenditure divided by net sales;

   - “Maintenance capital expenditure” represents 3% of net sales based on a management estimated based
on long-term average capital expenditures;

   - “Cash conversion” represents Free cash flow divided by Comparable EBITDA;

   - “Free cash flow” represents Comparable EBITDA minus Maintenance capital expenditure;

   - “MOVC” or “margin over variable costs” represents net sales minus variable costs of sales;

   - “MOVC / ton” represents our margin over variable costs per ton;

   - “MOVC margin” represents MOVC divided by net sales; and

   - “Adjusted operating cash flow” represents net cash from operating activities plus total items affecting
comparability in operating result net of taxes relating to items affecting comparability in operating
result.

We present non-IFRS measures for information purposes only. There can be no assurance that items we
have identified for adjustment as non-recurring will not recur in the future or that similar items will not be
incurred in the future. The calculations for Comparable EBITDA and As Adjusted EBITDA are based on various
assumptions, including, in the case of As Adjusted EBITDA, successful implementation of certain initiatives and
management or sponsor estimates. These amounts have not been, and, in certain cases, cannot be, audited,
reviewed or verified by any independent auditors’ firm. This information is inherently subject to risks and
uncertainties. It may not give an accurate or complete picture of the financial condition or results of operations
for the periods presented, may not be comparable to our consolidated financial statements or the other financial
information included in this Offering Memorandum, and should not be relied upon when making an investment
decision.

xvii


-----

We present non-IFRS measures because we believe that they are helpful to investors as measures of our
operating performance and ability to service our debt, and that they and similar measures are widely used by

payments that were made, or will in the future be made; and

**Overview**

We are a global leader in the production of high-performance fiber-based materials for a variety of
consumer and industrial end-uses. Our products are used in a broad range of industrial applications and
consumer-driven products and processes, ranging from everyday consumables, health care and life sciences,
homebuilding and furniture, industrial goods and transportation. Sustainability is central across our businesses,
and with our product offering we facilitate a sustainable everyday life by providing solutions with better
performance, safer materials, fewer resources and a lower environmental impact. Our net sales, operating result,
net result and Comparable EBITDA were €2,683.3 million, €176.2 million, €94.5 million and €334.2 million,
respectively, for the year ended December 31, 2020 and our As Adjusted EBITDA was €412.6 million for the
year ended December 31, 2020.

We produce fiber-based materials from pulp and other fibers, and then typically sell such materials to
converters who incorporate them in their end-products. We also produce certain end-products ourselves. Our
product offering includes filter materials, release liners, food and beverage processing and packaging materials,
decor papers, abrasive and tape backings, electrotechnical insulation paper, glass fiber materials, medical fabrics
and solutions for diagnostics, and a range of other specialty materials and pulp for industrial and consumer
end-uses. We develop our products in close cooperation with customers and other stakeholders in the valuechain, making use of our high technical expertise and broad experience. We design our custom-made and tailored
materials with a high degree of differentiation to meet and exceed specific customer demands concerning quality
and functionality, adding value for customers.

We target niche markets that benefit from value-based pricing and require technical specialization making it
more challenging for new market entrants. As a niche player, identifying trends and developing new customer
solutions are critical for our business. We have a strong focus on innovation and aim to regularly refresh our
offering and to improve sustainable functionality and design. Our recent innovations include FortiCell[®] launched
in 2020, a new range of fiber-based solutions for energy storage applications using amongst others our DISPRO
foam-forming technology, Extia[®] Protect, a comprehensive range of materials for face masks using fine fiber
technology, and BioWeb[®] and Fiber+ ranges, which use renewable biopolymer polylactic acid for producing
biodegradable and compostable tea bag materials. Our sales from New Products increased to 12% for the year
ended December 31, 2020.

We serve a diverse customer base with more than 6,000 customers in over 100 countries. For the year ended
December 31, 2020, 37% of our sales were to customers in the consumer goods sector, 27% in the homebuilding
and furniture sector, 14% in the transportation sector, 11% in the industrials sector and 11% in the health care
and life sciences sector. For the year ended December 31, 2020, our top-five and top-ten largest customers
generated 13% and 19% of our net sales, respectively.

We manufacture our products globally and have 45 manufacturing plants and converting sites in 14
countries. We consume commodity pulp as part of the manufacturing process. Our commodity pulp consumption
was approximately 1,200 thousand tons for the year ended December 31, 2020. Our pulp exposure was reduced
by approximately 500 thousand tons of our own pulp production during that same period, which includes
185 thousand tons of market pulp production at our Aspa pulp mill in Sweden that is sold to third parties. We
believe that our global manufacturing footprint represents a competitive advantage and would be challenging for
new market entrants to replicate given its specification and scale. Our manufacturing sites are equipped to
provide and apply innovative technology, including FluoroFree[®] capabilities (providing grease resistance without


1


-----

fluorochemicals), Parchmentizing technology (transforming cellulose to give it plastic-like qualities) and fine
fiber technology with multi-row spinning, which was recently adapted to also produce face masks. We delivered
a total of approximately 1,570 thousand tons of materials in the year ended December 31, 2020. We organize
delivery of our products directly to many of our business-to-business customers using third-party transport
service providers.

We were formed by the merger of Ahlstrom Corporation and Munksjö Oyj on April 1, 2017, which created
a global leader in the production of high-performance fiber-based materials. Our two predecessor companies
have a long history in the Finnish and Swedish forestry and paper industry. Since the merger, we have grown
significantly through the acquisitions of the Caieiras specialty paper mill in Brazil and Expera Specialty
Solutions in North America, each in October 2018.

**_Business Areas_**

We are organized into five business areas and reporting segments that are further divided into 16 businesses
as listed below:

   - **Filtration & Performance Solutions: Filtration, Nonwovens, Glass Fiber Tissue, Abrasive**

   - **Advanced Solutions: Liquid Technologies, Beverage & Casing, Medical, Tape, Precision Coating**

   - **Industrial Solutions: Insulation, Release Liners, Coated Specialties**

   - **Food Packaging & Technical Solutions: Food Packaging, Technical, Parchment**

   - **Decor Solutions: Decor**

We manage our platform of 16 businesses with group-level functions such as sourcing, IT, legal and
compliance, finance and human resources. Each business is accountable for its own operational and financial
performance, while we set the strategic direction, decide on priorities and resource allocation and provide support
and economies of scale for the business at the group level.

We also report net sales across five regions and 12 geographies. For the year ended December 31, 2020, our

_Filtration & Performance Solutions business area_

Filtration & Performance Solutions comprised 23.4% of our net sales and 34.8% of our Comparable
EBITDA, in each case, excluding the impact of Other and eliminations for the year ended December 31, 2020.
The Filtration & Performance Solutions business area includes the Filtration, Nonwovens, Glass Fiber Tissues,
and Abrasive businesses, with estimated market sizes of €1,200 million, €190 million, €160 million and
€200 million, respectively.

The Filtration business produces high-performance filtration materials from natural or synthetic fibers or a
combination of both for transportation applications, such as engine oils, fuels, air used in vehicles, and industrial
applications, such as heating, ventilation and air conditioning (“HVAC”) and air pollution control. The


2


-----

Nonwovens business offers a broad range of nonwoven materials used for automotive interiors, plasterboards,
hygiene, wallcover and wipes. The Glass Fiber Tissue business produces glass fiber tissue primarily for flooring
applications and a range of building and transportation related applications. The Abrasive business produces
specialty papers used in industrial and do-it-yourself sandpaper.

_Advanced Solutions business area_

The Advanced Solutions business area comprised 17.5% of our net sales and 17.9% of our Comparable
EBITDA, in each case, excluding the impact of Other and eliminations for the year ended December 31, 2020.
The Advanced Solutions business area includes the Liquid Technologies, Beverage & Casing, Medical, Tape and
Precision Coating businesses, with estimated market sizes of €400 million, €350 million, €830 million,
€400 million and €250 million, respectively.

The Liquid Technologies business produces high-quality filters for laboratory sample preparation and life
science diagnostics materials that are used by laboratories and manufacturers of rapid test kits and for highperformance filter media, an alternative to membrane technology, that has the ability to efficiently remove a wide
range of harmful contaminants. The Beverage & Casing business produces material for tea bags, coffee pods and
casings with a focus on sustainability. The Medical business produces medical fabrics used in sterile barrier
systems, drapes, gowns, facemasks and sterilization wraps, all used primarily in surgery but also in cleanrooms
and laboratories. The Tape business produces tape backings for masking and packaging specialty tape
manufacturers used in the construction and automotive industries and packaging applications for e-commerce
and for specialty purposes. The Precision Coating business produces a variety of release liners for specialty
end-uses, including fiber composites for the medical and tape applications.

_Industrial Solutions business area_

Industrial Solutions comprised 25.1% of our net sales and 20.9% of our Comparable EBITDA, in each case,
excluding the impact of Other and eliminations for the year ended December 31, 2020. The Industrial Solutions
business area includes the Insulation, Release Liners and Coated Specialties businesses, with estimated market
sizes of €250 million, €1,300 million and €2,200 million, respectively.

The Insulation business supplies electrotechnical insulation materials to manufacturers of transformers and
high voltage cables globally. The Insulation business also produces thin papers used as interleaves, textile print
masking papers as well as finish foils and balancing foils under the brand Spantex[TM]. In addition, the Insulation
business produces specialty bleached and unbleached long-fiber cellulose pulp. The Release Liners business
produces papers that, after coating of silicone from its customer, can be used to carry self-adhesive labels or for
manufacturing and assembling adhesive materials and components in industrial processes. The Coated
Specialties business manufactures coated label papers, flexible packaging papers for fast-moving consumables
and processed foods, as well as office, printing and writing papers.

_Food Packaging & Technical Solutions business area_

The Food Packaging & Technical Solutions business area comprised 20.4% of our net sales and 15.4% of our
Comparable EBITDA, in each case, excluding the impact of Other and eliminations for the year ended December 31,
2020. The Food Packaging & Technical Solutions business area includes the Food Packaging, Technical and
Parchment businesses, with estimated market sizes of €1,400 million, €1,600 million and €200 million, respectively.

The Food Packaging business offers a broad range of specialty papers and capabilities for quick service
restaurants, food processing, cooking and baking, and flexible packaging markets. The Technical business
produces specialty products used for a wide variety of industrial and construction applications. The Parchment
business produces a broad portfolio of solutions for food and industrial applications. The Parchment business
product portfolio includes cooking and baking papers, panliners, baking-trays and molds. In addition, parchment
is used in the textile tube and furniture laminate industries.

_Decor Solutions business area_

Decor Solutions business area includes the Decor business, which comprised 13.6% of our net sales and
11.0% of our Comparable EBITDA, in each case, excluding the impact of Other and eliminations for the year
ended December 31, 2020. The Decor business produces paper in a wide range of colors, grades and grammages


3


-----

for decorative applications mainly used in laminated furniture, flooring and interior applications both for
technical and esthetical purposes. The market size for products offered by our Decor Solutions business area is
€2,600 million.

**Strengths**

**_Leading producer of environmental and sustainability focused high performance fiber-based materials_**
**_requiring technical specialization making it more challenging for new market participants as compared to_**
**_commodity paper_**

We are a leading producer of specialty, high-performance fiber-based materials which contribute to a more
sustainable everyday life. Our specialty products have attractive price points and margins, as we are generally
able to set prices based on value, as compared to the cost-plus pricing of commodity products. In addition, the
specialty, high-performance market is growing in line with the increasing customer focus on health, safety and
sustainability, on which our business is focused, with an expected annual growth of approximately two to five
percent. This growth rate is particularly attractive when compared to commodities. The following table illustrates
the attractive price points based on the higher average selling prices and margins, market growth and average

Sustainability is central across our business. In response to increasing customer focus on sustainability and
demand for sustainable products and solutions, we design and launch solutions with better performance, safer
materials, fewer resources and a lower environmental impact. We provide sustainable and safe food packaging
and focus on compostable and biodegradable solutions. Our mineral oil barrier paper, paraffin wax-free paper,
FluoroFree[®] technology providing fluorochemicals-free grease-resistant papers, tea-bags, flushable wipes and
other products directly cater to a market trend towards more sustainable solutions and respond to stricter food
safety and chemical regulations. We also produce “Plastic Free” products such as plastic-free tea bags, singleserve coffee and casing materials, GenReleaz[™], cards for collection of bio samples, and our CelluStraw[™] an
alternative to the plastic straw. Our “Plastic Free” products provide alternatives to single-use plastics alongside
improved packaging functionality. We also produce recyclable products that help support the circular economy
by reducing waste. We believe increasing customer awareness towards health and safety is also partially driving
the market for our formaldehyde free papers, water purification filter media using its proprietary Disruptor[®]
technology, air and liquid filtration products, facemasks and other products.

Our businesses are also characterized by a high level of technological, customization and qualification
requirements as is required to effectively compete in our relevant markets, which we believe makes it more
challenging for new market participants. Technical and engineered products, in particular, involve manufacturing
complexity, R&D and investment and heightened environmental and safety standards. We operate a global
manufacturing platform, in which we have made significant investments over the prior year, that grants us a
competitive advantage over competitors and that may be hard for competitors to replicate. Product designs for
specific customer specifications, in particular, often require joint product development with the customers and
sometimes take several years to develop. In addition, many of our products require rigorous certifications and/or
long qualification processes, such as certifications for products destined for the aerospace industry and customer
qualification standards for composite release liners and high technical specifications for filter media solutions,
which help to protect our businesses from both conversion risk and other market players. In the year ended
December 31, 2019, we had customers covering 17% of our net sales with whom we had a relationship of over
10 years, demonstrating our ability to produce specialty, high-performance materials to the degree of specificity
and with the certifications that they require.

**_Leading positions across segments with attractive growth profiles_**

All of our sixteen businesses hold leading positions in their strategic segments, with a majority holding
positions as global leaders, while others hold positions as regional leaders. The Nonwovens, Glass Fiber Tissue,
Abrasive, Tape and Parchment businesses are global leaders in the segments for nonwoven wallcoverings, vinyl
flooring, abrasive paper backings, masking tape backings and cooking and baking parchment papers,
respectively. The Filtration, Liquid Technologies, Beverage & Casing, Release Liners and Insulation businesses
each hold number two positions globally in the engine and industrial filtration, macro filtration in laboratory and
in fiber-based solutions in the life science product segments as well as fry oil filters, tea bag and fibrous meat
casing materials, self-adhesive labels and industrial processes and electrotechnical and steel interleaving,
respectively. The Technical business holds a number two position in North America in the technical papers
segment. Our other businesses also occupy leading positions in their respective strategic segments.

**_Limited exposure to raw material cost and proven pricing power_**

We have a structured and systematic procurement process and have been able to improve our margin over
variable costs (“MOVC”) during 2020 despite volatility in pulp prices due to the low price sensitivity of our
products and by ensuring commercial excellence, business development, innovation and product development,
cost efficiency and productivity and optimizing our business processes and investments. Our MOVC per ton was
€674, €660, €699 and €721 on average in each of the years ended December 31, 2017, 2018, 2019 and 2020,
respectively. Our cost base is primarily variable, with variable costs, such as fibers, including pulp, other raw
materials and energy, constituting 65% of our total costs for the year ended December 31, 2020, as detailed
below:

Our commodity pulp consumption was approximately 1,200 thousand tons for the year ended December 31,
2020. Our pulp exposure was reduced by approximately 500 thousand tons of our own pulp production during the
year ended December 31, 2020, which includes 185 thousand tons of market pulp production at our Aspa pulp
mill in Sweden that is sold to third parties. We are typically able to pass through a portion of, or, depending on
the business, the entirety of, any increases in the cost of pulp to our customers by increasing the selling prices of
our products. We typically include contractual or indexed pass-through clauses in our contracts with customers.
For the remainder, we have a strong historical track record of being able to pass through price increases to our
customers, which is possible due to our strong market positions, our exposure to attractive and niche specialty
markets, our value-based pricing approach and the low price sensitivity for many of our products. This low price
sensitivity is the result of our products often being a vital part of our customers’ finished goods and as a result
constitute a relatively low proportion of the overall cost thereof. In addition, our products often perform a key
niche function in the finished good, in contrast to commodity paper, further contributing to low price sensitivity.
The specialized nature of our products also aids in our ability to pass-through increases in raw materials prices as
often they are difficult to replace or substitute. The natural hedge from our own pulp production, combined with
the low price sensitivity of our products and our strong ability to pass-through pulp price increases to customers,
helps to ensure that our profit and cash flows are highly resilient from swings in pulp prices. For instance MOVC
per ton remained relatively stable between 2017 and 2018, decreasing only by 2% or €14 per ton, even though
pulp prices increased by 30% during that period.

**_Diversified business model across customer-base, end-markets and geographies_**

We provide our products and solutions to a diverse base of over 6,000 customers engaged in a variety of
industries, including healthcare & life sciences, engineered industrial products, transportation, food & beverages,
consumer goods, construction and furniture, across more than 100 countries. Our top ten customers generated
19.0% of our net sales in the year ended December 31, 2020, with no single customer representing more than
10% of our net sales. Our top one hundred customers generated 48.3% of our net sales in the year ended
December 31, 2020. Our products serve diverse end markets, which makes our business inherently resilient. In
addition, our products are widely used in industries that are less cyclical and the end-markets for some of our
businesses, such as Medical and Liquid Technologies, are noncyclical, further enhancing our resilience. While
Europe and North America constitute 43.2% and 34.7% of our net sales in the year ended December 31, 2020,
we have also strengthened our presence in South America with our recent acquisition of Caieiras in 2018 and are
currently exploring strategic opportunities in the Decor business in China in order to benefit from market
opportunities and for purposes of managing our portfolio.

Having a diversified business model with high pass-through and internal pulp production provides stability
across macroeconomic cycles as we are cushioned from negative industry trends through our exposure to
multiple industries, which allows greater predictability of overall earnings and growth and resilience to
downturns. For example, the results of operations of each of our predecessors, Ahlstrom Corporation and
Munksjö Oyj remained largely stable during the global financial crisis that began in 2008. Similarly, our
Comparable EBITDA of €334.2 million during the year ended December 31, 2020 was 6.8% higher than the year
ended December 31, 2019, in spite of the global slowdown caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, though net sales
for this period decreased by 8.0% due to adverse currency effects, lower selling prices and a less favorable
product mix. While some of our businesses such as Filtration, Decor, Technical, Insulation and Precision Coating
were negatively impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, our Medical business (particularly due to increased
demand for face masks), Liquid Technologies and repurposed activities in our Filtration business, outperformed
prior periods. Diversified exposure in terms of customers, end-market and geography, with high pass-through and


7


-----

internal pulp production, where net short pulp position also mitigates cyclicality, given pulp prices typically are
low when macro activity is low, also contributes to our resilience.

**_Historical high Cash conversion together with strategic deployment of capital to create future capacity_**

We have a track record of profitable growth and free cash flow generation. Our Comparable EBITDA for
the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020 was €277.7 million, €312.9 million and €334.2 million,
respectively. Our Free cash flow for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020 was €205 million,
€225 million, and €254 million, respectively, and our Cash conversion during the same period was 74%, 72%
and 76%, respectively. During the same period, our Capital expenditures were €160.1 million, €161.1 million and
€117.5 million, respectively, our Capital expenditures to net sales ratio was 7%, 6% and 4%, respectively, and
net cash from operating activities was €91.6 million, €286.7 million and €255.1 million, respectively. We believe
that this level of capital expenditure is higher than our long-term Maintenance capital expenditure, which
management estimates to be approximately 3% of net sales per annum, and reflects a temporary, elevated level of
capital expenditures targeting growth in order to better position us to capture further market share. Since 2017,
we have been progressing with our €200 million strategic investment program, which includes investments in
13 projects, aimed at allowing us to increase and improve our production capabilities and providing us with an
opportunity to grow, while retaining attractive cash flows. Of these 13 projects, 11 have been completed, while
the remaining are scheduled to be completed during 2021 and 2022.

A significant proportion of our Capital expenditures in 2018 and 2019 were related to projects undertaken in
the Filtration business in Madisonville, United States, the Abrasive business in Arches, France, the Parchment
business in San Severin, France, and the Coated Specialties business in Jacareí, Brazil, and a boiler and pulp line
rebuild in our plant in Billingsfors, Sweden, part of the Insulation business. Given these significant investments
in increasing capacity and improving manufacturing capabilities, we believe our production facilities are
relatively well-invested and that we are well-positioned to support future growth. We estimate that our
Maintenance capital expenditure is approximately 3% of our net sales, and we estimate that approximately
€90 million of annual capital expenditures (including IT spending) are required to maintain the competitiveness
of our current portfolio which supports our product capability.

**_Significant Transformation Opportunity Leveraging Bain Capital’s Experience from its portfolio company,_**
**_Fedrigoni_**

Bain Capital has a strong track record of driving cost savings and improvements in margin, while at the
same time growing its portfolio companies both organically and through targeted acquisitions. Bain Capital is the
majority shareholder of Fedrigoni, a leading European manufacturer and distributor of pressure sensitive labels
and luxury papers, demonstrating extensive and relevant experience of achieving operational improvements in
the same sector similar to the planned strategies for the Group. Since Fedrigoni’s acquisition by Bain Capital,
Fedrigoni’s sales growth have accelerated, and adjusted EBITDA has doubled, with a focus on increasing organic
growth, successfully integrating a number of bolt-on acquisitions, as well as driving significant operating
improvements through pricing, procurement and operating efficiencies. Fedrigoni has also improved their passthrough of cost of raw materials through pricing optimization. Through competitive sourcing, volumes
optimization and reallocation, volumes planning, supplier cooperation, as well as contract optimization,
Fedrigoni achieved meaningful savings on procurement spend. In addition, through value engineering and recipe
optimization, overall equipment effectiveness debottlenecking, maintenance, repair and operations optimization
and energy efficiency, Fedrigoni achieved meaningful savings on direct costs baseline. Based on Bain Capital’s
tested playbook from Fedrigoni, our Sponsors have identified over €200 million of profit improvement
opportunities and we expect to action approximately €30 million of such opportunities in the next 18 months.

**Our Strategies**

We and the Sponsors have developed the following strategies:

**_Invest for long-term growth across the business_**

We operate in attractive niche specialty markets and our businesses are well-positioned to capture growth in
their respective markets. All of our sixteen businesses hold leading positions in their strategic segments, with a
majority holding positions as global leaders, while others hold positions as regional leaders. The average market
growth rates of many of the underlying market segments we operate in are growing at or above underlying GDP
rates prior to the COVID-19 pandemic and we expect these markets to continue to grow in the medium-to longterm. We plan to build on this position and capture further market share and to accelerate our growth. We invest
in innovation and product development and we operate extensive research and development capabilities in each
business area. Since 2017, we have been progressing with our €200 million strategic investment program, which
includes investments in 13 projects, aimed at allowing us to increase and improve our production capabilities and
providing us with an opportunity to grow, while retaining attractive cash flows. We plan to continue to drive
growth through selected investments where necessary in our businesses or regions in which we see profitable
growth opportunities.

**_Increase focus on environmental and sustainable specialty materials in line with customer preferences_**

The specialty, high-performance market is growing in line with the increasing customer focus on health,
safety and sustainability with an expected annual growth of approximately two to five percent. Increased
customer focus on environmental and sustainability concerns is causing a significant shift in the preferences for
specialty materials across applications and end uses and continues to drive growth. We believe that we can
significantly benefit from this trend in the mid-term, given our focus on specialty fiber-based materials and our
existing portfolio of sustainable, plastic-free and circular economy focused products. Our new product
development is focused on products that make a positive contribution to sustainability. We will continue to
develop sustainable products focused on moving towards alternatives to traditional plastics. We plan to capitalize
on these opportunities and emphasize the position of our business as an environmental and sustainable leader in
our market segments.

**_Focus on profitability and opportunities to drive further margin improvements_**

We believe there is a significant opportunity to increase profitability by driving further margin
improvements. Prior to the Transactions, we focused on increasing margins and improving overall profitability
with a €50 million savings program targeting variable cost reduction through procurement savings and other
improvement actions, which was completed ahead of schedule and exceeded targets. The Sponsors intend to
continue and expand upon the implementation of certain of our cost savings initiatives from which we expect to
derive significant cost savings and improve our margins. Bain Capital is the majority shareholder of Fedrigoni, a
leading European manufacturer and distributor of pressure sensitive labels and luxury papers. Based on Bain
Capital’s tested playbook for the specialty materials market, as evidenced by the increase in sales and


9


-----

improvements in the pass-through of cost of raw materials by Bain Capital’s portfolio company, Fedrigoni, we
see significant opportunity to further increase the profitability of the business, through areas such as
procurement, pricing, operational efficiency and general cost optimization. In addition to management’s cost
savings program, our Sponsors have identified over €200 million of profit improvement opportunities and we
expect to action approximately €30 million of such opportunities in the next 18 months. See “—Summary
_Consolidated Financial and Other Information—As Adjusted Data of the Issuer.”_

**_Portfolio management through selective acquisition, divestment and other investment opportunities_**

We will continue to consider selective acquisition and divestment opportunities on an on-going basis as they
arise in order to manage our portfolio to focus on enhancing our profitability. As part of our long-term
investment strategy, we continually evaluate potential acquisitions to grow our business in the market segments
we operate, capture market share and accelerate growth. For example, we are currently exploring opportunities to
acquire or invest in Minglian, a Chinese company comprising a greenfield decor paper plant in the city of
Xingtai, Hebei Province, China in order to increase our presence in China, which is the largest decor market. In
addition, we are actively considering strategic alternatives in relation to our entire Decor paper business,
including any potential ownership in Minglian, where one of the options being investigated is the possibility of a
divestment of the Decor business. Our mid-term objective is to refocus the business on higher value segments,
and increase presence in areas where we hold stronger, more differentiated positions.

**The Transactions**

**_The Acquisitions_**

_The Tender Offer_

On September 24, 2020, the Issuer and Ahlstrom-Munksjö entered into the Combination Agreement,
pursuant to which the Issuer announced a voluntary public cash tender offer with an offer price of €18.10 in cash
for each share validly tendered (the “Initially Announced Offer Price”) for all of the issued and outstanding
shares in Ahlstrom-Munksjö that are not held by Ahlstrom-Munksjö and its subsidiaries (the “Company Shares”
and the offer, the “Tender Offer”). The completion of the Tender Offer was subject to satisfaction of certain
conditions, including acceptance of the Tender Offer by shareholders holding more than 90% (on a fully diluted
basis) of the Company Shares and voting rights carried by the Company Shares, calculated in accordance with
applicable Finnish laws governing the right to commence compulsory squeeze-out proceedings (the “Minimum
Acceptance Condition”), together with any Company Shares otherwise held by the Issuer prior to the date of the
announcement of the final result of the Tender Offer. The Board of Directors of Ahlstrom-Munksjö, represented
by a quorum comprising the non-conflicted members of the Board of Directors, unanimously recommended that
the shareholders of Ahlstrom-Munksjö accept the Tender Offer. The Initially Announced Offer Price was
subsequently adjusted first to €17.97 per share and then to €17.84 per share (the “Tender Offer Price”) in
accordance with the terms and conditions of the Tender Offer, to account for two payments of dividend by the
Board of Directors of Ahlstrom-Munksjö after the Tender Offer was announced.

On January 15, 2021, the preliminary results of the Tender Offer were announced. The 50,386,853
Company Shares tendered in the Tender Offer, together with the total of 345,524 Company Shares acquired by
the Issuer through market purchases and the Company Shares which were to be received by Ahlstrom Invest
from the internal reorganization involving certain Ahlström family members and certain related entities and
which Ahlstrom Invest B.V. had undertaken to tender into the Tender Offer, represented approximately 81.1% of
all the Company Shares and voting rights carried by the Company Shares in Ahlstrom-Munksjö. On January 18,
2021, the Issuer announced that on the basis of the preliminary results of the Tender Offer, it decided to waive
the Minimum Acceptance Condition and complete the Tender Offer in accordance with its terms and conditions
provided that the final result of the Tender Offer confirmed that the Tender Offer had been validly accepted by
shareholders holding at least 75% (on a fully diluted basis) of the Company Shares and voting rights carried by
the Company Shares, calculated in accordance with Chapter 18, Section 1 of the Finnish Companies Act.

When the final result of the initial offer period under the Tender Offer was published on January 20, 2021,
the Company Shares validly tendered and accepted in the Tender Offer (including the Company Shares received
by Ahlstrom Invest B.V. as a result of the internal reorganization involving certain Ahlström family members
and certain related entities), together with the Company Shares acquired by the Issuer through market purchases,
represented approximately 81.0 % of all the Company Shares and voting rights carried by the Company Shares.
As such, the Issuer announced that it would complete the Tender Offer as the Minimum Acceptance Condition
had been waived and all other conditions to completion were fulfilled. The Issuer also announced that it would
commence a subsequent offer period in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Tender Offer (the
“Subsequent Offer Period”) in order to provide the remaining shareholders of Ahlstrom-Munksjö the opportunity
to accept the Tender Offer. On February 9, the Issuer announced the final result of the Subsequent Offer Period,
pursuant to which the Company Shares validly tendered and accepted during the Subsequent Offer Period,
together with the Company Shares validly tendered and accepted during the initial offer period (as extended) and
otherwise acquired by the Issuer through market purchases until February 8, 2021, represented approximately
90.6 per cent of all the Company Shares and voting rights carried by the Company Shares.

On February 4, 2021 (the “Initial Settlement Date”), the first settlement under the Tender Offer occurred
with respect to Company Shares registered with Euroclear Finland Oy and on February 5, 2021 with respect to
Company Shares registered with Euroclear Sweden AB, and the Issuer acquired approximately 81.0% of the
Company Shares. On February 10, 2021 (the “Second Settlement Date”), the second settlement under the Tender
Offer occurred with respect to Company Shares registered with Euroclear Finland Oy and on February 11, 2021
with respect to Company Shares registered with Euroclear Sweden AB, and the Issuer acquired an additional
9.6% of the Company Shares. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Issuer owned approximately
90.6% of the Company Shares.

_The Squeeze-Out_

Under Chapter 18, Section 1 of the Finnish Companies Act, a shareholder holding more than nine-tenths of
the total number of shares and voting rights in a limited liability company has the right to redeem and, subject to
a demand by other shareholders, is also obligated to redeem the shares owned by the other shareholders in a
company at a fair price. The shares held by the company or its subsidiaries are not taken into account when
calculating the aggregate number of the shares and voting rights for the purposes of said Section.

The Issuer has on February 11, 2021 notified Ahlstrom-Munksjö of its decision to exercise its redemption
right pursuant to the Finnish Companies Act and to redeem all the Company Shares held by any other remaining
shareholders in Ahlstrom-Munksjö. To implement the redemption of the remaining Company Shares, the Issuer
has filed an application to initiate arbitration proceedings as provided in the Finnish Companies Act. In the
redemption proceedings, the Issuer will seek a redemption price of €17.84 per Share for the remaining Company
Shares, which corresponds to the Tender Offer Price. The arbitral tribunal will determine the timing of the
redemption proceedings and eventually decide on the redemption price payable by the Issuer for the remaining
Company Shares. The Issuer intends to apply for the delisting of the Company Shares from Nasdaq Helsinki Ltd
and Nasdaq Stockholm AB as soon as permitted and reasonably practicable under applicable laws and
regulations and the rules of said stock exchanges.

Following the completion of the Squeeze-Out, we may undertake certain reorganizations of members of the
Group located in Sweden, France or Italy.

_The Refinancing_

In connection with the Acquisitions, the Issuer entered into the Bridge Facilities Agreements, which provide
for the EUR Bridge Facility in an aggregate principal amount of €600,000,000 and the USD Bridge Facility in an
aggregate principal amount of $484,936,000. The Issuer used, or will use, the proceeds from the Bridge
Facilities, the Equity Contributions from the Sponsors and drawings under the Senior Term Facilities, to finance
its acquisition of the Company Shares offered pursuant to the Tender Offer, to prepay or redeem the Existing
Senior Unsecured Notes, the Hybrid Bond and certain existing bank loans (excluding the Pension Loan, local
lines, leases and other bank loans being rolled over), to pay certain costs and expenses and for the other uses as
described under “—The Acquisitions—Sources and Uses for the Acquisitions.”

The proceeds from the Offering, together with a portion of the proceeds from the Senior Term Facilities and
cash on hand, will be used by the Issuer to refinance the indebtedness outstanding under the Bridge Facilities
and, in particular:

   - approximately €274.6 million for the purposes of refinancing the proceeds of the Bridge Facilities
utilized to pay the purchase price of €1,859.6 of the Company Shares that have been acquired by the
Issuer as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, representing approximately 90.6% of the Company
Shares, (ii) pay costs, fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Acquisitions and the other
transactions as described above, including legal, accounting, ratings advisory and other transaction
costs and professional fees, and (iii) pay costs, fees and expenses incurred in connection with the
Offering representing all the proceeds from Tranche A (as defined below) under the Notes; and

**Recent Developments**

**_Response to COVID-19_**

On January 23, 2020, we initiated a centralized crisis alert team to carry out a global pandemic contingency
and preparedness response plan. We established a COVID-19 Safety Protocol to ensure safe operations and
customer service. Our manufacturing plants are maintaining a cohesive set of rules to keep operations running
and employees safe. Local adjustments are made according to country-level or local health and safety regulation
and guidance.

Our 45 plants and converting sites in 14 countries remained operational during 2020 and have continued to
remain operational in the first months of 2021, except for a few temporary shutdowns caused by government
lockdowns or employee absences related to quarantine or infections. Production has not been interrupted to any
significant extent due to raw material supply issues.

The impact of the pandemic on customer activity has varied. Since the first quarter of 2020, we have
experienced strong demand in the healthcare and life science end-use segments. Demand for solutions for
personal protection equipment such as face masks, drape and gown materials, as well as diagnostics materials for
rapid test kits and venting filters for devices used in the treatment of patients with respiratory disorders was
strong in 2020. The exceptional circumstances, with regional lockdowns and limited mobility for citizens, also
increased demand for packaging-related release liner and packaging tape applications. In the second quarter of
2020, demand for home building and furniture, transportation and industrial end-uses decreased due to a large
portion of the global population being in lockdown. In the third quarter of 2020, demand recovered for home
building and furniture, driven mainly by increased household furniture spending, as well as transportation end
uses. Towards the end of 2020, demand for industrial-related products improved. Overall demand for consumer
goods related applications, of which food and beverage and packaging represent the largest share, remained
relatively stable during 2020, but varied somewhat, depending on end use. The resurgence of the COVID-19
pandemic in the fourth quarter of 2020 caused many countries to reimpose restrictions, but these lighter and more
regional lockdowns did not have a material impact on demand in the fourth quarter of 2020.

The COVID-19 pandemic has created an exceptional situation globally and a strong demand for healthcare
goods in general, and particularly for protective medical products made from our fabrics. We have long been an
established manufacturer of nonwoven fabrics, which are used to construct protective medical fabrics such as
surgical gowns and drapes, pleated surgical face masks, protective apparel and sterile barrier systems. We have
produced the inner and outer coverstock used for pleated surgical face masks, and have recently begun to
produce the middle filter media. Thanks to our in-depth knowledge of filtration materials and common
manufacturing platform, we were able to respond swiftly to growing demand by expanding manufacturing of
face mask fabrics to lines normally used for producing other fiber-based materials. Our offering included a full
range of protective face mask fabrics for civil, surgical and respiratory masks. This allowed us to fill production
capacity for filtration materials that would have otherwise remained unused, in particular during the second and
third quarters of 2020. During the second half of 2020, our delivery volumes of face mask fabrics gradually
decreased as production and export of face masks in China resumed and global availability and price competition
increased. We also expanded our manufacturing capacity for face masks at several of our facilities.

The financial impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on us was relatively limited in 2020. We incurred some
additional costs as a result of increased health and safety measures, securing the functionality of our operations
through increased logistics and overtime spend, shutdowns and servicing additional demand. We also
experienced a negative impact on net sales compared to 2019 driven primarily by adverse currency effects, lower
selling prices and a less favorable product mix, including due to COVID-19. While some of our business areas
experienced lower sales volumes, our Group-wide volumes were only slightly lower as a result of increased
demand, in Medical, for face mask materials, and, in Liquid Technologies, for rapid test kits and face masks. In
addition, we took numerous actions across the organization to cushion the short-term financial impact of the
expected decline in delivery volumes and to support our liquidity position, including the implementation of
temporary layoffs, reduction of working hours and the minimization of the use of external personnel and
services. We also reduced spending and postponed certain projects. Members of the Executive Management
Team and the CEO took a 50% and 100% reduction, respectively, on one month’s salary during the second
quarter of 2020. The Board of Directors also decided to forgo their compensation for one month in the second
quarter. Savings from these actions were approximately €24 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. As a
result, we estimate that the COVID-19 pandemic had a net negative impact of approximately €26 million on
Comparable EBITDA. See also “—Summary Consolidated Financial and Other Information—As Adjusted Data
_of the Issuer.”_
