(b) in respect of a Post Squeeze-Out Guarantor incorporated in the
United States or Finland, floating security over substantially
all assets located in its jurisdiction of incorporation (subject to
customary “excluded assets,” including real estate, and other
customary exclusions, materiality thresholds and exceptions),

in each case, where to do so would not have a material adverse
effect on their ability to conduct their business and operations, as
determined by each such Post Squeeze-Out Guarantor in its sole
and absolute discretion (the “Post Squeeze-Out Collateral” and,
together with the Issue Date Collateral, the “Collateral”).

Subject to and in accordance with the Agreed Security Principles, the
Collateral will also secure the Senior Secured Credit Facilities. The
security interests may be limited by applicable law or subject to certain
defenses that may limit their validity and enforceability. In addition, the
security interests in the Collateral may be released under certain
circumstances. Subject to the provisions of Indenture and the
Intercreditor Agreement, the Collateral may be pledged to secure future


20


-----

indebtedness. For more information on the security interests granted, see
“Description of the Notes—Security” and for more information on
potential limitations to the security interests, see “Certain Insolvency
_Law Considerations and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability_
_of the Note Guarantees and the Security Interests” and “Risk Factors—_
_Risks Related to the Notes and Our Structure.”_

Use of Proceeds . . . . . . . . . . . . . . The proceeds from the Offering of the Notes, together with a portion of
the proceeds from the Senior Term Facilities and cash, will be: (i) used
to refinance the indebtedness outstanding under the Bridge Facilities;
and (ii) used to pay the costs, fees and expenses incurred in connection
with the Offering, including financial advisory, legal, accounting, ratings
advisory and other transaction costs and professional fees. See “Use of
_Proceeds.”_

Additional Amounts . . . . . . . . . . . Any payments made by the Issuer or any Guarantor with respect to the
Notes or Note Guarantees will be made without withholding or
deduction for taxes unless required by law. If such withholding or
deduction is required by law in any “relevant taxing jurisdiction,” the
Issuer or the relevant Guarantor, as applicable, will pay the additional
amounts necessary so that the net amounts received after the withholding
or deduction is not less than the amount that would have been received
in the absence of the withholding or deduction, subject to certain
exceptions. See “Description of the Notes—Withholding Taxes.”

Optional Redemption . . . . . . . . . . The Issuer may redeem all or part of each series of Notes on or after
, 2024, at the redemption prices set forth under “Description
_of the Notes—Optional Redemption,” plus accrued and unpaid interest_
and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption.

Prior to, 2024, the Issuer may on any one or more occasions
redeem up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of each series of
Notes originally issued under the Indenture (including the original
principal amount of any additional Notes), using the net proceeds from
certain equity offerings at a redemption price equal to % of the
principal amount of the Notes so redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid
interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but not including, the applicable
date of redemption; provided that at least 50% of the aggregate principal
amount of the applicable series of Notes (excluding any additional Notes)
remains outstanding after each such redemption.

Prior to, 2024, the Issuer may redeem up to 10% of the
aggregate principal amount of each series of Notes originally issued
(including the aggregate principal amount of any additional Notes
issued) in each calendar year, commencing on the Issue Date, at a
redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount thereof, plus
accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, up to the
redemption date. See “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.”

In addition, prior to, 2024, the Issuer may redeem all or,
from time to time, part of each series of Notes at a redemption price
equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Notes plus the applicable
“make-whole” premium described in this Offering Memorandum and
accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but not
including, the applicable date of redemption.

Optional Redemption for
taxreasons . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . In the event of certain developments affecting taxation that become
effective on or after the Issue Date, the Issuer may redeem the applicable
series of Notes in whole but not in part, at any time, upon giving written
notice, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount, plus
accrued and unpaid interest, if any, and additional amounts, if any, to,


21


-----

but excluding, the date of redemption. See “Description of the Notes—
_Redemption for Taxation Reasons.”_

Change of Control . . . . . . . . . . . . Upon the occurrence of certain change of control events, the Issuer will
be required to offer to repurchase all outstanding Notes at a purchase
price equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and
unpaid interest to the date of the purchase. A change of control, however,
will not be deemed to have occurred if a specified consolidated total net
leverage ratio is not exceeded in connection with such event. See
“Description of the Notes—Change of Control.”

Certain Tender Offers . . . . . . . . . . In connection with certain tender offers for the Notes, if holders of not
less than 90% in aggregate principal amount of the applicable series of
outstanding Notes validly tender and do not withdraw such Notes in such
tender offer and the Issuer, or any third party making such a tender offer
in lieu of the Issuer, purchases, all of the applicable series of Notes
validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the Issuer or such
third party will have the right to redeem the Notes that remain
outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price
equal to the price offered to each other holder of Notes. See “Description
_of the Notes—Optional Redemption.”_

Certain Covenants . . . . . . . . . . . . The Indenture will limit, among other things, the ability of the Issuer and
(as applicable) its subsidiaries to:

                        - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain
preferred stock;

                        - pay dividends on, redeem or repurchase our capital stock;

                        - make certain restricted payments;

                        - make certain investments;

                        - create or permit to exist certain liens;

                        - impose restrictions on the ability of their subsidiaries to pay
dividends or make other payments to the Issuer;

                        - merge or consolidate with other entities, or make certain asset sales;

                        - enter into certain transactions with affiliates; and

                        - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the
Notes.

Each of the covenants in the Indenture will be subject to significant
exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the Notes—Certain
_Covenants.” Certain of the covenants and events of default will be_
suspended if and for as long as, and the security interests in respect of
the Collateral will be released if, we achieve investment grade ratings.
See “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—Suspension of
_Covenants on Achievement of Investment Grade Status.”_

U.S. Federal Income Tax
Considerations . . . . . . . . . . . . . For a discussion of certain U.S. federal income tax considerations of an
investment in the Notes, see “Certain Taxation Considerations—Certain
_U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations.” You should consult your own_
tax advisor to determine the U.S. federal, state, local and other tax
consequences of an investment in the Notes.

Transfer Restrictions . . . . . . . . . . The Notes and the Guarantees have not been registered under the
Securities Act or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction and will not
be so registered. The Notes are subject to restrictions on transferability
and resale. See “Notice to Investors.” Holders of the Notes will not have
the benefit of any exchange or registration rights.

No Prior Market . . . . . . . . . . . . . The Notes will be new securities for which there is no market. Although
the Initial Purchasers have informed us that they intend to make a market
in the Notes, they are not obligated to do so, and they may discontinue
market making at any time without notice. Accordingly, we cannot
assure you that an active trading market for the Notes will develop or be
maintained.

Listing . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . Application will be made to list the Notes on the Official List of the
Exchange. There can be no assurance, however, that the Notes will be
listed on the Official List of the Exchange, that such admission to trading
in the Notes will be granted or that such listing will be maintained. The
Exchange is not a regulated market pursuant to the provisions of
Directive 2014/65/EU on markets in financial instruments, as amended.

Risk Factors . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . Investing in the Notes involves substantial risks. You should consider
carefully all the information in this Offering Memorandum and, in
particular, you should evaluate the specific risk factors set forth in the
“Risk Factors” section before making a decision whether to invest in the
Notes.

Governing Law . . . . . . . . . . . . . . The Notes, the Note Guarantees and the Indenture will be governed by
New York law. The Intercreditor Agreement and the Senior Secured
Credit Facilities will be governed by English law. Each Transaction
Security Document will be governed by applicable local laws.

_The Issuer was formed for the purposes of facilitating the Transactions. The Issuer does not have any_
_business operations, material assets or liabilities other than those incurred in connection with its incorporation_
_and the Transactions. We do not present in this Offering Memorandum any financial information or financial_
_statements of the Issuer for the periods presented, other than certain limited financial data presented on an as_
_adjusted basis to reflect the Transactions and the Offering._

_The following tables set forth certain of Ahlstrom-Munksjö’s historical consolidated financial and other_
_information. Our summary historical consolidated financial and other information set forth below as of and for_
_the financial years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018 has been derived from the Financial Statements_
_included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. Such historical consolidated financial and other information_
_has been prepared in accordance with IFRS. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information.”_

_On January 1, 2020, we changed the presentation format for our income statement to present it based on_
_function of expense, instead of nature of expense and to align with our internal reporting. As of January 1, 2020,_
_our income statement is presented according to the function of expense method. The comparative income_
_statement information for the year ended December 31, 2019 in the 2020 Financial Statements has been restated_
_according to the function of expense method to facilitate comparability and is unaudited. In the 2019 Financial_
_Statements and the 2018 Financial Statements the income statement was presented using the nature of expense_
_method. In connection with the adoption of the function of expense method, certain minor reclassifications and_
_changes in names of income statement items have been made in the 2020 Financial Statements. Due to these_
_reclassifications net sales for the year ended December 2019 decreased by €1.0 million. Certain income_
_statement line items were also renamed in the 2020 Financial Statements. For example, net profit was renamed_
_to net result, and profit before tax was renamed to result before tax. In order to aid comparability, financial_
_information from the year ended December 31, 2019 is presented on an audited historical basis when comparing_
_to the financial information for the year ended December 31, 2018, and, otherwise, is extracted without_
_adjustment from the unaudited, restated comparative column included in the 2020 Financial Statements. See_
_“Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Ahlstrom-Munksjo¨—Comparability of the Financial_
_Statements—Presentation of Income Statement.”_

_We decided to implement a new business structure, which became effective on January 1, 2020, to promote_
_core business capabilities and sharpen strategic targets and align the business characteristics of each business_
_area. For periods after January 1, 2020, our five business areas comprise Filtration & Performance Solutions,_
_Advance Solutions, Industrial Solutions, Food Packaging & Technical Solutions, and Decor Solutions, which_
_also form our operating and reporting segments. For periods prior to January 1, 2020, our five business areas_
_comprised Filtration & Performance Solutions, Industrial Solutions, Decor, Specialties, and North American_
_Specialty Solutions. In the 2020 Financial Statements, we have restated our presentation of the financial_
_information of our business areas for the comparative year ended December 31, 2019 to reflect our new business_
_structure and the restated business area financial information is unaudited. However, no business area financial_
_information for any prior period has been restated and the business area financial information for the year ended_
_December 31, 2018 is presented based our previous business areas and is not comparable to the business area_
_information presented in the 2020 Financial Statements. In order to provide meaningful comparable information_
_in this Offering Memorandum, we present the financial information for the business areas for the year ended_
_December 31, 2019 based on the prior business areas when comparing to the financial information for the year_
_ended December 31, 2018, and, otherwise, based on the new business areas. See “Presentation of Financial and_
_Other Information—Ahlstrom-Munksjo¨—Comparability of the Financial Statements—Changes to Reportable_
_Segments.” The business areas’ performance is assessed internally on the basis of net sales and Comparable_
_EBITDA. Comparable EBITDA is defined for internal management reporting purposes as EBITDA excluding_
_items affecting comparability in EBITDA, such as material items outside the ordinary course of business, such as_
_gains and losses on business disposals, direct transaction costs related to business acquisitions, costs for closure_
_of business operations and restructurings including redundancy payments, one-off items arising from purchase_
_price allocation such as inventory fair value adjustments, compensation related to environmental damages_
_arising from unexpected or rare events and other items, including fines (such as VAT tax audit fines) or other_
_similar stipulated payments and litigation, but excluding impairment losses in each case, as further described_
_under “—As Adjusted Data of the Issuer.”_

_For the year ended December 31, 2018 and following the acquisitions of Expera Specialty Solutions and_
_Caieiras, each business area’s performance was assessed internally on the basis of its net sales and Comparable_

**RISK FACTORS**

_An investment in the Notes involves a high degree of risk. In addition to the other information contained in_
_this Offering Memorandum, you should carefully consider the following risk factors before purchasing the Notes._
_The risks and uncertainties described below are not the only ones that the Group faces. Additional risks and_
_uncertainties that we are not aware of or that the we currently believe are immaterial could also have a material_
_adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition, cash flows, competitive position and_
_prospects. If any of the possible events described below occurs, our business, financial condition, results of_
_operations, cash flows, competitive position and prospects could be materially and adversely affected. If that_
_happens, the Issuer may not be able to pay interest or principal on the Notes when due and you could lose all or_
_part of your investment._

_This Offering Memorandum also contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties._
_Our actual results may differ materially from those anticipated in these forward-looking statements as a result of_
_various factors, including the risks described below and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum._

**Risks Related to Our Operating Environment**

**_Uncertain global economic and financial market conditions could have a material adverse effect on our_**
**_business, financial condition and results of operations._**

The general economic and financial market conditions in Europe and other parts of the world have
undergone significant volatility in recent years. We are especially exposed to the macroeconomic conditions
affecting Europe and North America, which accounted for 43.2% and 34.7%, respectively, of our total net sales
for the year ended December 31, 2020. Since early 2020, the primary factor in increased uncertainty globally
from an economic and social perspective has been the global outbreak of COVID-19 (the “COVID-19
pandemic”). The resulting broader economic downturn and slowing global economic growth has increased the
risk of weakened demand for a wide range of our products.

The COVID-19 pandemic may result, and in many jurisdictions has already resulted, in restrictions such as
limitations on travel and transportation of goods, closure of businesses and public offices, quarantines and
general lockdowns, the duration of which are uncertain. This has resulted, and may continue to result, in
materially increased volatility and declines in financial markets and weaker demand in the global economy.
Furthermore, such measures implemented, or intended to be implemented, by governments or governmental
bodies could have a material adverse effect on supply chains and generally impact business operations across the
economy both as a result of weakened economic activity and in terms of the health and wellbeing of employees
being affected. Several central banks and governments have announced and employed financial stimulus
packages in anticipation of a significant negative impact on gross domestic product. However, there is no
certainty that these policy tools will counter anticipated macroeconomic risks. This has resulted, and may
continue to result, in materially increased volatility and declines in financial markets and weaker demand in the
global economy.

Furthermore, global economic conditions have been, and are likely to continue to be, affected by concerns
over increased geopolitical tensions as well as political developments, such as the United Kingdom’s decision to
leave the European Union (“Brexit”) on January 31, 2020, and the threat of escalated trade disputes on a global
level. See “—The result of the United Kingdom’s withdrawal from the European Union may have a negative
_effect on our business.” In addition, developing markets, such as South America, are generally subject to greater_
political, economic and social uncertainties than countries with more developed institutional structures, and the
risk of losses resulting from changes in law, authorities’ practices and interpretations, economic or social
upheaval and other factors may be substantial. These or other geopolitical tensions, political developments
around the world and a global trend toward protectionism have affected the global economic conditions and
increased market uncertainty and volatility and may continue to do so in the future.

It is difficult to predict how market conditions will develop, as they are impacted by macro movements of
the financial markets and many other factors, including the stock, bond and derivatives markets as well as
measures taken by various governmental and regulatory authorities and central banks, over which we have no
control. Uncertainty remains in the global markets and the global economy could experience another recession,
or a depression, which could be more prolonged or have a greater financial impact than the global recessions that
began in 2008.

Our business is affected by the trends in global investment activities and cyclical fluctuations in our
customers’ end-use segments. The uncertainty in the global economy and financial markets may diminish

33


-----

customers’ ability or willingness to make investments, as a result of which order decisions may be postponed or
cancelled, which could decrease our sales and impair our profitability. In addition, uncertainty in the global
economy and financial markets may have a negative effect on the availability and cost of financing. Our liquidity
and access to financing may be materially affected by changing conditions in the financial markets, or our capital
resources may not, at all times, be sufficient or readily available to satisfy our liquidity needs. We may not
necessarily be able to utilize the opportunities arising from the economic fluctuations or to adapt to a long-term
recession or stagnation of the economy. The materialization of any of the above risks could have a material
adverse effect on our profitability, future cost of debt and access to bank and capital market financing in the
future, which, in turn, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of
operations.

**_Demand for our products may be affected by, among other factors, the cyclical nature of the industry in which_**
**_we operate and changing market conditions._**

Our products are generally affected by the cyclical nature of our industry in terms of selling prices, raw
material prices and delivery volumes, and the cycles may vary in different customer industries and in geographic
regions. Demand for our products is affected by global, regional and national macroeconomic conditions that
affect end-users of our products. Accordingly, we are also exposed to cyclical changes in the various industries in
which our customers operate, such as everyday consumables, health care and life science, homebuilding and
furniture as well as transportation and industrial end-use segments.

The cyclical nature of the fiber-based solutions and products industry may result in overcapacity and
consequently put pressure on the pricing of our products, which could have a material adverse effect on our
profitability. In the absence of sufficient economic growth, periods of local excess supply may decrease the
demand for our products and lead to decreases in market selling prices. Demand for our products could also
decline due to various other factors in our operating environment, some of which are discussed elsewhere in
these “Risk Factors.”

Shifts in the patterns of demand, whether foreseen or not, could also strain the flexibility of our asset base
and leave some assets underutilized, while others may become overloaded. See also “—Risks Related to Our
_Business and Operations—Our production operations involve operational risks, and failures or deficiencies in_
_the management of operational efficiency could have a material adverse effect on us” below._

Any decreases or changes in the patterns of demand for our products could have a material adverse effect on
our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_We operate in highly competitive markets, which could negatively impact our results of operations and_**
**_financial condition._**

The segments for fiber-based solutions and products in which we operate are highly competitive, and we
compete with multinational corporations, regional manufacturers and specialized manufacturers. Certain of our
products are priced in a competitive market environment at prevailing market prices, which may result in small
margins. The competitive environment has tightened in some of our product segments, particularly for release
liner and coated one-sided segment used for flexible packaging in Europe, filter materials in North America and
in export markets for decor papers outside of Europe. Some of our competitors may be able to take advantage of
stronger economies of scale benefits due to larger sites, higher investment capacity or other operational benefits,
such as ability to utilize integrated pulp at their sites.

In addition, existing or new competitors may enter one or more of our key markets, or they may seek to
increase their market share through aggressive pricing strategies or otherwise. Existing or new competitors may
begin to manufacture products that compete with certain of our products, by adapting their existing production
capacity or by investing in new capacity. If this were to occur to any significant degree, decreased prices for
those products would likely follow, thus adversely affecting the profitability of our business. The COVID-19
pandemic may also accelerate the decline in the consumption of printing and writing paper and may trigger the
conversion of paper machines to production of products in segments other than printing and writing paper in
which we are operating. Furthermore, our products may face competition from alternative materials, such as
petroleum-based materials including plastics. If the use of other products and materials in certain applications
increases at the expense of fiber-based solutions and products, there is a risk that demand for our products will
decrease. The electrification of mobility is picking up momentum and impacts one of our larger customer
segments, the transportation industry, which may negatively impact demand for our combustion engine filtration
products. Although this impact may be offset by new solutions that are being developed where new types of

34


-----

filters are needed for applications such as battery cooling and air filtration, there can be no assurance that we will
benefit from such trends.

In addition, we may be subject to long-term adverse trends in demand for paper. For example, use of fine
paper has declined since the 1990s and conversion has increased as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. See also
“—Risks Related to Our Business and Operations—We may not be successful in product development and
_innovation or in development of our production processes to keep pace with competitors, or we may be forced to_
_make further investments due to technological developments in the industry” below._

Failure to adapt to industry trends, sustain the investments necessary to compete effectively, properly
manage our response to increased competition, or otherwise compete effectively, may have a material adverse
effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Changes in the costs or availability of raw materials and energy could have a material adverse effect on our_**
**_business and profitability._**

Our primary raw materials are wood, pulp, wood necessary to produce pulp, renewable annual fibers,
various synthetic fibers, including glass, and plastic, as well as chemicals, including titanium dioxide, and
energy. Our cost base is primarily variable, with variable costs, such as fibers, other raw materials and energy,
constituting 65% of our total costs for the year ended December 31, 2020. Our commodity pulp consumption was
approximately 1,200 thousand tons for the year ended December 31, 2020. Volatility, price increase and the
availability of raw material, particularly of pulp, impact our margin on variable costs and results. Our pulp
exposure was reduced by approximately 500 thousand tons of our own pulp production during the year ended
December 31, 2020, which includes 185 thousand tons of market pulp production at our Aspa pulp mill in
Sweden that is sold to third parties. The price and availability of raw materials and energy may fluctuate
significantly depending on a variety of factors, including business cycles in the relevant markets, supply
conditions, government regulations, natural disasters and other factors that are difficult to predict and beyond our
control. While raw material costs, particularly for pulp and titanium dioxide, have decreased in 2019 and 2020,
any substantial increases in the cost of pulp, energy or other raw materials that we use could have a material
adverse effect on our results. In addition, decreasing raw material prices may also put additional pricing pressure
on some of our products as customers may expect decreased raw materials costs to be passed through to them.

The level of raw materials production capacity is also a key factor that impacts price and availability of raw
materials. Global overproduction of raw materials generally decreases the price and increases the availability of
raw materials, whereas underproduction generally decreases the availability of raw materials in the market,
which may result in a price increase. Natural disasters or issues with our supply agreements could also cause the
prices of raw materials or energy to increase. Price increases in raw materials, energy and services, such as
transportation, that cannot be offset by corresponding price increases of our products and solutions could impact
our margins and profitability, which, in turn, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition and results of operations. Our ability to pass price increases to our customers through increases in the
prices of our products is dependent on several factors, including demand and the negotiation power of our major
suppliers and customers.

While we have generally been able to pass through increases in the costs of raw materials and energy to our
customers, our ability to continue doing so depends on several external factors, such as demand for our products
and the negotiation power of our major suppliers and customers. As a result, we may not be able to reliably pass
through increases in the costs of raw materials and energy to our customers. Furthermore, we may experience
significant time delays in passing through these price increases for various reasons, including limits in
contractual provisions or competitive pressures.

In the event of a significant increase in the price, or a significant disruption in the supply, of raw materials
or energy, we may have to purchase raw materials or energy from alternate sources, which could significantly
impact our ability to provide competitively priced products to our customers in a timely manner. Furthermore,
while we are not dependent on any specific supplier, certain major suppliers to an individual business may be
costly or difficult to replace, particularly if there are supply shortages. If any of the above factors were to
materialize, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Trade restrictions, such as tariffs, and economic sanctions could have a material adverse effect on our_**
**_business, financial condition and results of operations and our reputation._**

We operate in a large number of countries, some of which are or have been the subject of export controls
and economic sanctions, such as Russia, Armenia, Bosnia, Egypt, Lebanon, Moldova, Serbia, Tunisia, Ukraine

35


-----

and Venezuela. Our purchases of raw material and/or sale of products have in the past, and may in the future,
become subject to new or tightened export control regulations, sanctions, tariffs, embargoes or other economic
and trade restrictions in the future, and such measures could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition and results of operations.

Authorities in the countries in which we operate or from which we import our products may impose new
custom duties to imports, or repeal current ones, which could have a material adverse effect on the supply of
products or their prices. Changes in the level of custom duties may have a material adverse effect on our ability
to import our products or the profitability of our domestic operations in markets where such protectionist
measures are applied.

The global nature of our business operations subjects us to sanctions and regulations imposed by a multitude
of jurisdictions. For example, we must comply with laws and sanctions regulations of the United States, the
European Union and the United Nations. International economic and trade sanctions are complex and subject to
frequent change, including in relation to jurisdictional reach and to the list of countries, entities and individuals
subject to sanctions. While we regularly monitor the situation, ensuring compliance with such controls and
regulations may be difficult or costly and there is a risk that it could become subject to investigations or claims
by authorities or contracting parties. Although we have trade compliance procedures and controls in place, there
can be no assurance that these procedures and controls will be effective or that we will not be deemed to be
engaged in dealings with entities or individuals subject to sanctions through our operations. New or possible
further trade restrictions, protectionist measures, sanctions or economic slowdown resulting from increased
economic or political instability in certain regions could have a material adverse effect on our operations.
Materialization of any of the above risks, including any actual or perceived violations of, or non-compliance
with, such trade restrictions or economic sanctions, could have a material adverse effect on our reputation,
business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Political, financial or legal risks in emerging markets could have a material adverse effect on us._**

We have operations around the world, including in a number of emerging markets, in particular in Asia and
South America. Emerging markets are generally subject to political, economic and social uncertainties, and the
risk of losses resulting from changes in law, authorities’ practices and interpretations, economic or social
upheaval and other factors may be substantial. Among the more significant risks of operating and investing in
emerging markets are those arising from the introduction of trade restrictions, enforcement of foreign exchange
restrictions, inflation and changes in tax laws and enforcement mechanisms. Operations in certain emerging
market countries may also include the risk of the possibility of expropriation or nationalization of assets.
Materialization of any of the above risks could substantially reduce or eliminate any benefits derived from
operating in these markets and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and
results of operations.

**_The result of the United Kingdom’s withdrawal from the European Union may have a negative effect on our_**
**_business._**

On June 23, 2016, the United Kingdom held an in or out referendum on the United Kingdom’s membership
of the European Union, the result of which favored the exit of the United Kingdom from the European Union. On
January 31, 2020, Brexit became effective and the United Kingdom entered into a transition period during which
the European Union and the United Kingdom acted as if the United Kingdom was a member of the European
Union (the “Transition Period”). Following the expiry of the Transition Period, the United Kingdom ceased to be
treated as a member of European Union on December 31, 2020. Although on December 24, 2020 the United
Kingdom and the European Union agreed to a trade agreement (the “Trade and Cooperation Agreement”), there
are still a number of areas of uncertainty in connection with the future of the United Kingdom and its relationship
with the European Union and the application and interpretation of the Trade and Cooperation Agreement, and
Brexit-related matters may take several years to be clarified and resolved. The United Kingdom may still face
barriers to trade and commerce with the European Union and may still lose its present rights to the global trade
deals negotiated by the European Union on behalf of its members, which may in turn diminish overall economic
activity between the United Kingdom and the European Union and the United Kingdom and its global trade
partners. Given this uncertainty and the range of possible outcomes, it is currently impossible to determine the
impact that Brexit, the Trade and Cooperation Agreement and the nature and extent of responses by the United
Kingdom in the formulation of fiscal and monetary policies and any related matters may have on general
economic conditions in the United Kingdom. It is also not possible to determine the impact that these matters
will have on our business.

36


-----

Although we have made preparations to ensure business continuity, there can be no assurance that our
suppliers’ and customers’ current business operations will not be impacted by Brexit, or that the consequences of
Brexit on the European Union’s border with the United Kingdom will not affect supplies to us or lead times of
deliveries. In addition, the Scottish regional government is actively considering a second referendum on Scottish
independence from the United Kingdom, which may lead to additional uncertainty and may affect our business
activities in Scotland and other parts of the United Kingdom. The above-mentioned and similar events could have
a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**Risks Related to Our Business and Operations**

**_We may not be able to successfully implement our business strategy and subsequently manage our growth_**
**_effectively_**

Our growth depends on the successful implementation of our business strategy. Our ability to implement our
business strategy is subject to a variety of factors, many of which are beyond our control, including, but not
limited to, our ability to:

   - focus on profitability and opportunities to drive further margin improvements;

   - increase our focus on environmental and sustainable specialty materials in line with customer
preferences;

   - invest for long-term growth across the business; and

   - manage our portfolio through selective acquisition and divestment opportunities.

Adverse developments in general economic conditions could also adversely affect our ability to successfully
implement our business strategy. Any failure to successfully execute our business strategy could have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_We may not be successful in product development and innovation or in development of our production_**
**_processes to keep pace with competitors, or we may be forced to make further investments due to technological_**
**_developments in the industry._**

Our market position is dependent on a combination of regular product and technology development and
long-term customer relationships. Our ability to grow and to maintain our competitiveness depends on our
continued ability to identify and respond to changes in consumer and industry preferences and demand, develop
our production and launch new and improved products in a timely manner using our existing or new production
capabilities in all of our key markets and manufacture and market our products in changing markets. In addition,
our production chains are fairly complex, which may cause additional challenges in responding to specific
customer and industry needs. The speed with which new products are rolled out to the market is essential for our
continued competitiveness. We may not be successful in launching new products on time or as expected during
the planning and development process as the commercialization process may require a considerable amount of
time.

Our business operations depend on our ability to foresee commercial and technological developments in our
key markets, and to implement such developments. If we are unable to effectively foresee or implement such
developments, a competitor rather than us may benefit from such developments. We may be required to make
large investments to acquire such developments, or may be unable to acquire such developments, which could, in
turn, affect our ability to compete with our competitors. For example, while we are currently exploring
opportunities for new applications to be used in electric vehicles, changes in the use of electric vehicles may
occur more rapidly than expected or the market for electric vehicles could stagnate. There can be no certainty
that we will be able to foresee future developments in a timely manner or future developments may require
significant additional investments to remain competitive in the sector.

There can be no assurance that we will be successful in continuing to meet our customers’ needs through
innovation or in developing new products or technologies, or that, if developed, any such new products or
technologies will meet the needs of our customers. We may not be able to recover investments that we have
made in order to develop these new products or technologies, and may not have sufficient resources to keep pace
with technological developments. Our failure to keep pace with evolving technological innovations in our
markets and adequately foresee customer preferences could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition and results of operations.
