The COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted consumers’ lives across the world. The length of the pandemic will
likely be a key determinant for if and how markets and customers’ behavior patterns will permanently change
and what effect these changes will have on future business opportunities for companies, including us.

**_The fiber-based solutions and products industry is characterized by significant capital expenditure in the_**
**_production processes and maintenance of existing production and converting facilities and the failure or delay_**
**_of any current or upcoming investment of a significant size may have a material adverse effect on us._**

The fiber-based solutions and products industry is characterized by significant capital expenditure in the
production processes and maintenance of existing production and converting facilities. In recent years, we have
undertaken certain investments in order to improve product capability, the efficiency of our production processes
and to increase capacity. In 2019 and 2020, we have, among other things, completed the rebuild of the recovery
boiler and debottlenecking of the pulp line in Billingsfors, Sweden, the bailing line modernization at the Aspa
pulp plant in Sweden, the production line upgrade of decor paper in Dettingen, Germany, the expansion of
coating capabilities in Jacareí, Brazil, a rebuild of our converting line of sterilization wrap at our Pont-Audemer
plant in France and the installation of a new cogeneration plant at our site in Turin, Italy. In addition, in 2018, we
announced an investment of approximately €28 million to strengthen our manufacturing platform for high
performance filtration and energy storage applications. This project, which is expected to be completed during
the second half of 2021, consists of a significant expansion of our micro glass capacity and a further growth in
our industrial filtration capacity in Turin, Italy, Fabriano, Italy, Malmedy, Belgium and Binzhou, China. In 2018,
we also announced an investment currently expected to be approximately €37 million in a second-hand Voith
production line that will produce tea bag and coffee pod materials at our Chirnside plant in the UK, has partially
been delayed and has incurred additional costs in an amount of €9 million. The deviation in the capital
expenditure spending and timeline is a result of the complexity of the project, reduction in capital expenditure
plans in 2019 which placed the project on hold, as well as the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic. In 2020, we
announced an investment of €7 million related to a new coating machine to enable formaldehyde-free balancing
and finish foils for furniture and the building and construction industries. The investment will also help reduce
carbon dioxide emissions and increase production capacity. The coating machine is expected to be completed in
the fourth quarter of 2021. We have also acquired several new production facilities as a result of our corporate
acquisitions and there can be no certainty as to the need for capital expenditure and maintenance investments
relating to equipment, machinery and other assets of the newly acquired production facilities or in any future
corporate acquisitions.

The investments we undertake may not be completed in the expected timeframe or at all, may experience
budget overruns or may not result in the benefits that we expect, and the newly acquired production facilities
may be subject to significant unexpected capital expenditure and maintenance costs. The materialization of any
of the above risks may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of
operations.

**_We are subject to risks in relation to acquisitions and other investments._**

We have grown through a combination of organic development and acquisitions, and we expect to continue
to grow through selected acquisitions or investments that add geographical scope, new technologies or customer
segments. We may not be able to identify suitable acquisition or investment candidates in the future and even if
we identify a suitable acquisition or investment candidate, we may not be able to finance such acquisition on
favorable terms, if at all. We acquired Expera Specialty Solutions, a U.S. based specialty paper producer (the
“Expera Acquisition”), and Caieiras in Brazil (the “Caieiras Acquisition”) in 2018. In 2019, we achieved the
targeted cost synergy run rate of €21 million from the acquisition of Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras,
exceeding the initial target of €14 million and actions implemented during 2020, which were delayed due to the
COVID-19 related lockdowns and travel restrictions, generated a further €2 million of synergies. We expect to
generate additional business synergies of at least €8 million from the Expera Acquisition, with a gradual impact
from 2021 onwards.

We are also exploring options to acquire or invest in Minglian, a Chinese company comprising a greenfield
decor paper plant in the city of Xingtai, Hebei Province, China. The COVID-19 pandemic-related lockdowns and
travel restrictions have delayed the negotiation and signing of the transaction, which could happen as early as
during the first half of 2021. See also “—Problems associated with any reorganization of our operations or
_divestments of businesses could have a material adverse effect on us.”_

Achieving the remaining or the anticipated benefits of the Expera Acquisition and other corporate
acquisitions or investments largely depends on timely and efficient integration of their business operations,

38


-----

processes and ways of working with us, which, in turn, are also dependent on the management’s time and
resources available to the acquired entities. There can be no assurance that we will achieve such remaining or
anticipated benefits in the expected timeframe or at all. We may also encounter difficulties in integrating
acquisitions or investments with our operations, applying our internal controls processes to these acquisitions or
in managing strategic investments.

Acquisitions are also subject to a number of risks related to the assessment of the acquired business or other
investments, including its value, strengths, weaknesses, potential profitability, assets and liabilities. Diligence
reviews of acquisition or investment targets may not identify all of the material issues necessary to accurately
estimate the cost or potential loss contingencies with respect to a particular transaction, including potential
exposure to regulatory sanctions resulting from an acquisition target’s previous activities. Even a detailed review
of the acquired entity may fail to identify and discover potential liabilities and deficiencies, including legal
claims, claims for breach of contract, employment related claims, tax liabilities and other liabilities (whether or
not contingent), which could result in significant future additional costs and liabilities. Furthermore, indemnities
and other contractual protections in the acquisition or investment documentation may not protect us against all or
part of every known liability or deficiency, and may incur unanticipated costs or expenses in connection with
such transactions, including post-closing asset impairment charges, expenses associated with eliminating
duplicate facilities, litigation and other liabilities, including related to warranties. Target companies may be
located in countries in which the underlying legal, economic, political and cultural conditions do not correspond
to those customary in our key areas of activity or have other national peculiarities with which it is not familiar. In
addition, any future acquisitions or investments may be subject to regulatory approvals by competent national
and supra-national authorities, including competition authorities, which we may be unable to obtain without
unreasonable expense or delay, if at all. We may not realize the targets for growth, economies of scale, cost
savings, development, production and distribution, or other strategic goals that we seek from the relevant
acquisition or investment to the extent or in the timeframe anticipated, and the attention of management and other
personnel may be diverted for long periods of time. Moreover, the purchase price may prove to have been too
high or unforeseen restructuring or integration expenses may become necessary.

In addition, the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic or any possible future outbreaks could increase the
uncertainties regarding the execution of corporate acquisitions or other investments and the acquired companies’
planned integration with our business operations and lead to additional costs. Furthermore, the overall effects of
the COVID-19 pandemic or any possible future outbreaks of the virus on the global economy could erode the
acquired companies’ businesses or the investment opportunity in a way that unpredictably decreases their value
for us.

Our failure to integrate acquired businesses or investments, or to realize any expected synergies, may
prevent it from obtaining the advantages that the acquisitions were intended to create, and could have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Problems associated with any reorganization of our operations or divestments of businesses could have a_**
**_material adverse effect on us._**

We may from time to time contemplate reorganizing certain business operations to improve our profitability
or to respond to changes in market conditions. For example, we implemented a new business and reporting
structure beginning January 1, 2020, with a view to supporting profitable growth, competitiveness as well as
customer support. In addition, we may, from time to time, divest businesses that do not meet our strategic
objectives or growth or profitability targets. For example, in 2020, we divested our fine art paper business in
Arches, France and our glass fiber reinforcement business in Mikkeli, Finland. In addition, we are actively
considering strategic alternatives in relation to our entire Decor paper business, including any potential
ownership in Minglian, where one of the options being investigated the possibility of divestment of the Decor
business. The successful execution of any reorganization plans or divestments is dependent on a number of
factors, including the correct timing and execution of the plans, co-operation of our employees and customers,
ability to maintain operational efficiency and in case of a divestment, ability to negotiate favorable terms with the
buyer.

Any reorganization of business operations may have a material adverse effect on us and may result in
customers reducing or cancelling orders or terminating their customer relationship with us entirely. Any
significant reduction in sales could lead to overcapacity, which in turn could have a material adverse effect on
our ability to utilize our production capacity efficiently or profitably. In addition, any divestment may also
subject us to surviving warranties under the applicable terms, some of which may be uncapped in time and/or

39


-----

amount. Such plans could also result in the loss of key executives or employees, may result in labor claims,
litigation or reputational harm. There can be no certainty that we would be able to achieve all of the anticipated
benefits of such plans or divestments. The estimated costs could be higher than estimated and any plan or
divestment may not be completed within the expected timeframe or at all.

The occurrence of any of such risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition
and results of operations.

**_Joint ventures and other partnerships arrangements may expose us to risks._**

From time to time we enter into joint ventures and other partnership arrangements with other parties in
relation to projects in which we have an interest. Joint ventures and partnership arrangements can often require
unanimous approval of the parties to the joint venture or partnership arrangement or their representatives for
certain fundamental decisions, which means that each party may have a veto right with respect to such decisions.
This could, in turn, lead to a deadlock in the operations of the joint venture or partnership. Further, we may be
unable to exert control over strategic decisions made in respect of such joint venture or partnership. Any failure
of such other parties to meet their obligations to us or to third parties, or any disputes with respect to the parties’
respective rights and obligations, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and
results of operations.

**_We may be unable to recruit and retain key personnel._**

We are, to a certain extent, dependent on key individuals. We operate in a technically demanding industry in
which qualified and experienced employees, particularly in research and development, provide an important
competitive advantage. We also face the risk of an aging workforce. Our ability to retain and recruit employees
who have relevant qualifications and to succeed in succession planning is important for our continued success.
Furthermore, we are subject to the risk of employees, including senior management and other key employees,
leaving due to corporate transactions, such as corporate acquisitions or divestments. If we fail to retain and
recruit key individuals or if we fail in succession planning, this could delay or impair our business and product
development, which in turn could have a material adverse effect on our financial condition and results of
operations.

**_The COVID-19 pandemic and possible future outbreaks could disrupt our business operations._**

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and any possible future outbreaks could have an adverse effect on us. In
response to the outbreak, we have initiated a centralized crisis alert team to carry out a global pandemic
contingency and preparedness response plan to ensure the safety of our employees worldwide. Our 45 plants and
converting sites in 14 countries have remained operational during 2020, except for a few temporary shutdowns
caused by government lockdowns or employee absences due to quarantine or infections. Raw material supply
issues have not caused any significant interruptions of production. Our investment project in a second-hand Voith
production line that will produce biodegradable and compostable tea and coffee infusion materials at our
Chirnside plant in the UK, however, has partially been delayed and has incurred additional costs in an amount of
€9 million. The deviation in the capital expenditure spending and timeline is a result of the complexity of the
project, reduction in capital expenditure plans in 2019 which placed the project on hold, as well as the outbreak
of the COVID-19 pandemic.

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and any possible future outbreaks of the virus among our employees, or
if employees are unable to work as a result of being quarantined, may have an adverse effect on our operations
and could lead to significant interruptions of production. In addition, the current pandemic or any possible future
outbreaks of the virus could have an adverse effect on our suppliers, distributors, logistics and other supply chain
operations, resulting in a deficit of supplies necessary to carry out our operations, and therefore possibly
disrupting output deliveries to customers. Although we have taken measures to decrease operational risks arisen
due to the COVID-19 pandemic, there can be no assurance that the chosen measures will be effective, especially
if the COVID-19 pandemic persists for a long period.

Furthermore, the COVID-19 pandemic or any possible future outbreaks or COVID-19, including any new
variants thereof, or of other viruses could negatively affect the demand of our products. For example, the
exceptional circumstances of the COVID-19 pandemic, with regional lockdowns and limited mobility for
citizens, have resulted in lower restaurant traffic, which has slowed demand for food processing and packaging
products. Similarly, demand for home building and furniture, transportation and industrial end-uses has
decreased. In 2020, we implemented actions, such as temporary layoffs, shorter working hours and minimizing

40


-----

the use of external personnel and services, to mitigate the financial impact of lower volumes, in particular during
the second and third quarters of 2020.

Any failure to successfully adapt our business operations or strategy to the changing operating conditions
caused by the COVID-19 pandemic or any future outbreaks or materialization of any other risks mentioned
above, may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_We may not be able to achieve the estimated benefits from the renewal of our business platform._**

On February 13, 2020, we announced a renewal of our business processes and modern systems to create a
strong foundation to operate our global business effectively and strengthen customer experience. The new,
stronger platform is intended to benefit our way of doing business by utilizing the data and the opportunities for
further digitalization. The business platform is expected to enable growth strategy implementation and generate
efficiency, agility, transparency, improve stakeholder value and contribute to profitable growth. The business
platform renewal started in 2020 with a planning phase and will be implemented over several years. Achieving
the estimated benefits of the renewal will involve certain risks and uncertainties, and there can be no assurance
that we will achieve the estimated benefits of the renewal within the currently estimated timeframe, or at all. In
addition, increased digitalization of our business may increase certain of the risks described in this “Risk
_Factors” section, including the risks described under “—Any significant problems with our IT systems could have_
_a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.”_

Risks and challenges relating to the renewal of the business platform include, but are not limited to, the
following:

   - introduction and implementation of a new operating model and business processes;

   - implementation of new IT technologies;

   - placement of demands on our resources to manage the process internally, which may affect the
management’s ability to run our business effectively during the renewal process; and

   - co-operation with our employees and customers.

The expected benefits from the renewal of the business platform as well as the related costs are inherently
uncertain and based on a number of our assumptions and judgments. In addition, the renewal might not be
completed in the expected timeframe. The materialization of any of the above described risks could result in us
not being able to achieve the estimated benefits from the renewal and cause additional costs to us, which could
have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Our production operations involve operational risks, and failures or deficiencies in the management of_**
**_operational efficiency could have a material adverse effect on us._**

Our ability to utilize our production capacity efficiently could be materially affected by variations in
customer demand or interruptions in production. Any inability to adjust production capacity may lead to
opportunity loss, in the case of increasing demand, or to cost burdens, in the case of decreasing demand. Rapid
production changes may be challenging to implement, which could also increase our vulnerability to adverse
general economic and industry conditions. We typically only produce goods against orders received, rather than
for stock. However, a variety of conditions may cause customers to reduce, delay or cancel anticipated or
confirmed orders and lower capacity utilization to align the production with the demand. Any inability to
maintain operational efficiency could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and
results of operations.

In addition, any interruption or disruption in production at our production sites, whether due to lack of
orders, labor action, environment-related accidents, breakdown of major paper, pulping or other production
machines, interruptions in the distribution of energy, system failures or service interruptions in IT systems, fire,
accidents, natural hazards, catastrophes, natural disasters, adverse weather conditions, unexpected geological or
other physical conditions, criminal or terrorist acts, pandemics, transportation disruptions, problems in our supply
agreements or other factors, could have a material adverse effect on our ability to meet our production goals and
result in lost opportunities in the future. Any of the above may have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition and results of operations.

**_Loss of significant customer relationships and customer concentration could harm our business._**

Changes in customer industries related to customer strategies or end-user needs could have a material
adverse effect on our business. We are not dependent on any specific customer or group of customers. Our ten

41


-----

largest customers generated 19.0% of our net sales in the year ended December 31, 2020 and no single customer
represented more than 10% of our net sales in same period. However, we have customers that are significant to
the operations of an individual business area. Additionally, a number of our customers are, or could in the future
be, under pressure in their own domestic markets from imports, in particular from Asia, and may consequently
lose market share or have to relocate their production or converting facilities to other markets, which could cause
our customers to reduce the volume of their purchases. The loss of a significant number of our key customers, if
not replaced with new customer agreements on similar terms, or a significant reduction in sales to any such
customers could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. We
are also exposed to a risk of customer concentration. The industries in which our customers operate may be
subject to future consolidation. Any such consolidation could result in companies having increased bargaining
power and could lead to a decline in our market share if an existing customer merges with or is acquired by an
entity that has a strong relationship with one of our competitors.

**_We rely on certifications by industry standard-setting bodies._**

We obtain and seek to adhere to certain certifications, because we seek to conduct our activities with respect
to the environment. We incur significant costs and expenses in order to comply with and maintain our
certifications, including assessments necessary for the renewal of the certifications and monitoring and
implementation of the certifications. If we fail to maintain any of our certifications, our business may be harmed
because our customers may cease buying certain products from us, which in turn could have a material adverse
effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Any significant problems with our IT systems could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial_**
**_condition and results of operations._**

Our operations depend on the integrity, security and stable operation of our IT systems and software, which
are primarily provided by third-party suppliers. The operation of our IT systems and software could be
interrupted by power cuts, software or telecommunication errors or disasters such as fires or natural disasters, as
well as human errors made by our own staff or third-party suppliers. If our IT systems and software were to
become unusable or their function were to be significantly impaired for any reason during an extended period of
time due to, for example, systems and software becoming outdated or due to a lack of sufficient resources for IT
support from third-party suppliers, our operations could be adversely affected, since our production processes
and our ability to deliver products on time, order raw materials and handle inventory are largely dependent on
our IT systems and software. Difficulties in renewing, maintaining, upgrading and outsourcing our IT systems
and software could result in increased costs and damage to our reputation in the eyes of our customers and other
third parties, which, in turn, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results
of operations.

Despite our security measures and back-up systems, our information technology and infrastructure may be
vulnerable to attacks by hackers, computer viruses or malicious code. Various cyber threats have increased in
recent years along with the digitalization of companies’ operations. We may be targeted, for example, by
phishing or malware attacks, denial-of-service attacks, breaches in information or data systems, ransomware or
attacks targeting production processes. It may also be difficult for us to detect cyber-attacks upon their
occurrence, which could have an impact on the size of damage. In addition, our information technology and
infrastructure may be breached due to employee error, malfeasance or affected by other disruptions, including as
a result of natural disasters or telecommunications breakdowns or other reasons beyond our control. In addition,
any problems with IT systems and software could result in leakage of sensitive information and theft of
intellectual property. Any of the above could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition
and results of operations.

**_Failure to establish, manage and protect intellectual property rights could have a material adverse effect on_**
**_our competitiveness and our business, financial condition and results of operations._**

Our success depends on being on the leading edge in terms of product development and improvement of our
manufacturing and production processes. This, in turn, depends on our ability to protect our intellectual property
rights. We have taken active measures to obtain protection of our intellectual property by obtaining patents,
trademarks and by monitoring activities in our major markets. In addition to our patent portfolio and trademarks,
we rely on trade secrets, know-how, the development of new products and technological development in
combination with non-disclosure and other agreements to protect our intellectual property rights. However, the
measures that we take to protect our intellectual property may not effectively deter competitors from improper

42


-----

use of our intellectual property. Protection of intellectual property rights may be more challenging in some of the
regions in which we operate. For example, in the past there have been attempts in China to misuse the name and
logo of Ahlstrom Corporation, one of our predecessor companies. Competitors, suppliers and customers may
misappropriate intellectual property owned or licensed by us, disputes as to ownership of intellectual property
may arise and intellectual property may otherwise become known by or independently developed by competitors,
suppliers or customers. In addition, certain technologies and processes used by us may be subject to the
intellectual property rights of third parties. Such third parties may take legal action for infringement of these
intellectual property rights and any such claim could delay or prevent the delivery of our products. We may not
be successful in defending against this or other challenges brought against our intellectual property rights, may
be required to pay royalties for the use of patents or trademarks of third parties for key technologies or may need
to make substantial investments to research and develop suitable alternatives. We, at times, rely on trade secrets
instead of other forms of protection for our patents or trademarks when patent or trademark protection is not
possible, such as, for example, when the particular technology which was used could not be exactly identified or
would not qualify for patent or trademark protection, or in our opinion would be less effective than maintaining
secrecy. In addition, we rely upon confidentiality agreements with our employees, contractors and other third
parties. To the extent that we rely on trade secret protection and confidentiality agreements, there can be no
assurance that our efforts to maintain secrecy will be successful or that third parties will not be able to develop
the product, technology or know-how independently. Any loss of secrecy could have a material adverse effect on
our financial condition and results of operations. Any failure by us to establish, manage and protect our
intellectual property or resulting claims of infringement on third-party intellectual property rights could have a
material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and our competitiveness. See
also “—We may from time to time be involved in litigation and other similar proceedings that could have a
_material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.”_

**_Compliance with environmental, health and safety, anti-corruption and other national and international laws_**
**_and regulations could increase our operating costs, and potential violations of laws and regulations could_**
**_have a material adverse effect on us._**

We and our operations are subject to various regional, national and local laws and regulations, including
environmental regulations, health and safety laws and regulations, labor regulations, competition regulations,
regulations restricting competitive trading conditions, anti-corruption laws, anti-dumping, data-protection,
corporate, tax and accounting laws. These requirements are complex and frequently change, and they have
tended to become more stringent over time. The passing of new or amended laws or regulations, could require us
to adopt more stringent standards, could restrict our operational or strategic flexibility or require significant costs
and investments. In addition, our operations are subject to different environmental permits, with which we must
comply. We will incur capital and operating costs in our efforts to comply with these laws and regulations. For
example, wastewater discharges and air emissions are highly regulated, and large investments are required to
ensure compliance with applicable requirements. There can be no assurance that the requirements of such laws
and regulations and the associated cost of compliance will not increase in the future. Adapting operations to such
changes may require us to incur costs that are difficult to anticipate, which, in turn, could have a material adverse
effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Our operations in the EU are also affected by the cost of compliance with the EU Emissions Trading System
(“ETS”) in accordance with directive 2003/87/EC, as amended, establishing a scheme for greenhouse gas
emission allowance trading. If our carbon dioxide emission levels exceed the rights in our possession, we must
purchase sufficient carbon dioxide emission allowances. From 2013 onwards, manufacturing companies have
generally had to purchase a steadily increasing amount of emission rights in auctions, for which the costs for
emission allowances are difficult to foresee. The cap on total annual emissions in the EU will gradually be
reduced in phase four of the ETS starting from 2021, and auctions will become the main method for issuing
allowances. Further, regulations on chemicals, such as EU Regulation (No 1907/2006) concerning chemicals and
their safe use, aim to improve the protection of human health and the environment through a system of
registration, evaluation, authorization and restriction of chemicals, and may also impose obligations and related
costs on us. For example, we use titanium dioxide as a raw material for manufacturing certain types of specialty
papers. The European Commission has approved the classification of titanium dioxide as a category 2 carcinogen
under the CLP regulation (1272/2008/EC) and the harmonized classifications will apply from September 9, 2021.
The change in the classification could impose additional obligations and costs on us and the use of titanium
dioxide in our products could generate reputational harm for us. Any of the above events could have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

43


-----

Other environmental and health and safety expenditures relate to maintenance, inspection and security
requirements, contingency arrangements for emergency preparedness and insurance coverage. Industrial
operations, including our production processes are inherently fraught with risks of substantial environmental
costs and liabilities. We may be unable to predict future changes to laws, regulations and operating permits,
which may require us to incur increased operating costs and additional liabilities on us.

We are also required to comply with the provisions of anti-corruption legislation in jurisdictions in which
we operate. There can be no assurance that our current and past policies and monitoring systems have been or
will be able to detect or prevent all potential instances of illicit conduct, or that such policies have been or will be
fully and consistently applied throughout our organization. While we seek to exercise best practices in
compliance with applicable laws, there can be no assurance that our past and current policies and monitoring
systems were or are able to detect or prevent all potential instances of illicit conduct.

We have adopted data protection practices with the aim of being compliant with the General Data Protection
Regulation 2016/679 (the “GDPR”) and other applicable data protection laws and regulations applicable to our
business and operations. Compliance with the GDPR and other laws and regulations or potential inadequacy of
our data protection practices may cause problems, difficulties or additional costs for us. Any infringement of the
GDPR or any other applicable laws and regulations could adversely affect our reputation among our customers
and other stakeholders. Furthermore, data protection authorities may be vested with the power to impose
corrective actions, including temporary or definitive bans on data processing, and to impose fines for breaches of
the GDPR or other applicable laws and regulations.

If we or our employees, distributors or suppliers, violate any of the applicable laws and regulations, we
could experience increased costs or delays in the delivery of our products, be subject to fines, damages or
penalties as well as orders and sanctions imposed by supervisory authorities and courts. We may also suffer
reputational harm, which could reduce demand for our products and have a material adverse effect on our
business.

**_Our operations are exposed to risks related to human health, environment and natural resources, which may_**
**_cause it to incur additional costs and liabilities._**

The nature of our manufacturing processes and products exposes us to potential liability risks under
applicable laws and regulations relating to human health, the environment and natural resources. Health and
safety-related incidents have occurred in the past at our production sites and could occur in the future. Such
incidents could result in injury to our employees, harm to employees and disruptions in production processes,
which may result in costs and other liabilities and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition and results of operations, and could damage our reputation and ability to recruit qualified employees.

Our operations result in emissions of substances in the air and water, and generate noise. Production
processes and products, which by their nature require the use of chemicals and materials that are potentially
harmful to the environment and result in the generation of waste products that require special treatment. Many of
our manufacturing facilities are situated in locations with a long history of environmentally harmful industrial
use, including the use, storage and disposal of hazardous materials. We are currently, and could in the future be,
required to investigate, remediate, monitor or otherwise pay for remediation or other clean-up measures at
locations where operations are currently pursued or where they have been pursued in the past, and such payments
may be material. Such liability for costs might also arise with respect to real estate property that we own, have
previously owned or where predecessor companies previously had operations, or in connection with a closure of
a production facility. Even where liability is the result of predecessor actions, these costs may not be adequately
covered by predecessors or we may be liable for such costs in the future even after a production facility is closed
or sold. For the year ended December 31, 2020, we made environmental provisions of €15.8 million. There can
be no guarantee that our environmental provisions will be sufficient to cover any environmental liabilities that we
may incur.

Our product development and manufacturing processes involve the use of chemicals, such as organic
solvents and other mineral additives, and other hazardous materials. Our operations also result in emissions of
substances in the air and generate noise. These programs and processes expose us to risks of accidental
contamination, such as accidental discharge of untreated water used in the production process, events of
non-compliance with environmental, health and safety laws and regulatory enforcement, personal injury,
property damage and claims and litigation resulting from such events.

Any environmental accident or finding, employee injury, occupational disease or other health and safety
issue could impose significant liabilities and remedial costs on us as well as result in reputational damage. In

44


-----

addition, individuals (employees as well as third parties) could seek damages for alleged personal injury or
property damage due to accidents or exposure to chemicals, materials or substances that are currently used or
were used in the past by us or that are present at facilities operated by us. The Rottersac and Arches production
sites in France have been designated as sites where employees have been in contact with asbestos from 1956 to
1997 and from 1960 to 1992, respectively. As a result of potential exposure to asbestos, employees employed at
the Rottersac and Arches production sites during these periods are entitled to or have already opted for early
retirement. In addition, we are aware of a number of cases where individual employees and/or their beneficiaries
have presented asbestos indemnification claims for their illness, alleged loss of salary, anxiety suffering
(préjudice d’anxiété) and difficult living conditions (trouble dans les conditions d’existence). While we sold our
fine arts paper business which was housed by the Arches production site, to Italy-based F.I.L.A. Group in the
first quarter of 2020, we continue to remain liable for these claims under the terms of the sale. Although we do
not believe that these claims will have a material effect on our financial condition, there can be no assurance that
further claims will not be made against us. While we have an outstanding provision of €1.5 million as of
December 31, 2020 to cover outstanding asbestos-related claims by employees, there can be no guarantee that
such claims will not increase or that new claims will not be brought in the future. We may face other asbestosrelated liabilities as asbestos has been identified in materials and structures in certain current and former
productions sites. If materials and structures containing asbestos become damaged or are renovated or
demolished, additional costs may be incurred.

If any of the above-mentioned risks were to materialize, they could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, any potential non-compliance with
environmental, health and safety regulations could lead to administrative sanctions, such as warnings, fines and
suspension of activities, temporary or permanent withdrawal of permits and licenses granted from government
entities and/or public authorities and, potentially, criminal sanctions.

**_Product safety or quality failures could interrupt our manufacturing operations and we may be required to_**
**_pay damages or other remedies as a result of product liability claims._**

The quality and safety of our products is critical to the success of our business. The quality targets of our
customers in many product segments are very high and tend to have risen further in recent years, which
highlights the importance of consistency and repeatability in production processes to ensure customer
satisfaction. Furthermore, certain of our products are used in the food and medical industries, where key
customers have stringent requirements regarding the products they purchase and conduct regular audits to ensure
compliance with applicable regulations, including consumer protection, health, safety and hygiene standards. The
consequences of quality or safety issues due to, for example, accidental or malicious raw material contamination
or due to supply chain contamination caused by human error, sabotage or equipment fault could be severe.
Detected faults or defects in products or in product descriptions discovered at a critical point in our production
chain could interrupt production in the unit concerned and disturb the entire chain’s operations. Such
disturbances could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Our products are generally integrated into and become a part of more valuable end products. If a product
supplied by us is found to be defective and causes the end product to fail, our potential liability may be higher
than the cost of the faulty product sold by us. In the event that effective contractual limitations of liability have
not been included in some of the supply agreements into which we have entered or will enter with our customers,
or if such limitations are not enforceable, we may be required to pay substantial damages if faulty products have
been or are delivered by us under such supply agreements. Such occurrences may also take substantial time to
resolve, including assessing potential liabilities and involving insurance companies. Any of the above could have
a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Our insurance coverage may not be sufficient, potentially leaving us uninsured against certain risks._**

Globally, we have 45 production facilities located in several European countries, the United States, Brazil
and Asia, and damages to these facilities or interruptions in the production at these facilities may disrupt our
operations and lead to production loss, which can result in delivery problems and additional costs. There can be
no assurance that damages to the production facilities or losses resulting from production interruptions are fully
covered by insurance. The COVID-19 outbreak has adversely changed and may continue to change the
characteristics of the global insurance market, making it less favorable to insurers amidst the outbreak. We seek
to use leading insurance brokers and insurance companies for our business. However, our insurance coverage
may not be sufficient to cover all of our potential liabilities. Accordingly, a major claim, or a series of smaller
claims, for damages related to our products sold, or advice given to customers in connection with products sold,

45


-----

may not be fully covered by insurance, or may not be covered by insurance at all, which could have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

We maintain insurance coverage for, among other things, property damage, business interruption and
product and general liability in amounts believed to be consistent with industry practices, but it is not fully
insured against all risks, and insurance against all types of risks and catastrophic events may not be available on
reasonable economic terms or at all. In addition, our global operations make it more difficult to manage the
insurance coverage, as insurance practices and terms vary depending on the jurisdiction, and there can thus be no
assurance that we are able to maintain a sufficient insurance coverage in all the jurisdictions in which we operate.
The occurrence of an accident that causes losses in excess of limits specified under the relevant policy or is
subject to material deductibles or self-insured retentions, or losses arising from events not covered, or not fully
covered, by insurance policies, such as certain catastrophic events, could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition and results of operations. We may be exposed to natural catastrophic events
including, among others, windstorms, hailstorms, severe winter weather, floods, earthquakes and outbreaks of
disease, viruses and pandemics, which are inherently unpredictable in terms of both their occurrence, severity,
spread and potential harm to human beings. We may also be exposed to the risk of terrorism, the materialization
of which could have a material adverse effect on the industries in which we operate and our business, financial
condition and results of operations.

**_Financial difficulties or bankruptcy of one or more of our major customers or financing counterparties could_**
**_have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations._**

We are exposed to credit risk in relation to our accounts receivable from customers. As of December 31,
2020, our trade and other receivables amounted to €264.7 million. In the past, certain of our customers have
experienced, and may experience in the future, financial and operational challenges, the continuation or
exacerbation of which could place them in additional financial and operational distress or could even result in
their bankruptcy. Although we have in place certain procedures and controls, such as credit insurance and
additional credit risk assessment, such measures may not fully or adequately alleviate our exposure to such credit
risks. For example, the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic may have a negative effect on the business of our
customers, especially in the short-term. See “—The COVID-19 pandemic and possible future outbreaks could
_disrupt our business operations.”_

Furthermore, a prolonged duration of the COVID-19 pandemic, including any future outbreaks of the virus
or of a similar pandemic, or the other changes in the global economy may put additional financial stress on our
customers. Financial and operational challenges experienced by customers may impact our ability to collect
outstanding accounts receivables fully or in a timely manner, or at all, and, consequently, result in credit losses
and have a material adverse effect on our cash flows. In an uncertain economic situation, it may be difficult to
cover our customer credit risks with credit insurance. In addition, the failure by customers to fulfill their payment
obligations towards us may have a material adverse effect on the terms or availability of credit insurance for us.
These factors, combined with limited availability of credit, could also cause our customers to reduce the volume
of their purchases in an effort to improve their own financial position.

An uncertain economic situation also leads to increased counterparty risk, that is the risk that one or more of
our counterparties may be unable to fulfill their contractual obligations to us. The financial downturn following
the COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated this risk. As uncertainty remains in the global markets, the global
economy could fall back into a recession which could lead to banks, insurance companies and other corporations
facing financial difficulties, which, in turn, may lead to corporate restructuring arrangements, states taking over
companies and bankruptcies. Despite any efforts by us to manage our counterparty risk, there is a possibility that
one or more of our counterparties could face serious financial difficulties or bankruptcy. If counterparty risk
materializes, we may have to absorb losses in an amount higher than expected or may incur costs relating to,
among other things, rearranging our credit transactions, including on less favorable terms, such as an incremental
change in our financing rate or insurance contracts. Further, counterparty risks that materialize could force us to
obtain alternative financing to meet our obligations under our financing arrangements, and such financing may
not be available on commercially acceptable terms, or at all. Materialization of a credit or counterparty risk could
have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_We are subject to currency exchange rate fluctuations._**

We operate and sell products globally, and, as a result, we generate a portion of our sales and incur a portion
of our expenses in currencies other than our functional currency, euro, which are primarily U.S. dollar, Swedish

46


-----

krona, Chinese renminbi, Brazilian real, British pound sterling and South Korean won. As a result of our
significant presence in the United States, we are particularly exposed to fluctuations in the exchange rate of the
U.S. dollar. In addition, purchase prices of pulp, chemicals and freight are primarily denominated in U.S. dollar,
and, following the Transactions, a large portion of our indebtedness will be denominated in U.S. dollars. We are
exposed to both transaction risk and translation risk. As we incur a portion of our expenses in currencies other
than the currencies in which we generate our sales, appreciation of a currency in which costs are incurred against
a currency in which sales are generated could have a material adverse impact on our results of operations. To
reduce the impact of transaction exposure at the Group level, we have regularly hedged a forecasted exposure to
currencies in accordance with our hedging policies, See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial
_Condition and Results of Operations—Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Financial Risk—Market_
_Risk—Currency Risk.” Following the Transactions, we also expect to naturally hedge U.S. dollar translation risk_
by designating the USD Notes and the USD TLB Facility as hedges of our net investments denominated in U.S.
dollars. However, the hedging policies adopted by us may not be sufficient to reduce or eliminate such risk. In
addition, we report our results in euro, but have revenues, expenses, assets and liabilities in other currencies,
primarily as the result of our ownership of our foreign subsidiaries. Consequently, we are exposed to translation
risk to the extent that assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses are reported in currencies other than euro. In order
to prepare our consolidated financial statements, we must translate the value of those assets, liabilities, revenues
and expenses at then applicable exchange rates. For more information on currency risk management, see note 19
to the 2020 Financial Statements. As a result, any fluctuations in currency exchange rates could have a material
adverse effect our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Our tax burden could increase due to changes in tax laws or regulations or their application and_**
**_interpretation, or as a result of current or future tax audits._**

Due to the international nature of our business, we are subject to the tax laws and regulations of several
jurisdictions, in particular with regard to transfer pricing rules. Related companies must conduct any intercompany transactions on an arm’s length basis and provide sufficient documentation thereof, subject to
applicable rules of the relevant jurisdiction. The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development
(“OECD”) has recently published new guidance on transfer pricing. National tax authorities are increasingly
scrutinizing and challenging companies’ transfer pricing policies. In addition, the estimation of our total income
taxes requires thorough consideration and numerous filings in various countries and the final amount of taxes
related to certain transactions and calculations cannot be estimated with full certainty. Our tax burden is,
therefore, dependent on specific aspects of tax laws and regulations in several jurisdictions including their
application and interpretation. Changes in tax laws or regulations or their application or interpretation could
significantly increase our tax burden, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition and results of operations. These include the recent limitations on the right to deduct interest expense
and controlled foreign company rules, implemented into national tax laws and applied as of the year 2019, due to
the Council Directive (EU) 2016/1164 of 12 July 2016 laying down rules against tax avoidance practices that
directly affect the functioning of the internal market (as amended from time to time). Furthermore, the
introduction of the OECD multilateral instrument and the inclusion of the so-called principal purpose test in the
same could increase uncertainty with respect to application of tax treaties.

In addition, we are currently and will be, from time to time, subject to general tax audits by national tax
authorities. At the date of this Offering Memorandum, we are subject to tax audits or tax litigation in Italy,
Germany, India, Brazil, the United States (Pennsylvania, Kentucky and Illinois) and China. As a result of
ongoing or future tax audits or other review actions of tax or other authorities, additional taxes (such as income
taxes, withholding taxes, real estate taxes, capital gains taxes, transfer taxes and value added taxes) could be
imposed, which could lead to an increase in our tax liabilities either as a result of the relevant tax payment being
imposed directly against us or as a result of us becoming liable for the relevant tax as a secondary obligor.

Tax audits and claims could have a material adverse effect on us. We and our predecessors have historically
grown by acquisitions, with the most significant being the Expera Acquisition and the Caieiras Acquisition in
2018. Tax authorities may question some of the positions that we or our predecessors have taken and,
consequently, additional taxes may be assessed, or tax assets may be challenged. The main items under
discussion or already disputed relate to transfer pricing and business-related taxes. Although we currently believe
that the above-mentioned processes will not have any significant effect on our financial position or profitability,

48


-----

the realization of any risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition and results of operations.

**_We may be unable to utilize our deferred tax assets._**

As of December 31, 2020, Ahlstrom-Munksjö’s recorded deferred tax assets (after netting) and deferred tax
liabilities were €6.1 million and €141.7 million, respectively. Our ability to generate taxable income will be
subject to general economic, financial, competitive, legislative, regulatory and other factors that are beyond our
control. If we generate a lower taxable income than the amount assumed in determining our deferred tax assets or
if tax rates are lowered, the value of our deferred tax assets would be reduced. Any of these factors could have a
material adverse effect on our financial condition and results of operations.

**_Costs related to pension benefit plans could increase._**

Ahlstrom-Munksjö has established certain defined pension benefit and defined pension contribution plans in
various countries in which it operates or have liability for such plans as part of its historical operations.
Accordingly, we will be exposed to various risks related to our defined benefit plans, including the risk of actual
investment returns being lower than assumed rates of return and the risk of results deviating from actuarial
assumptions for areas such as mortality of plan participants. In addition, fluctuations in interest rates may cause
changes in the annual cost and benefit obligations. Higher than expected inflation may increase benefit
obligations and annual payments to insurance companies. The additional amount of future contributions to our
defined benefit plans will depend upon factors mentioned above and, as a result, the amounts we will be required
to contribute in the future may vary. Cash contributions to defined benefit plans will reduce cash available for
our business. The above-mentioned risks relate in particular to our plans that are in effect in Sweden, Germany,
France, Italy, the United States and the United Kingdom. As of December 31, 2020, Ahlstrom-Munksjö’s
employee benefit obligations in the balance sheet amounted to €93.1 million. Any of the above-mentioned risks,
if they were to materialize, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results
of operations.

**_We are subject to the risk of labor disputes, work stoppages and increased labor costs._**

Most of our employees are represented by labor unions. Although we believe that our relations with our
employees and with our labor unions are generally good, there can be no assurance that this will continue to be
the case. A deterioration of relationships between us and our employees and labor unions could result in strikes
or work stoppages at any of our facilities. In addition, our relations with employees represented by a labor union
are governed by certain collective bargaining agreements and we may not be able to renegotiate satisfactory
collective bargaining agreements when they expire, which could lead to, among other consequences, increased
labor costs. Such renegotiation could also lead to disputes which may disrupt operations at our production sites.
Labor disputes in the transportation sector may prevent the distribution of our products, and labor disputes
affecting our suppliers or customers may result in variations in the supply of products and materials to us and in
demand for our products and services. Any sustained labor dispute leading to a substantial interruption in our
overall business, increased labor costs or changes to the terms of collective bargaining agreements could have a
material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_We may from time to time be involved in litigation and other similar proceedings that could have a material_**
**_adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations._**

We may from time to time be involved in litigation and other similar proceedings and further disputes could
arise in the ordinary course of business related to, among others, contracts, tax issues, alleged defects in product
deliveries, health and safety matters, competition law, intellectual property, employment matters, and
environmental issues. Such litigation and other similar proceedings may be costly, divert management attention,
disrupt normal operations and result in reputational damage for us. The outcome of any dispute is impossible to
predict. It is also impossible to rule out the possibility of an unfavorable outcome in ongoing proceedings, or any
proceedings that may arise in the future, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition and results of operations.

**_Concerns about the effects of climate change may have an impact on our business._**

Concerns about global warming and carbon footprints, as well as legal and financial incentives favoring
alternative fuels, are causing the increased use of sustainable, non-fossil fuel sources for electricity generation.

49


-----

Electricity generation companies are competing in the same markets as us for the same raw materials that we use
in some of our production process, namely wood and derivative products, driving prices for such materials
upwards, especially during the winter in the Northern hemisphere. Climate change could also cause the spread of
disease and pestilence into plantations and fiber sources, far beyond their traditional geographic spreads,
increasing the risk that the wood supply necessary to our operations may be negatively impacted. If either of
these phenomena intensifies, additional costs or supply shortages could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition and results of operations.

**Risks Related to the Transactions**

**_Ownership of 100% of the Company Shares is dependent on the completion of the Squeeze-Out._**

As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Issuer owns 90.6% of the Company Shares. The Issuer has
filed an application to initiate the Squeeze-Out proceedings as provided in the Finnish Companies Act in order to
gain 100% of the Company Shares. Until such time as the Squeeze-Out has completed or the Issuer has obtained
advance title to the remaining minority Company Shares against the placing of a security under the Squeeze-out
proceedings, third-party minority shareholders will continue to hold the outstanding Company Shares. The
Squeeze-Out is an arbitral proceeding regulated by the Finnish Companies Act and the Finnish Arbitration Act,
which could potentially be time consuming, and is subject to appeal by one or more minority shareholders. These
proceedings typically take approximately eight to twelve months to complete but advance title to the minority
shares may, subject to the discretion of the arbitral tribunal, under the proceedings often be obtained in
approximately four to six months against the placing of a security. These proceedings may also be longer due to
events outside the Issuer’s control. Further, in the event that the placing of a security by the Issuer for obtaining
of the advance title is refused by the arbitral tribunal, the Issuer could decide not to place such security or appeal
the arbitral award and if the Issuer decides not to pay the redemption price in accordance with such award, the
minority shareholders would potentially continue to hold some or all of the outstanding Company Shares until
the Issuer’s redemption right and the redemption price have been finally determined by a non-appealable arbitral
award or court decision and such redemption price has been paid by the Issuer.

**_The Sponsors’ opportunity to conduct due diligence with respect to Ahlstrom-Munksjö was limited, and their_**
**_due diligence may not have revealed all facts that may be relevant in connection with the Acquisition._**

Before making investments, the Sponsors conduct due diligence that they deem reasonable and appropriate
based on the facts and circumstances applicable to each investment. The objectives of the due diligence process
are to identify attractive investment opportunities based on the facts and circumstances relevant to a specific
asset, to identify possible risks associated with such asset and to prepare a framework that may be used from the
date of the acquisition of such asset to drive operational achievement and value creation in such asset. When
conducting due diligence, the Sponsors typically evaluate a number of important business, financial, tax,
accounting, environmental and legal issues in determining whether or not to proceed with an investment.

Outside consultants, legal advisors, accountants and investment banks are involved in the due diligence
process in varying degrees depending on the type of investment. Nevertheless, when conducting due diligence
and making an assessment regarding an investment, the Sponsors rely on resources available to them, including
information provided by the target of the investment and, in some circumstances, third party investigations.
Instances of bribery, fraud, accounting irregularities, contingent liabilities and other improper, illegal or corrupt
practices can be difficult to detect, and fraud and other deceptive practices can be widespread in certain
jurisdictions.

There may be liabilities that the Sponsors failed or were unable to discover in the course of performing due
diligence investigations into us and our subsidiaries in connection with the Acquisition. Following the
Acquisition, the Sponsors may learn of additional information about us and/or any of our subsidiaries that
adversely affect us, such as unknown or contingent liabilities and issues relating to compliance with applicable
laws. Any such liabilities, individually or in the aggregate, could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial position and results of operations.

As Ahlstrom-Munksjö is a publicly listed company, the due diligence conducted for the Acquisition was
mostly limited to publicly available information and certain other information made available to the Sponsors as
part of their due diligence process. Accordingly, we cannot be certain that the Sponsors’ due diligence
investigation has revealed or highlighted all relevant facts (including fraud, bribery and other illegal activities
and contingent liabilities) that may be necessary or helpful in evaluating the merits of investing in us. We cannot
be certain that the Sponsors’ due diligence investigations will result in the Sponsors’ investment in us being

50


-----

successful or that the actual financial performance of such investment will not fall short of the financial
projections the Sponsors used when evaluating that investment.

**_We may not be able to realize the anticipated operational efficiencies and cost savings in the Acquisition._**

The Sponsors intend to implement certain operational efficiency and cost saving measures in connection
with the Acquisition. We may not be able to realize the anticipated efficiencies and savings targeted by these
measures, either in the amount or within the timeframe that we currently anticipate, and the costs of achieving
these measures may be higher than what we expect.

Our estimated efficiency gains and costs savings are forward-looking and therefore subject to a number of
assumptions about the timing, execution and costs associated with realizing the underlying measures. Such
assumptions are inherently uncertain and are subject to significant business, economic and competition risks and
uncertainties. There can be no assurance that such assumptions will turn out to be correct. In addition, the
estimated efficiency gains and cost savings may be offset by deterioration in the markets in which we operate,
increases in other expenses or challenges in the business unrelated to the Transactions. As a result, the amount of
efficiency gains and savings that we will actually realize and/or the timing of any such realization may differ
significantly (and may be significantly lower or later) from the ones that we currently estimate and we may incur
significant costs in realizing the Acquisition and in reaching the estimated gains and savings. Failure to achieve
the expected efficiency gains and savings may result in a lower return on investment for the Acquisition and
could have a material adverse effect on our business and results of operations.

**_The Acquisition will entitle certain of Ahlstrom-Munksjö‘s customers and business partners to terminate their_**
**_agreements with Ahlstrom-Munksjö as a result of change of control provisions._**

Certain of the agreements entered into by Ahlstrom-Munksjö and its subsidiaries include change of control
provisions. The Acquisition may constitute a change of control under such agreements. As a result,
counterparties to these agreements may be entitled to terminate their agreements with Ahlstrom-Munksjö as a
result of the Acquisition. Some of these counterparties may exercise their termination rights, which could have an
adverse effect on Ahlstrom-Munksjö‘s business, financial position and results of operations. In addition, changes
of control may be subject to approval by governmental authorities.

In the event of termination of any material contract as a result of the Acquisition, there can be no assurance
that Ahlstrom-Munksjö would be able to successfully replace any products or services that were provided under
the relevant contract at attractive prices or at all. Likewise, if Ahlstrom-Munksjö is required to amend any such
contract, we can provide no assurance that the terms of such amendment will not be materially adverse to us or
will not otherwise impact Ahlstrom-Munksjö‘s business or operations. Accordingly, any termination or
amendment of a significant contract as a result of the change of control could materially or adversely affect
Ahlstrom-Munksjö‘s business and the ability to provide services to our customers. It is also possible that material
supply contracts could be terminated or amended in other circumstances. Any such termination or amendment
could have a material adverse effect on Ahlstrom-Munksjö‘s business, results of operations and financial
condition.

**Risks Related to our Indebtedness**

We have a significant amount of debt and debt service obligations. As of December 31, 2020, after giving

amounting to €51.0 million) in a nominal amount of €1,845.6 million (equivalent), of which €1,650.0 million

“Capitalization,” “Description of Other Indebtedness,” and “Description of the Notes.” We anticipate that our
high leverage will continue to exist for the foreseeable future.

The degree to which we will be leveraged following completion of the Transactions could have important
consequences to holders of the Notes, including, but not limited to:

   - making it more difficult for the Issuer and its subsidiaries to satisfy their respective obligations with
respect to the Notes, the Senior Secured Credit Facilities and other debt and liabilities we may incur;

   - increasing our vulnerability to, and reducing our flexibility to respond to, general adverse economic
and industry conditions;

fund working capital, capital expenditures, acquisitions, joint ventures, product research and

   - restricting us from pursuing acquisitions or exploiting business opportunities;

   - increasing our exposure to interest rate increases because some of our indebtedness bears a floating rate

   - limiting our ability to obtain additional financing to fund future operations, capital expenditures,

   - limiting our ability to obtain additional capacity for issuance of bid, advance payment, performance

   - tax implications arising from the Transactions, tax deductibility of interest costs thereon, an increase in
our effective tax rate and tax jurisdictions involved.

Any of these or other consequences or events could have a material adverse effect on our ability to satisfy
our obligations, including under the Notes and the Senior Secured Credit Facilities.

**_The Issuer is a holding company that has no revenue generating operations of its own and will depend on_**
**_cash from the operating companies of the Group to be able to make payments on the Notes and the Note_**
**_Guarantees._**

The Issuer is a holding company with no business operations other than management of the equity interests
it holds in its subsidiaries. The Issuer will be dependent upon the cash flow from its operating subsidiaries in the
form of dividends or other distributions or payments to meet its obligations, including its obligations under the
Notes and the Note Guarantees. Given the Group’s international operations, it has a large number of operating
subsidiaries and business participations, which individually contribute to our Group’s results. The amounts of
dividends and distributions available to the Issuer will depend on the profitability and cash flows of their
subsidiaries and the ability of each of those subsidiaries to declare dividends under applicable law or transfer
profits under profit and loss transfer agreements, if applicable. The Issuer’s subsidiaries, however, may not be
able to, or may not be permitted under applicable law to, make distributions or advance upstream loans to the
Issuer to make payments in respect of their indebtedness, including the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Various agreements governing our debt may restrict and, in some cases may actually prohibit, the ability of
these subsidiaries to move cash within their restricted group. Applicable tax laws may also subject such
payments to further taxation. Applicable law as well as profit and loss transfer agreements between several
entities of the Group may also limit the amounts that some of our subsidiaries will be permitted to pay as
dividends or distributions on their equity interests, or even prevent such payments. In particular, the ability of the
Issuer’s subsidiaries to pay dividends to the Issuer will generally be limited to the amount of distributable
reserves available to each of them and the ability to pay their respective debt when due. The subsidiaries of the
Issuer that do not guarantee the Notes have no direct obligation to make payments with respect to the Notes or
the Note Guarantees.

While the Indenture limits the ability of the Issuer’s subsidiaries to incur consensual restrictions on their
ability to pay dividends or make other intercompany payments, these limitations are subject to significant
qualifications and exceptions, including exceptions for restrictions imposed by applicable law.

52
