The United States is not currently bound by a treaty providing for reciprocal recognition and enforcement of
judgments, other than arbitral awards rendered in civil and commercial matters, with France, Finland and Italy.
For further information see “Service of Process and Enforcement of Civil Liabilities.”

**_The Issuer may not be able to repurchase the Notes upon a change of control. In addition, under certain_**
**_circumstances, the Issuer may have the right to purchase all outstanding Notes in connection with a tender_**
**_offer, even if certain holders of the Notes do not consent to the tender offer._**

If a Change of Control (as defined in the Indenture) occurs, the Issuer will be required to make an offer to
purchase all the outstanding respective Notes at a price equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof, plus any
accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of purchase. In such a
situation, the Issuer may not have enough funds to pay for all of the Notes that are tendered under any such offer.
If a significant principal amount of Notes is tendered, the Issuer will likely have to obtain financing to pay for the
tendered Notes. However, the Issuer may not be able to obtain such financing on acceptable terms, if at all. A
change of control would entitle each lender under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement (individually)
to cancel its commitments and require prepayment of amounts outstanding to it under the Senior Credit Facilities
Agreement and could trigger put rights, mandatory prepayments or accelerations under other existing or future
financing arrangements of the Group. Any failure by the Issuer to offer to purchase the Notes upon a change of
control would constitute a default under the Indenture, which would, in turn, constitute a default under the Senior
Secured Credit Facilities Agreement.

The change of control provision contained in the Indenture may not necessarily afford you protection in the
event of certain important corporate events, including reorganizations, restructurings, mergers, recapitalizations
or other similar transactions involving us that may adversely affect you, because such corporate events may not
involve a shift in voting power or beneficial ownership or, even if they do, may not constitute a change of control
as defined in the Indenture. Furthermore, the occurrence of certain events that might otherwise constitute a
change of control under the Indenture will be deemed not to be a change of control if a specified consolidated net
leverage ratio is met. See “Description of the Notes—Change of Control.”

In addition, in connection with certain tender offers for the Notes, if holders of not less than 90% in
aggregate principal amount of the applicable outstanding Notes validly tender and do not withdraw such Notes in
such tender offer and the Issuer, or any third party making such a tender offer in lieu of the Issuer, purchases, all
of the Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the Issuer or such third party will have the right
to redeem the Notes that remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to
the price offered to each other holder of Notes. See “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption—General.”

**_The term “all or substantially all” in the context of a change of control has no clearly established meaning_**
**_under relevant law and is subject to judicial interpretation such that it may not be certain that a change of_**
**_control has occurred or will occur._**

Upon the occurrence of a transaction that constitutes a change of control under the Indenture, the Issuer will
be required to make an offer to repurchase all outstanding Notes tendered. The definition of “change of control”
in the Indenture will include (with certain exceptions) a disposition of all or substantially all of the assets of the
Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries (taken as a whole), to any person. Although there is a limited body of case
law interpreting the phrase “all or substantially all,” it has no clearly established meaning under relevant law,
varies according to the facts and circumstances of the subject transaction and is subject to judicial interpretation.
Accordingly, in certain circumstances, there may be a degree of uncertainty in ascertaining whether a particular
transaction would involve a disposition of “all or substantially all” of the assets of a person, and therefore it may
be unclear whether a change of control has occurred and whether the relevant Issuer is required to make an offer
to repurchase the Notes.

**_We may dispose of certain assets or capital stock of entities in the Group._**

We may have an interest in pursuing acquisitions, divestitures, financings, or other transactions that, in our
judgment, would be beneficial to us, even if such transactions might involve risks to you as noteholders. For
example, pursuant to the asset disposition covenant and other provisions of the Senior Secured Credit Facilities
Agreement and the Indenture, we may, under certain circumstances, sell, convey, transfer or otherwise dispose of
material assets of the Group and, if meeting certain leverage ratios on an as adjusted basis or otherwise having
restricted payments capacity, distribute some or all of the proceeds therefrom to our shareholders. Such a
transaction would not constitute a change of control or a default under the terms of the Notes. See “Description

68


-----

_of the Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Restricted Payments.” Additionally, we may issue, sell transfer_
or otherwise dispose of the capital stock of entities in the Group for purposes of taking a dividend or distribution
that would benefit us but not benefit you as the noteholders.

**_Holders of the Notes may have adverse tax consequences in the event of an IPO Debt Pushdown._**

Under certain circumstances, we may undertake an IPO Debt Pushdown (as described in “Description of the
_Notes—IPO Debt Pushdown”), pursuant to which the Issuer is entitled to give notice that the terms of the_
Indenture and the Intercreditor Agreement (or any Additional Intercreditor Agreement (as defined in
“Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—Additional Intercreditor Agreements”)) will automatically
operate so that, among other things, the references to the Issuer and Restricted Subsidiaries (as defined in
“Description of the Notes—Certain Definitions”) (and all related provisions) shall apply only to the IPO
Pushdown Entity (as defined in “Description of the Notes—IPO Debt Pushdown”) and its Restricted Subsidiaries.
In such event, each holding company of the IPO Pushdown Entity would be released from its obligations under
the Indenture.

Such modifications to the terms of the Notes could be treated for U.S. federal income tax purposes as a
deemed exchange of (i) the Notes as in place prior to such modifications for (ii) new Notes as in place after such
modifications (the “New Notes”). If such modifications result in a deemed exchange for U.S. federal income tax
purposes, it would generally be treated as a taxable transaction for U.S. federal income tax purposes in which
beneficial owners of the Notes would be required to recognize any gain or loss. Furthermore, for U.S. federal
income tax purposes, the New Notes deemed issued in such a deemed exchange could be treated as issued with
original issue discount. In such event, U.S. Holders (as defined under “Certain Taxation Considerations—
_Certain U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations”) would generally be required to include the original issue_
discount in their income (as ordinary income) as it accrues, in advance of the receipt of cash corresponding to
such income. In addition, the determination of whether the New Notes are treated as “contingent payment debt
instruments” as a result of the possibility of additional payments, as further described under “Certain Taxation
_Considerations—Certain U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations—Additional Payments,” would be made at the_
time of the modification. U.S. Holders should consult their own tax advisors as to the U.S. federal income tax
considerations relating to potential modifications of the Notes in connection with the IPO Debt Pushdown,
including the U.S. federal income tax considerations of a deemed exchange and resulting OID, if any.

It is also possible that the IPO Debt Pushdown could result in a taxable event for tax purposes other than
U.S. federal income tax purposes.

**_Certain covenants and events of default will be suspended if we receive investment grade ratings._**

The Indenture will provide that, if at any time following the date of the Indenture, the Notes issued under
such Indenture receive any two of the following ratings: Baa3 or higher from Moody’s, BBB- or higher from
S&P or BBB- or higher from Fitch, and no default or event of default has occurred and is continuing, then
beginning that day and continuing until such time as such Notes are no longer rated investment grade by either
rating agency, certain covenants will cease to be applicable to such Notes. See “Description of the Notes—
_Certain Covenants—Suspension of Covenants on Achievement of Investment Grade Status.” At any time when_
these covenants are suspended, we will be able to, among other things, incur additional indebtedness, pay cash
dividends and redeem subordinated indebtedness without restriction, each of which may conflict with the
interests of holders of the Notes. There can be no assurance that the Notes will ever achieve an investment grade
rating or that any such rating if achieved will be maintained.

**_Credit ratings may not reflect all risks, are not recommendations to buy or hold securities and may be subject_**
**_to revision, suspension or withdrawal at any time._**

One or more independent credit rating agencies may assign credit ratings to the Notes. The credit ratings
address our ability to perform our obligations under the terms of the Notes and credit risks in determining the
likelihood that payments will be made when due under the Notes. The ratings may not reflect the potential
impact of all risks related to the structure, market, additional risk factors discussed above and other factors that
may affect the value of the Notes. A credit rating is not a recommendation to buy, sell or hold securities and may
be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal by the rating agency at any time. No assurances can be given
that a credit rating will remain constant for any given period of time or that a credit rating will not be lowered or
withdrawn entirely by the credit rating agency if, in its judgment, circumstances in the future so warrant. A
suspension, reduction or withdrawal at any time of the credit rating assigned to the Notes by one or more of the
credit rating agencies may adversely affect the cost and terms and conditions of our financings and could
adversely affect the value and trading of the Notes.

**_The Notes may not become or remain listed on the Exchange._**

Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited for the listing of and
permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange. However, there can be no assurance that the
Notes will become or remain listed. If the Issuer cannot maintain the listing on the Exchange and the admission
to dealing on the Official List thereof, or if it becomes unduly burdensome to make or maintain such listing, the
Issuer may cease to make or maintain such listing on the Official List of the Exchange. Listing of any of the
Notes on the Exchange does not imply that a public offering of any of the Notes in the Channel Islands or the Isle
of Man has been authorized. Although no assurance is made as to the liquidity of the Notes as a result of listing
on the Official List of the Exchange or another recognized listing exchange for comparable issuers, failure to be
approved for listing of the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange or another recognized listing exchange or
the delisting of the Notes from the Official List of the Exchange or another listing exchange may have an adverse
effect on a holder’s ability to resell Notes in the secondary market.

**_You may face foreign currency exchange as a result of investing in the Notes._**

The EUR Notes will be denominated and payable in euro. If you are a U.S. investor, an investment in the
EUR Notes will entail foreign exchange related risks due to, among other factors, possible significant changes in
the value of the euro relative to the U.S. dollar because of economic, political and other factors over which we
have no control. Depreciation of the euro against the U.S. dollar could cause a decrease in the effective yield of
the EUR Notes below their stated coupon rates and could result in a loss to you on a U.S. dollar basis.
Investments in the notes by U.S. investors may also have important tax consequences as a result of foreign
exchange gains, if any. The Indenture will not be qualified under the U.S. Trust Indenture Act of 1939, as
amended.

The Indenture will not be required to, and will not be, qualified under the U.S. Trust Indenture Act of 1939,
as amended (the “TIA”) and will not incorporate or include and will not be subject to any of the provisions of the
TIA. Consequently, the holders of Notes will not be entitled to the protections provided under the TIA to holders
of debt securities issued under a qualified indenture, including those respecting preferential collections by the
trustee or conflicting interests of the trustee. See “Description of the Notes.”

**_The Notes may be issued with original issue discount for U.S. federal income tax purposes._**

If the stated principal amount of the Notes exceeds their issue price by an amount greater than or equal to a
statutorily defined de minimis amount, then the Notes will be considered to be issued with original issue discount
(“OID”) for U.S. federal income tax purposes, although it is expected that the Notes will be issued without
original issue discount for U.S. federal income tax purposes. If the Notes are issued with OID, then, in addition to
the stated interest on a note, a U.S. investor would generally be required to include such OID in gross income (as
ordinary income) as it accrues on a constant yield basis for U.S. federal income tax purposes in advance of the
receipt of cash payments to which such income is attributable and regardless of the holder’s method of
accounting for U.S. federal income tax purposes.

**THE TRANSACTIONS**

**The Transactions**

**_The Acquisitions_**

_The Tender Offer_

On September 24, 2020, the Issuer and Ahlstrom-Munksjö entered into the Combination Agreement,
pursuant to which the Issuer announced a voluntary public cash tender offer with an offer price of €18.10 in cash
for each share validly tendered (the “Initially Announced Offer Price”) for all of the issued and outstanding
shares in Ahlstrom-Munksjö that are not held by Ahlstrom-Munksjö and its subsidiaries (the “Company Shares”
and the offer, the “Tender Offer”). The completion of the Tender Offer was subject to satisfaction of certain
conditions, including acceptance of the Tender Offer by shareholders holding more than 90% (on a fully diluted
basis) of the Company Shares and voting rights carried by the Company Shares, calculated in accordance with
applicable Finnish laws governing the right to commence compulsory squeeze-out proceedings (the “Minimum
Acceptance Condition”), together with any Company Shares otherwise held by the Issuer prior to the date of the
announcement of the final result of the Tender Offer. The Board of Directors of Ahlstrom-Munksjö, represented
by a quorum comprising the non-conflicted members of the Board of Directors, unanimously recommended that
the shareholders of Ahlstrom-Munksjö accept the Tender Offer. The Initially Announced Offer Price was
subsequently adjusted first to €17.97 per share and then to €17.84 per share (the “Tender Offer Price”) in
accordance with the terms and conditions of the Tender Offer, to account for two payments of dividend by the
Board of Directors of Ahlstrom-Munksjö after the Tender Offer was announced.

On January 15, 2021, the preliminary results of the Tender Offer were announced. The 50,386,853
Company Shares tendered in the Tender Offer, together with the total of 345,524 Company Shares acquired by
the Issuer through market purchases and the Company Shares which were to be received by Ahlstrom Invest
from the internal reorganization involving certain Ahlström family members and certain related entities and
which Ahlstrom Invest B.V. had undertaken to tender into the Tender Offer, represented approximately 81.1% of
all the Company Shares and voting rights carried by the Company Shares in Ahlstrom-Munksjö. On January 18,
2021, the Issuer announced that on the basis of the preliminary results of the Tender Offer, it decided to waive
the Minimum Acceptance Condition and complete the Tender Offer in accordance with its terms and conditions
provided that the final result of the Tender Offer confirmed that the Tender Offer had been validly accepted by
shareholders holding at least 75% (on a fully diluted basis) of the Company Shares and voting rights carried by
the Company Shares, calculated in accordance with Chapter 18, Section 1 of the Finnish Companies Act.

When the final result of the initial offer period under the Tender Offer was published on January 20, 2021,
the Company Shares validly tendered and accepted in the Tender Offer (including the Company Shares received
by Ahlstrom Invest B.V. as a result of the internal reorganization involving certain Ahlström family members
and certain related entities), together with the Company Shares acquired by the Issuer through market purchases,
represented approximately 81.0 % of all the Company Shares and voting rights carried by the Company Shares.
As such, the Issuer announced that it would complete the Tender Offer as the Minimum Acceptance Condition
had been waived and all other conditions to completion were fulfilled. The Issuer also announced that it would
commence a subsequent offer period in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Tender Offer (the
“Subsequent Offer Period”) in order to provide the remaining shareholders of Ahlstrom-Munksjö the opportunity
to accept the Tender Offer. On February 9, the Issuer announced the final result of the Subsequent Offer Period,
pursuant to which the Company Shares validly tendered and accepted during the Subsequent Offer Period,
together with the Company Shares validly tendered and accepted during the initial offer period (as extended) and
otherwise acquired by the Issuer through market purchases until February 8, 2021, represented approximately
90.6 per cent of all the Company Shares and voting rights carried by the Company Shares.

On February 4, 2021 (the “Initial Settlement Date”), the first settlement under the Tender Offer occurred
with respect to Company Shares registered with Euroclear Finland Oy and on February 5, 2021 with respect to
Company Shares registered with Euroclear Sweden AB, and the Issuer acquired approximately 81.0% of the
Company Shares. On February 10, 2021 (the “Second Settlement Date”), the second settlement under the Tender
Offer occurred with respect to Company Shares registered with Euroclear Finland Oy and on February 11, 2021
with respect to Company Shares registered with Euroclear Sweden AB, and the Issuer acquired an additional
9.6% of the Company Shares. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Issuer owned approximately
90.6% of the Company Shares.

_The Squeeze-Out_

Under Chapter 18, Section 1 of the Finnish Companies Act, a shareholder holding more than nine-tenths of
the total number of shares and voting rights in a limited liability company has the right to redeem and, subject to
a demand by other shareholders, is also obligated to redeem the shares owned by the other shareholders in a
company at a fair price. The shares held by the company or its subsidiaries are not taken into account when
calculating the aggregate number of the shares and voting rights for the purposes of said Section.

The Issuer has on February 11, 2021 notified Ahlstrom-Munksjö of its decision to exercise its redemption
right pursuant to the Finnish Companies Act and to redeem all the Company Shares held by any other remaining
shareholders in Ahlstrom-Munksjö. To implement the redemption of the remaining Company Shares, the Issuer
has filed an application to initiate arbitration proceedings as provided in the Finnish Companies Act. In the
redemption proceedings, the Issuer will seek a redemption price of €17.84 per Share for the remaining Company
Shares, which corresponds to the Tender Offer Price. The arbitral tribunal will determine the timing of the
redemption proceedings and eventually decide on the redemption price payable by the Issuer for the remaining
Company Shares. The Issuer intends to apply for the delisting of the Company Shares from Nasdaq Helsinki Ltd
and Nasdaq Stockholm AB as soon as permitted and reasonably practicable under applicable laws and
regulations and the rules of said stock exchanges.

Following the completion of the Squeeze-Out, we may undertake certain reorganizations of members of the
Group located in Sweden, France or Italy.

Agreement also provides for the Revolving Credit Facility in an amount of €325 million (equivalent). See “Capitalization.”

Company Shares. These proceedings typically take approximately eight to twelve months to complete but advance title to the minority
shares may, subject to the discretion of the arbitral tribunal, under the proceedings often be obtained in approximately four to six months
against the placing of a security. While the Issuer has initiated the proceedings on the basis of the Tender Offer Price, the price of the
Company Shares acquired in the Squeeze-Out could be in excess of the Tender Offer Price. The price of the Company Shares to be paid

_The Refinancing_

In connection with the Acquisitions, the Issuer entered into the Bridge Facilities Agreements, which provide
for the EUR Bridge Facility in an aggregate principal amount of €600,000,000 and the USD Bridge Facility in an
aggregate principal amount of $484,936,000. The Issuer used, or will use, the proceeds from the Bridge
Facilities, the Equity Contributions from the Sponsors and drawings under the Senior Term Facilities, to finance
its acquisition of the Company Shares offered pursuant to the Tender Offer, to prepay or redeem the Existing
Senior Unsecured Notes, the Hybrid Bond and certain existing bank loans (excluding the Pension Loan, local
lines, leases and other bank loans being rolled over), to pay certain costs and expenses and for the other uses as
described under “—The Acquisitions—Sources and Uses for the Acquisitions.” See also “Use of Proceeds.”

**USE OF PROCEEDS**

We estimate that the gross proceeds of the Offering of the Notes will be €650.0 million (equivalent). The
proceeds from the Offering, together with a portion of the proceeds from the Senior Term Facilities and cash on
hand, will be used by the Issuer to refinance the indebtedness outstanding under the Bridge Facilities and, in
particular:

   - approximately €274.6 million for the purposes of refinancing the proceeds of the Bridge Facilities
utilized to pay the purchase price of €1,859.6 of the Company Shares that have been acquired by the
Issuer as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, representing approximately 90.6% of the Company
Shares, (ii) pay costs, fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Acquisitions and the other
transactions as described above, including legal, accounting, ratings advisory and other transaction
costs and professional fees, and (iii) pay costs, fees and expenses incurred in connection with the
Offering representing all the proceeds from Tranche A (as defined below) under the Notes; and

   - approximately €375.4 million for the purposes of refinancing proceeds of the Bridge Facilities utilized
for the purposes of the repayment or refinancing of certain existing debt of the Group, representing all
the proceeds from Tranche B (as defined below) under the Notes.

For the avoidance of doubt, the “virtual tranching” of the Notes is aimed at identifying the separate portions
of the proceeds from the Offering to be used by the Issuer to refinance the proceeds under the Bridge Facilities
utilized for (i) payment of the purchase price of the Company Shares, (ii) payment of costs, fees and expenses
related to the Transactions and (iii) refinancing of repayment or refinancing certain existing debt of the Group
and will not entail issuing separate identifiers (ISINs or Common Codes) for each such virtual tranche under the
Notes. See “—The Acquisitions—Sources and Uses for the Acquisitions” and “Use of Proceeds.”
.

**Overview**

We are a global leader in the production of high-performance fiber-based materials for a variety of
consumer and industrial end-uses. Our products are used in a broad range of industrial applications and
consumer-driven products and processes, ranging from everyday consumables, health care and life sciences,
homebuilding and furniture, industrial goods and transportation. Sustainability is central across our businesses,
and with our product offering we facilitate a sustainable everyday life by providing solutions with better
performance, safer materials, fewer resources and a lower environmental impact. Our net sales, operating result,
net result and Comparable EBITDA were €2,683.3 million, €176.2 million, €94.5 million and €334.2 million,
respectively, for the year ended December 31, 2020 and our As Adjusted EBITDA was €412.6 million for the
year ended December 31, 2020.

We produce fiber-based materials from pulp and other fibers, and then typically sell such materials to
converters who incorporate them in their end-products. We also produce certain end-products ourselves. Our
product offering includes filter materials, release liners, food and beverage processing and packaging materials,
decor papers, abrasive and tape backings, electrotechnical insulation paper, glass fiber materials, medical fabrics
and solutions for diagnostics, and a range of other specialty materials and pulp for industrial and consumer
enduses. We develop our products in close cooperation with customers and other stakeholders in the value-chain,
making use of our high technical expertise and broad experience. We design our custom-made and tailored
materials with a high degree of differentiation to meet and exceed specific customer demands concerning quality
and functionality, adding value for customers.

We target niche markets that benefit from value-based pricing and require technical specialization making it
more challenging for new market entrants. As a niche player, identifying trends and developing new customer
solutions are critical for our business. We have a strong focus on innovation and aim to regularly refresh our
offering and to improve sustainable functionality and design. Our recent innovations include FortiCell® launched
in 2020, a new range of fiber-based solutions for energy storage applications using amongst others our DISPRO
foam-forming technology, Extia® Protect, a comprehensive range of materials for face masks using fine fiber
technology, and BioWeb® and Fiber+ ranges, which use renewable biopolymer polylactic acid for producing
biodegradable and compostable tea bag materials. Our sales from New Products increased to 12% for the year
ended December 31, 2020.

We serve a diverse customer base with more than 6,000 customers in over 100 countries. For the year ended
December 31, 2020, 37% of our sales were to customers in the consumer goods sector, 27% in the homebuilding
and furniture sector, 14% in the transportation sector, 11% in the industrials sector and 11% in the health care
and life sciences sector. For the year ended December 31, 2020, our top-five and top-ten largest customers
generated 13% and 19% of our net sales, respectively.

81


-----

We manufacture our products globally and have 45 manufacturing plants and converting sites in
14 countries. We consume commodity pulp as part of the manufacturing process. Our commodity pulp
consumption was approximately 1,200 thousand tons for the year ended December 31, 2020. Our pulp exposure
was reduced by approximately 500 thousand tons of our own pulp production during that same period, which
includes 185 thousand tons of market pulp production at our Aspa pulp mill in Sweden that is sold to third
parties. We believe that our global manufacturing footprint represents a competitive advantage and would be
challenging for new market entrants to replicate given its specification and scale. Our manufacturing sites are
equipped to provide and apply innovative technology, including FluoroFree® capabilities (providing grease
resistance without fluorochemicals), Parchmentizing technology (transforming cellulose to give it plastic-like
qualities) and fine fiber technology with multi-row spinning, which was recently adapted to also produce face
masks. We delivered a total of approximately 1,570 thousand tons of materials in the year ended December 31,
2020. We organize delivery of our products directly to many of our business-to-business customers using thirdparty transport service providers.

We were formed by the merger of Ahlstrom Corporation and Munksjö Oyj on April 1, 2017, which created
a global leader in the production of high-performance fiber-based materials. Our two predecessor companies
have a long history in the Finnish and Swedish forestry and paper industry. Since the merger, we have grown
significantly through the acquisitions of the Caieiras specialty paper mill in Brazil and Expera Specialty
Solutions in North America, each in October 2018.

**Our Business Areas**

On January 1, 2020, we implemented a new business structure to promote core business capabilities,
sharpen strategic targets and align the business characteristics of each business area. This structure has sixteen
businesses, which are organized into five business areas based on their core capabilities and characteristics to
strengthen synergies, and for reporting and governance purposes.

   - **Filtration & Performance Solutions: Filtration, Nonwovens, Glass Fiber Tissue, Abrasive**

   - **Advanced Solutions: Liquid Technologies, Beverage & Casing, Medical, Tape, Precision Coating**

   - **Industrial Solutions: Insulation, Release Liners, Coated Specialties**

   - **Food Packaging & Technical Solutions: Food Packaging, Technical, Parchment**

   - **Decor Solutions: Decor**

We believe that this change to our business areas was a natural next step following the initial integration
phase of the North America Specialty Solutions business area following the acquisition of Expera Specialty
Solutions. In the new structure, North America Specialty Solutions is integrated into the operating platform and
businesses are partly reorganized. Our Filtration & Performance Solutions and Advanced Solutions business
areas are focused on product development, and our Industrial Solutions and Food Packaging & Technical
Solutions business areas are focused on optimizing production. The Decor Solutions business area maintains its
single business focus, with the ambition to build a leading standalone global operation.

We evaluate the performance of each of these segments using key measures, such as net sales and
Comparable EBITDA. For the year ended December 31, 2020, excluding the impact of Other and eliminations,
Filtration & Performance Solutions comprised 23.4% of our net sales, Advanced Solutions comprised 17.5% of
our net sales, Industrial Solutions comprised 25.1% of our net sales, Food Packaging & Technical Solutions
comprised 20.4% of our net sales and Decor Solutions comprised 13.6% of our net sales. For further information
on our business areas for period prior to January 1, 2020, see “—Factors Affecting the Comparability of the
_Financial Statements—Changes to Reportable Segments” below._

We also report net sales across five regions and 12 geographies. For the year ended December 31, 2020, our
net sales were 43.2% in Europe, 34.7% in North America, 7.3% in South America, 13.3% in Asia-Pacific and
1.4% in the Rest of the World.

**Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations and Financial Condition**

Our results of operations are affected by a combination of factors, including factors which are beyond our
control. We believe that our results of operations, and particularly the results of operations during the periods
under review, have been primarily affected by the following factors.

82


-----

**_Demand drivers_**

Most of our businesses hold a leading position in their strategic market segments. A majority also have a
global leadership position, while others hold positions as regional market leaders. All our businesses operate in
growing markets with solid demand drivers.

The accelerating pace of change demands readiness and the ability to adapt. Identifying the crucial factors
and trends and then making the right priorities in product development and corporate strategy is more important
than ever in the effort to maintain and strengthen competitiveness. Since we manage a broad platform of
businesses and serve a wide range of end uses, while our individual businesses may be impacted by individual
factors or trends, we are not likely to be significantly affected at a Group level.

_Filtration_

The Filtration business develops and produces high-performance filtration materials from natural or
synthetic fibers or a combination thereof for transportation applications, such as engine oils, fuels, air used in
vehicles as well as industrial applications such as heating, ventilation and air conditioning and air pollution
control. The Filtration business also produces and is further developing solutions for hybrid and fully electric
vehicles. In transportation applications, sales are primarily generated by the aftermarket. In industrial end-uses,
sales are primarily generated by indoor air and cleanroom applications and gas turbine air intake applications.
Demand in the Filtration business is driven by mileage, growing truck and passenger car fleets, as well as more
stringent emission regulations and air quality standards. In transportation, demand is also driven by new filter
applications in electrical mobility. The Filtration business has also utilized production lines for the production of
face mask materials as a result of high demand caused by the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020.

_Nonwovens_

The Nonwovens business produces a wide range of nonwoven materials that are used for various
applications, including automotive interiors, plasterboards, hygiene, wallcover and wipes. The Nonwovens
business product range includes nonwovens backings, reinforcements and composite materials for automotive
interior, reinforcements for plasterboard, wetlaid specifically designed nonwovens for the apparel, fabric care,
hygiene, and wallcover markets, nonwovens for use as a base material for wound-care and wipes products. In the
construction industry, there has been growing demand for energy-efficient materials and technical plasterboard
solutions. We have also experienced a shift from paper to nonwoven wallcoverings, an increased use of
personalized design in high-end wallcoverings and a fast-growing digital print market. The Nonwovens business
is also driven in part by consumer spending.

_Glass Fiber Tissue_

The Glass Fiber Tissue business produces glass fiber tissue primarily for flooring applications, and a range
of building and transportation-related end-uses. Demand in the Glass Fiber Tissue business is driven by
construction and renovation activity. We have experienced a growing popularity of luxury vinyl tile flooring
solutions and an increase in the substitution from other flooring reinforcements such as mineral felt, especially in
North America.

_Abrasive_

The Abrasive business produces specialty papers used as backings for abrasive products used in industrial
and do-it-yourself sanding applications. Demand for abrasive products is driven by the automotive, wood,
furniture and construction industries. The Abrasive business also includes printing and surface treatment papers
for different backings. Demand for decorative printing and coating paper products is driven by interior designers.

_Medical_

The Medical business produces medical fabrics used in sterile barrier systems, drapes, gowns, facemasks
and sterilization wraps, all used primarily in surgery but also in cleanrooms and laboratories. Demand in the
Medical business is driven by the increase in high-risk surgeries, increasing liabilities related to infections and
contamination, rigorous regulatory requirements and the increasing use of single-use protection. In 2020, demand
for medical fabrics was fuelled by the COVID-19 pandemic.

83


-----

_Liquid Technologies_

The Liquid Technologies business produces high-quality filters for laboratory sample preparation and life
science diagnostics materials, used by laboratories and manufacturers of rapid test kits, in addition to highperformance filter media, an alternative to membrane technology, that has the ability to efficiently remove a wide
range of harmful contaminants for water purification devices. Other niches include hot cooking oil and milk
filtration applications. Demand in the Liquid Technologies business is driven by an increase in testing for
environmental and health monitoring. Consumers in the Liquid Technologies business seek patient-friendly
procedures that can be performed at home (or the point of care) and quick, cost-effective solutions for healthcare.
Demand is also driven by a desire for safer drinking water and rising quality standards for food and liquids. In
2020, diagnostics materials for rapid test kits and venting filters for devices used in the treatment of patients with
respiratory disorders were in strong demand.

_Beverage & Casing_

The Beverage & Casing business produces material for tea bags and coffee pods and casings, with a focus
on sustainability. Consumers are increasingly seeking sustainable alternatives. Demand is also driven by stricter
food safety and chemical regulations, and customer requests for more demanding packaging functionality and
barrier properties. In 2020, the negative impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on quick service restaurants has been
offset by increased at-home consumption.

_Tape_

The Tape business produces tape backings to masking and packaging specialty tape manufacturers used in
the construction and automotive industries and packaging applications for e-commerce and for specialty
purposes. Demand in the Tape business is driven by home construction and renovation activity, growth in
automotive and electronics industries and growth in e-commerce. In 2020, regional lockdowns and limited
mobility for citizens increased demand for packaging-related tape backings.

_Precision Coating_

The Precision Coating business produces a variety of release liners for specialty markets, including fiber
composites, medical and tape. The business focuses on technically demanding applications that leverage the
integration of our business and our coating expertise. Precision Coating continues to expand its capabilities to
meet the stringent guidelines for the aerospace and medical markets as well as sustainable non-release products
for a range of markets. Demand in the Precision Coating business is driven by the aerospace industry, aging
population driving product development in advanced wound care, the increased use of self-adhesive fasteners in
industrial and home applications and sustainable solutions in coating and substrates, which are driving the next
generation of products. Non-aerospace markets are showing signs of recovery following the slowdown caused by
the COVID-19 pandemic.

_Release Liners_

The Release Liners business produces papers that, after the customer coats the product with silicone, can be
used to carry self-adhesive labels or for manufacturing and assembling adhesive materials and components in
industrial processes. E-commerce drives the need for labels in tracking and identification, which further
increased in 2020 as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. Demand in the Release Liners business is also driven
by the growing use of self-adhesive labels, fastening systems and carriers in industrial processes and the
consumption of packaged food and beverages. In 2020 demand for packaging-related release liner increased.

_Coated Specialties_

The Coated Specialties business manufactures coated label papers, flexible packaging papers for fastmoving consumables and processed foods, as well as office, printing and writing papers. Demand for coated
papers in the Coated Specialties business is driven by rapid urbanization increasing the need for packaging and
the expansion of e-commerce is increasing the need for labels. Consumers are increasingly demanding
sustainable papers solutions to replace plastics films for use in flexible packaging and improved packaging
functionality, which in turn is driving the need for barriers, resistance and heat-sealability on paper. The Coated
Specialties business also experiences demand driven by fluoro-free regulatory requirements and by digital media
replacing traditional media.

84


-----

_Insulation_

The Insulation business supplies electrotechnical insulation papers to manufacturers of transformers and
high voltage cables globally. The Insulation business also produces thin papers used as interleaves, masking for
textile printing, balancing foils under the Spantex[TM] brand and specialty long-fiber pulp. Demand for
electrotechnical insulation paper is driven by extensions and upgrades to power distribution networks and the
decentralization of power generation and power grids. Urbanization and construction activity also drive power
equipment investments in this business.

_Food Packaging_

The Food Packaging business offers a broad range of specialty papers and capabilities for quick service
restaurants, food processing, cooking and baking, and flexible packaging markets. Demand in the Food
Packaging business is increasingly driven by demand for sustainability, recyclability, and compostability,
alternatives to single use-plastics and improved packaging functionality. Demand is also driven by stricter food
safety and chemical regulations.

_Parchment_

The Parchment business produces a broad portfolio of solutions for food and industrial applications. The
Parchment product portfolio includes cooking and baking papers, baking-trays and molds and food packaging
papers for fresh and greasy foods. Parchment is also used in the textile tube and furniture laminate industries as
well as in radio frequency identification and printed circuit board and copper clad lamination. Demand in the
Parchment business is driven by a push from brand-owners towards using sustainable alternatives. Food and
industrial markets have increasingly been seeking cellulosic solutions with intrinsic barrier properties and other
functionalities to replace plastics. In 2020, in particular, demand was driven by the increase of cooking and
baking at home caused by the COVID-19 pandemic and resulting lockdown measures.

_Technical_

The Technical business produces specialty products used for a wide variety of industrial and construction
applications. The product portfolio includes glass interleave papers, saturating bases, laminating bases, and other
industrial fiber-based solutions. Demand in the Technical business is driven by U.S. construction and
infrastructure activity, particularly homebuilding, and trends in residential and commercial building segments,
and changing building codes. The increased use of LCD/other displays and continuing need for higher quality
materials, desire for sustainable packaging, specifically in e-commerce and cold-chain applications, also drive
demand in this business.

_Decor_

The Decor business produces paper in a wide range of colors, grades and grammages for decorative
applications mainly used in laminated furniture, flooring and interior applications both for technical and
esthetical purposes. Demand in the Decor business is driven by the number of residential home starts,
commercial building projects and renovation. A rapidly growing middle class in developing markets is driving
construction and furniture demand. Demand in this business is also driven by interior design trends and trends of
substitution from solid wood to panel based furniture and, within panel-based furniture, substitution from veneer
and plastic foils to decor paper surfaces.

**_General economic conditions_**

The main end-user customer segments for our products and solutions include food and beverage processing
and packaging, transportation, homebuilding and furniture and the health care and life science industries. Growth
in our targeted markets is based on the general economic development with potential further upside from
increased value of new products or expanded product end-uses. Demand for our products is impacted by the
economic cycle. Lower end-use demand, stiffer competition and destocking in the value chain put pressure on
volumes and pricing, which in turn can have a negative impact on our financial results. To stay in tune with
changing market conditions, we monitor several factors in the operating environment. Each business has also
created its own strategy, taking specific trends relevant to its unique market into account. For example, some of
our businesses have been negatively impacted by the economic downturn that has followed the COVID-19
pandemic since the first quarter of 2020, but we also experienced strong demand in the healthcare and life
science end-use segments as solutions for personal protection equipment such as face masks, drapes and gowns,

85


-----

as well as diagnostics materials for rapid test kits and venting filters for devices used in the treatment of patients
with respiratory disorders were in strong demand. See “—Impact of COVID-19” below. Demand for products and
services distributed by us may also be affected, positively or negatively, by the economic conditions in the
regions and countries in which our end-customers operate. We believe that our global network of sales offices,
45 plants and converting sites in 14 countries and our more than 6,000 customers in over 100 countries helps us
manage the impact of events or situations specific to a given country.

**_Impact of COVID-19_**

On January 23, 2020, we initiated a centralized crisis alert team to carry out a global pandemic contingency
and preparedness response plan. We established a COVID-19 Safety Protocol to ensure safe operations and
customer service. Our manufacturing plants are maintaining a cohesive set of rules to keep operations running
and employees safe. Local adjustments are made according to country-level or local health and safety regulation
and guidance.

Our 45 plants and converting sites in 14 countries have remained operational during 2020, except for a few
temporary shutdowns caused by government lockdowns or employee absences related to quarantine or infections.
Production has not been interrupted to any significant extent due to raw material supply issues.

The impact of the pandemic on customer activity has varied. Since the first quarter of 2020, we have
experienced strong demand in the healthcare and life science end-use segments. Demand for solutions for
personal protection equipment such as face masks, drape and gown materials, as well as diagnostics materials for
rapid test kits and venting filters for devices used in the treatment of patients with respiratory disorders was
strong. This was primarily due to personal protection equipment shortages, which allowed us to shift sales of our
materials for such purposes even though they are more expensive than standard viral protection materials, and
despite the demand for the more typical uses for drape and gown materials having decreased in line with the
decreased number of surgeries. The exceptional circumstances, with regional lockdowns and limited mobility for
citizens, also increased demand for packaging-related release liner and packaging tape applications. In the second
quarter of 2020, demand for home building and furniture, transportation and industrial end-uses decreased due to
a large portion of the global population being in lockdown. In the third quarter of 2020, demand recovered in
home building and furniture, driven mainly by increased household furniture spending, as well as transportation
end uses. Towards the end of 2020, demand for industrial-related products improved. Overall demand for
consumer goods related applications, of which food and beverage and packaging represent the largest share,
remained relatively stable, but varied somewhat, depending on end use. The resurgence of the COVID-19
pandemic in the fourth quarter of 2020 caused many countries to reimpose restrictions, but these lighter and more
regional lockdowns did not have a material impact on demand in the fourth quarter of 2020.

The COVID-19 pandemic has created an exceptional situation globally and a strong demand for healthcare
goods in general, and particularly for protective medical products made from our fabrics. We have long been an
established manufacturer of nonwoven fabrics, which are used to construct protective medical fabrics such as
surgical gowns and drapes, pleated surgical face masks, protective apparel and sterile barrier systems. We have
produced the inner and outer coverstock used for pleated surgical face masks, and has recently begun to produce
the middle filter media. Thanks to our in-depth knowledge of filtration materials and common manufacturing
platform, we were able to respond swiftly to growing demand by expanding manufacturing of face mask fabrics
to lines normally used for producing other fiber-based materials. As of the second quarter of 2020, our offering
includes a full range of protective face mask fabrics for civil, surgical and respiratory masks. This allowed us to
fill production capacity that would have otherwise remained unused, in particular during the second and third
quarters of 2020. During the second half of 2020, our delivery volumes of face mask fabrics gradually decreased
as production and export of face masks from China resumed and global availability and price competition
increased.

**_Average Selling Price and Product Mix_**

The average selling prices we are able to obtain for our products and solutions affect our margin on variable
costs of our products and our results of operations. Our results are also affected by changes in the mix of
products sold from period to period due to different margin on variable costs associated with the different
products. Interchangeable materials and products that can replace our products, as well as new producers that
establish themselves within our product areas, can impact both price and volume. Our comparable EBITDA
margin varies based on the business. While some of our product groups in the Release Liners, Coated Specialties
and Decor businesses are more competitive and have a lower degree of differentiation, we target selected niche
markets that require technical specialization with high barriers to entry and value-based pricing. A common

86


-----

denominator is that they are fiber-based with a high degree of complexity and technical content. Products and
solutions that are more technical and complex, as well as customized, are typically characterized by higher
margins. In less differentiated product groups, cost efficiency is increasingly important. Margin on variable costs
has developed favorably in the periods under review as we successfully implemented our commercial strategy
that focuses on product differentiation, service and quality and optimized price and product mix. We also
continued to introduce several new value-adding products for our customers. Our sales from New Products
increased to 12% for the year ended December 31, 2020. We aim to continue to increase the percentage of our
net sales attributable to sales of New Products. In 2020, our net sales decreased due to an adverse currency effect,
lower selling prices and a less favorable product mix, although Comparable EBITDA margin increased to 12.5%,
due to lower costs.

**_Strategic acquisitions and divestments_**

We regularly evaluate opportunities for acquisition and expansion. Our aim is to grow our businesses
through both organic investments and acquisitions that add geographical scope, new technologies or customer
categories, which can lead to volume increase, customer retention or improved margins. In addition, we
undertake acquisitions to improve positions within existing markets, support expansion in growth markets or to
enter new markets. In October 2018, we completed the bolt-on acquisitions of Expera Specialty Solutions
Holdings, Inc., an U.S. based specialty paper producer (“Expera Specialty Solutions”), for a cash consideration of
€524.9 million, and MD Papéis’ Caieiras specialty paper mill in Brazil (“Caieiras”), for a cash consideration of

Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras, exceeding the initial target of €14 million and actions implemented
during 2020, which were delayed due to the COVID-19 related lockdowns and travel restrictions, generated a
further €2 million of synergies.

In 2019, we completed the acquisition of filter converting capacity to grow the Liquid Technologies

Our regular assessment of the best structure of our platform of businesses resulted in the divestment of two
