business in Mikkeli, Finland in 2019. In addition, we are actively considering strategic alternatives in relation to
our entire Decor paper business, including any potential ownership in Minglian, where one of the options being
investigated the possibility of divestment of the Decor business.

Acquisitions and disposals can impact our sales and our profitability by changing the scope of our business
year on year. They can also lead to integration costs (and capital expenditure) in the year of acquisition or in
subsequent years depending on the time taken to integrate these companies in a country in which we already
operate. We have extensive experience from successful integration processes and realized synergies.

**_Raw materials and energy_**

We operate in a resource-intensive manufacturing industry and costs and availability of raw materials
impact our performance. Our primary raw materials are commodity pulp, wood to produce pulp, other renewable
fibers, various synthetic fibers including glass and plastic as well as chemicals including titanium dioxide and
energy. Volatility, price increase and the availability of raw materials, particularly commodity pulp and wood,
impact our margin on variable costs of our products and affect our financial results. We use different types of
pulp, such as long, short fiber and specialty pulps, in our production. We work with a reasonably large number of
suppliers to secure the diverse inputs needed. Our commodity pulp consumption was approximately
1,200 thousand tons for the year ended December 31, 2020. Our pulp exposure was reduced by approximately
500 thousand tons of our own pulp production during the year ended December 31, 2020, which includes
185 thousand tons of market pulp production at our Aspa pulp mill in Sweden that is sold to third parties. There
is a structured process for the procurement of pulp, which is managed globally. This structured procurement
process creates conditions for better service and lower costs, and it also requires less administration and allows
improved consistency of practices to better ensure compliance.

Energy costs also represent a significant portion of the production costs. We mainly consume electricity,
gas, coal and oil. Changes in prices or availability of energy may increase or decrease our operating costs, as
applicable, and impact our operating results and margins.

In order to drive EBITDA growth and to support our margins, we implemented a savings program focused
on variable cost reduction through procurement savings and other improvement actions. The savings program
was completed ahead of schedule and exceeded the initial target of €50 million. Raw material and energy prices
negatively impacted results in 2019. In 2020, our profitability benefitted from lower raw material prices and was
supported by our cost-saving measures.

**_Innovation_**

As a niche player, innovation, identifying trends and developing new customer solutions is increasingly
important in ensuring our future competitiveness. We have extensive research and development capabilities in
each business area. R&D in the business areas is carried out in the production processes at the various plants and
in collaboration with customers. We also operate two R&D facilities in France, one in Pont-Evêque and one in
Apprieu. The innovation and product development resources have been significantly strengthened through the
merger of Ahlstrom and Munksjö as well as through the recent acquisitions of Expera Specialty Solutions and
Caieiras. In addition, marketing, sales and customer service organizations all form integral parts of the R&D
process by supporting the understanding of what areas of development to give priority to, what improvements in
qualities are needed, and what new applications are sought after by customers. We have a strong product
development platform and we aim to increase the amount of sales generated from New Products in the coming

88


-----

years. In 2020, approximately 12% of our net sales were attributable to New Products. We plan to continue to
launch new products that add value for our customers. Examples of new sustainable products included Extia[®]
launched in 2019, a filtration material designed to extend the lifetime of air pollution applications, CelluStraw, a
plastic-free renewable material for drinking straws also launched in 2019, and a FortiCell[®] LAB, a range of high
performance fiber-based solutions for energy storage applications launched in 2020 and TenderGuard[™]
BioBased launch in 2021 as an alternative to fossil based media for face masks applications.

We are committed to sustainability and we have integrated sustainable practices throughout our value chain.
It is also an important driver in most of our markets. Our areas of research include improved sustainability, which
involves making existing products more environmentally friendly by, for example, making them compostable,
recyclable or using lower amounts or different chemicals. One of our strategic directions is to develop barrier
papers based on biopolymers to offer biodegradable packaging media. Other areas of research include various
forms of nanocellulose, which is renewable and biodegradable, has a wide range of applications and we expect it
will compete with plastics and other nondegradable materials in many areas. Our goal is to create new materials
for electrotechnical insulation to manufacturers of transformers and high voltage cables. We also focus on
researching biopolymers, which are bi-products of the pulp used in production. Biopolymers are used for
enhancing current paper products. In 2020, our expenditure on R&D, comprising of R&D expenses and
capitalized R&D costs, was €27.2 million, representing 1% of our net sales, excluding technical product
development costs carried out in close cooperation with customers.

**_Capital expenditures_**

Our Capital expenditures are key to maintaining our competitiveness and enhanced production capability,
and also represent an important driver of our results of operations. Our Capital expenditures for the years ended
December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020 were €160.1 million, €161.1 million and €117.5 million, respectively,
partially driven by our €200 million strategic investment program that we have been progressing since 2017 and
which includes investments in 13 projects (11 have been completed while the remaining are scheduled to be
completed during 2021 and 2022). These investments aim to increase and improve our production capabilities
and to allow us to grow while retaining attractive cash flows. A significant proportion of our Capital expenditures
in 2018 and 2019 were related to projects undertaken in the Filtration business in Madisonville, United States,
the Abrasive business in Arches, France, the Parchment business in San Severin, France, and the Coated
Specialties business in Jacareí, Brazil, and a boiler and pulp line rebuild in our plant in Billingsfors, Sweden, part
of the Insulation business. Given these significant investments in increasing capacity and improving
manufacturing capabilities, we believe our production facilities are relatively well-invested and that we are wellpositioned to support future growth. We estimate our Maintenance capital expenditure as approximately 3% of
our net sales, and we estimate that approximately €90 million of annual capital expenditures (including IT
spending) are required to maintain the competitiveness of our current portfolio which supports our product
capability.

**_Currency Exchange Rates_**

_Transactional_

Due to our global operations, we generate a portion of our revenue, and incur a portion of our expenses, in
currencies other than the euro, which are primarily U.S. dollar, Swedish krona, Chinese renminbi, Brazilian real,
British pound sterling and South Korean won. As a result of Ahlstrom Munksjö’s increased presence in the
United States, we are particularly exposed to fluctuations in the exchange rate of the U.S. dollar. A large share of
operating expenses is in euro and U.S. dollars. In addition, purchase prices of pulp, chemicals and freight are
primarily based on U.S. dollar. However, the significant operations in the United States and the denomination of
key raw materials and freight in U.S. dollars create a natural hedge. During the periods under review, we hedged
approximately 75% of forecasted cash flows for a period up to nine months if the total exposure to forecasted net
flows of foreign currency exceeds the equivalent of 2% of the total turnover of the company. As of December 31,
2020, the fair value of the forwards under hedge accounting was €4.2 million. See note 19 to the 2020 Financial
Statements for further information on currency risk and the use of derivative instruments and hedging activities.

We may also be exposed to currency transaction risks through firm commitments to buy businesses. For
instance, in 2018, we hedged a portion ($300 million nominal) of the U.S. dollar-denominated firm commitment
to acquire Expera Specialty Solutions in latter part of 2018 by using a foreign exchange forward contract. The
gain on hedge amounted to €4.4 million which was recorded as an adjustment to the purchase consideration.

89


-----

In addition, following the Transactions, a large portion of our indebtedness will be denominated in
U.S. dollars. Strengthening of the euro against the U.S. dollar will result in a decrease in the euro value of our
U.S. dollar-denominated indebtedness and vice versa. As adjusted to give effect to the Transactions and the
Offering, a significant portion of our indebtedness will be denominated in U.S. dollars.

_Translational_

We report our consolidated financial statements in our functional currency, which is the euro. As a result,
the assets, liabilities, net sales and expenses of all of our operations with a currency other than the euro are
translated into euro at then applicable exchange rates. Consequently, increases or decreases in the value of the
euro affect the value of these items with respect to the non-euro-denominated businesses in the consolidated
financial statements, even if their value has not changed in their original currency. For example, a stronger euro
will reduce the reported results of operations of non-euro businesses and conversely a weaker euro will increase
the reported results of operations of non-euro businesses. While we aim to minimize currency risk related to
translation exposure by aiming to balance assets and liabilities of subsidiaries so that the foreign exchange risk is
minimized in the consolidated balance sheet, these translations could affect the comparability of our results
between financial periods or result in changes to the carrying value of our assets, liabilities and shareholders’
equity. Exchange differences on translation of foreign operations during 2020 amounted to €78.3 million and is
recognized in the other comprehensive income line item.

**Factors Affecting the Comparability of the Financial Statements**

**_Presentation of the Income Statement_**

On January 1, 2020, we changed the presentation of its income statement to the function of expense method
from the nature of expense to align with its internal reporting. The comparative income statement information for
the year ended December 31, 2019 in the 2020 Financial Statements has been restated according to the function
of expense method to facilitate comparability and is unaudited. The income statement was presented using the
nature of expense method in the 2019 Financial Statements and in the 2018 Financial Statements. In connection
with the adoption of the function of expense method, certain minor reclassifications and changes in names of
income statement items have been made in the 2020 Financial Statements. As a result of these reclassifications,
net sales for the year ended December 31, 2019 decreased by €1.0 million from the previous year and other
operating income for the year ended December 31, 2019 increased by €8.6 million from the previous year. These
reclassifications had no impact on Ahlstrom-Munksjö’s operating result or net result for the year ended
December 31, 2019. In the 2020 Financial Statements, certain income statement line items were also renamed,
such as net profit to net result and profit before tax to result before tax. As a result, the 2019 Financial Statements
and the 2018 Financial Statements are not directly comparable with the 2020 Financial Statements or the 2019
comparative, unaudited, restated column presented therein. In order to provide meaningful comparable financial
information in this Offering Memorandum, income statement information for the year ended December 31, 2019
is presented on an audited historical basis when comparing to the financial information for the year ended
December 31, 2018, and, otherwise, is extracted without adjustment from the unaudited, restated comparative
column included in the 2020 Financial Statements. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—
_Ahlstrom-Munksjo¨—Comparability of the Financial Statements—Presentation of Income Statement.”_

**_Changes to Reportable Segments_**

In 2019, we decided to implement a new business structure, which became effective on January 1, 2020, to
promote core business capabilities and sharpen strategic targets and align the business characteristics of each
business area. For periods after January 1, 2020, our five business areas comprise Filtration & Performance
Solutions, Advance Solutions, Industrial Solutions, Food Packaging & Technical Solutions, and Decor Solutions,
which also form our operating and reporting segments. For periods prior to January 1, 2020, our five business
areas comprised Filtration & Performance Solutions, Industrial Solutions, Decor, Specialties, and North
American Specialty Solutions.

In the new structure, North America Specialty Solutions is integrated into the operating platform and
businesses are partly reorganized to reflect our expansion in North America following the initial integration
phase of the North America Specialty Solutions business. The new business structure is comprised of sixteen
businesses that underlie each business area as compared to fourteen businesses under the previous structure. In
the 2020 Financial Statements, we have restated our presentation of the financial information of our business

90


-----

areas for the comparative year ended December 31, 2019 to reflect its new business structure and the restated
financial information is unaudited. However, no business area financial information for any prior period has been
restated and the business area financial information for the year ended December 31, 2018 is presented based on
our previous business areas and is not comparable to the business area information presented in the 2020
Financial Statements. In order to provide meaningful comparable information in this Offering Memorandum, we
present the financial information for the business areas for the year ended December 31, 2019 based on the prior
business areas when comparing to the financial information for the year ended December 31, 2018, and,
otherwise, based on the new business areas. See note 4 to the 2020 Financial Statements for further information
on our new business area information.

_Segment Reporting Principles_

Our CEO, assisted by the Executive Management Team, is our chief operating decision maker. Operating
segments are determined on the basis of information reviewed by the CEO for the purposes of allocating
resources and assessing our business area’s performance. The business area’s performance is assessed internally
on the basis of net sales and Comparable EBITDA. Comparable EBITDA is defined for internal management
reporting purposes as operating result before depreciation, amortization and impairments and excluding items
affecting comparability.

For the year ended December 31, 2018 and following the acquisitions of Expera Specialty Solutions and
Caieiras, each business area’s performance was assessed internally on the basis of its net sales and Comparable
EBITDA, in each case pro forma for the acquisitions of Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras. Net sales, pro
forma for the acquisitions of Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras, is defined for internal management
reporting purposes as net sales giving pro forma effect to the net sales impact of the acquisitions of Expera
Specialty Solutions and Caieiras. Comparable EBITDA pro forma for the acquisitions of Expera Specialty
Solutions and Caieiras is defined for internal reporting purposes as EBITDA excluding certain items affecting
comparability and giving pro forma effect to the acquisitions of Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras. The pro
forma impact of the acquisitions of Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras on net sales and Comparable
EBITDA for internal management reporting purposes is presented as if Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras
had been consolidated to full-year results for the year ended December 31, 2018.

**_Acquisitions and Divestments_**

We acquired Expera Specialty Solutions, a U.S. based specialty paper producer, on October 10, 2018, and
Caieiras, a specialty paper mill in Brazil, on October 17, 2018. Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras were
consolidated into our historical consolidated financial statements from their respective dates of acquisition. The
income statement or statement of cash flows for any period prior to such dates do not include the impact of such
acquisitions. As a result, given the magnitude of the acquisitions of Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras, the
historical consolidated income statement and cash flow information for 2018 are not comparable to such
information for any subsequent period. Business area net sales and Comparable EBITDA for the year ended
December 31, 2018 is presented herein in accordance with IFRS 8 (Operating Segments) based on internal
management reporting information giving effect to the impact of the acquisitions of Expera Specialty Solutions
and Caieiras and is thus on a comparable basis to such information for the year ended December 31, 2019. See
also “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Ahlstrom-Munksjo¨—Comparability of the Financial
_Statements—Acquisitions and Disposals—Acquisitions of Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras.”_

In addition, we made an acquisition to grow our highly profitable Liquid Technologies business in 2019 and
completed two divestments in 2020. As a result, our consolidated financial information may not be comparable
following the date of such acquisition or divestments.

**_Other Changes to Accounting Policies_**

_Adoption of IFRS 16_

We adopted IFRS 16 (Leases) on January 1, 2019. The new standard resulted in the recognition of the
majority of our leases on the balance sheet and therefore our assets and liabilities have increased. The adoption of
IFRS 16 increased right-of-use assets by €57.0 million, non-current liabilities by €44.1 million and current
liabilities by €12.3 million in the opening balance sheet as of January 1, 2019. The impact on EBITDA for the
year ended December 31, 2019 was €16.3 million, as the formal rental charges are reflected in depreciation and
interest expense under IFRS 16. We have adopted the new standard using a simplified approach and thus
comparative figures are not restated. See notes 1, 8, 9 and 12 to the 2019 Financial Statements for more
information.

91


-----

_Adoption of IFRIC 23_

As of January 1, 2019, we adopted IFRIC 23 (Uncertainty over Income Tax Treatments). As a result of the
adoption of IFRIC 23, we recognized an adjustment in an amount of €2.6 million to increase our income tax
liabilities and to decrease retained earnings at January 1, 2019. Our financial statements as of and for the year
ended December 31, 2018 do not apply IFRIC 23. As a result, the results of operations for the year ended
December 31, 2018 may not be directly comparable with the results of operations for the years ended
December 31, 2019 and 2020.

_Reclassification of certain balance sheet items_

In 2019, Ahlstrom-Munksjö changed the classification of certain balance sheet items between interestbearing and non-interest-bearing liabilities. The comparative information as of December 31, 2018 has been
restated accordingly. The restatement as of December 31, 2018 from current borrowings to trade and other
payables amounted to €8.8 million. In 2019, lease liabilities were also reclassified from borrowings to a separate
line item, and lease liabilities as of December 31, 2018 were restated accordingly. The lease liabilities as of
December 31, 2018 relate to finance leases in accordance with previously used IAS 17 (Leases) and the related
interpretations, which were replaced by IFRS 16 as of January 1, 2019. The restated information is unaudited.

**_Impact of the Transactions_**

On October 22, 2020, the Issuer launched the Tender Offer to acquire up to all of the Company Shares for
cash consideration equal to the Tender Offer Price. On February 4, 2021, the first settlement under the Tender
Offer occurred and the Issuer acquired approximately 81.0% of the Company Shares. On February 10, 2021, the
second settlement under the Tender Offer occurred and the Issuer acquired approximately 9.6% of the Company
Shares. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, 2021, the Issuer owned approximately 90.6% of the
Company Shares. See “Summary—The Transactions—The Acquisition—The Tender Offer.” Consequently, our
consolidated financial information following the Transactions will not be fully comparable with our historical
consolidated financial information due to, among other things, (i) the application of purchase accounting from
the date of acquisition in connection with the Acquisition, (ii) changes to depreciation and amortization expenses,
among other things, that may result from the purchase accounting of the Acquisition, (iii) additional interest
expense associated with the financing of the Transactions (including the refinancing of certain of AhlstromMunksjö’s existing debt), and (iv) changes to the level of consolidation of our results in the future, following a
de-listing (if any). See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Ahlstrom-Munksjo¨—Comparability of
_the Financial Statements—Impact of the Transactions.”_

**Components of Our Historical Results of Operations**

**_Year ended December 31, 2020 and unaudited, restated comparative information for the year ended_**
**_December 31, 2019_**

Our historical results of operations for the years ended December 31, 2020, which includes the unaudited,
restated comparative information for the year ended December 31, 2019 comprise the following components. See
“—Factors Affecting the Comparability of the Financial Statements—Presentation of the Income Statement.”

_Net sales_

Net sales comprise the sale of manufactured products, including filter materials, release liners, food and
beverage processing materials, decor papers, abrasive and tape backings, electrotechnical paper, glass fiber
materials, medical fiber materials and solutions for diagnostics as well as a range of specialty materials for
industrial and consumer end-uses, through our five business areas. Revenue from these sales is recognized based
on the price specified in the contract, net of estimated discounts and refunds.

_Cost of goods sold_

Cost of goods sold includes costs of producing inventories that have been sold to third parties, delivery
expenses, impairment of inventories, repair and maintenance, operative exchange gains/losses including the
impact of foreign exchange derivatives and general overhead expenses of our production and supply function
which are expensed as incurred.

_Gross profit_

Gross profit represents net sales minus cost of goods sold.

92


-----

_Sales and marketing expenses_

Sales and marketing expenses include costs of selling products, customer service, marketing and
promotional expenses.

_R&D expenses_

R&D expenses include the expenses of our R&D facilities and expenses related to innovation and product
development.

_Administrative expenses_

Administrative expenses include expenses of the General Management, Finance, Corporate Strategy and
Development, Legal, Communications and Investor Relations, Human Resources and Information Systems
functions.

_Other operating income_

Other operating income includes gain from disposal of assets, gain on sale of emission rights, sale of scrap
and side products and regular incomes, such as rental and lease income and gain relating to business
combinations. Other operating income also includes grants. Government grants are recognized in the income
statement in the same period as the costs they are intended to compensate. Government grants relating to the
purchase of property, plant and equipment are deducted from the cost of the assets and accordingly reduce the
depreciation of the underlying asset.

_Other operating expense_

Other operating expense includes depreciation and amortization from purchase price allocations, losses from
disposal of assets, bad debt allowances and other costs not directly related to production or sale of products.

_Net financial items_

Net financial items is comprised of financial income net of financial expenses.

_Financial income_

Financial income is mainly comprised of exchange rate gains on financing items.

_Financial expenses_

Financial costs mainly consist of interest expense on bank loans and bonds.

_Income taxes_

Income taxes is comprised of current tax and deferred tax. Tax is recognized in the income statement except
when underlying transactions are reported in other comprehensive income, or directly in equity, in which case the
associated tax effect is reported in other comprehensive income or directly in equity.

**_Years ended December 31, 2019 and December 31, 2018_**

Our historical results of operations for the years ended December 31, 2019 and December 31, 2018
comprise the following components. See “—Factors Affecting the Comparability of the Financial Statements—
_Presentation of the Income Statement.”_

_Net sales_

Net sales comprise the sale of manufactured products, including filter materials, release liners, food and
beverage processing materials, decor papers, abrasive and tape backings, electrotechnical paper, glass fiber
materials, medical fiber materials and solutions for diagnostics as well as a range of specialty materials for
industrial and consumer end-uses, through our five business areas. Revenue from these sales is recognized based
on the price specified in the contract, net of the estimated discounts and refunds.

-----

_Other operating income_

Other operating income includes government grants, sale of scrap products and materials, research and
development and other tax credits, gain on sale of fixed assets, rental and lease income, insurance compensation
and other income. See note 5 to the 2019 Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum
for further information.

_Changes in inventories of finished goods and work in progress_

Changes in investors of finished goods and work in progress includes the change in value of inventories in
the balance sheet during the period.

_Materials and supplies_

Materials and supplies includes the cost of raw materials such as wood pulp, titanium dioxide and other
chemicals and raw materials used in production.

_Other operating expenses_

Other operating expenses includes the cost of production incurred by us in the manufacture and sale of our
product offerings, but excluding the cost of materials and supplies and employee benefit expenses. The largest
component of other operating expenses is energy costs, which are incurred in the production process.

_Employee benefit expenses_

Employee benefit expenses includes wages, salaries and other remuneration and indirect employee costs of
our employees and executive management, including pensions and other benefits, which may include company
cars, housing, schooling fees and health insurance.

_Depreciation, amortization and impairment_

Depreciation, amortization and impairment comprises depreciation, amortization and impairment of
intangible assets, property, plant, equipment and right-of-use assets.

_Share of profit in equity accounted investments_

Share of profit in equity accounted investments is comprised of profits earned through equity investments in
its associate company in Sweden, Sydved AB.

_Net financial items_

Net financial items is comprised of financial income net of financial expenses.

_Financial income_

Financial income is mainly comprised of exchange rate gains on financing items.

_Financial expenses_

Financial costs mainly consist of interest expense on bank loans and bonds.

_Income taxes_

Income taxes is comprised of current tax and deferred tax. Tax is recognized in the income statement except
when underlying transactions are reported in other comprehensive income, or directly in equity, in which case the
associated tax effect is reported in other comprehensive income or directly in equity.

_Net sales_

Net sales for the year ended December 31, 2020 decreased by €232.0 million, or 8.0%, to €2,683.3 million,
from €2,915.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. The decrease was primarily due to adverse
currency effects, lower selling prices and a less favorable product mix, including due to COVID-19, as well as
divestments of the glass fiber reinforcement and fine arts businesses. In terms of product mix, deliveries
increased significantly in healthcare and life science-related end-uses, and grew modestly in consumer goods
related end-uses. Deliveries decreased in transportation and industrial related applications and fell slightly in
home-building and furniture-related end-uses.

- Filtration & Performance Solutions

Net sales in the Filtration & Performance Solutions business area decreased by €87.0 million, or 12.0%, to
€637.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €724.0 million for the year ended December 31,
2019. This decrease was primarily due to lower sales volumes, particularly in the Filtration business and the
divestments of the glass fiber reinforcement and fine arts businesses, which had an impact of approximately
€43.0 million on net sales. Filtration & Performance Solutions saw a large cyclical decline in the year ended
December 31, 2020 due to COVID-19 induced end-market weaknesses. Demand for filtration materials gradually
recovered in the second half of 2020 following a decline in the second quarter. In particular, face mask material
deliveries compensated for temporarily lower demand in the second and third quarters of 2020 as a result of the
COVID-19 pandemic. Demand for glass fiber flooring, abrasive backings, wallcovers and plasterboard materials
also improved in 2020 compared with 2019. Demand in Filtration & Performance Solutions in 2020 was also
supported in part by new product launches, including FibRoc[®], a new product platform of high performance
solutions for durable applications and the launch of product portfolio for lead acid batteries under the FortiCell
range of fiber-based solutions for energy storage applications.

- Advanced Solutions

Net sales in the Advanced Solutions business area increased by €5.9 million, or 1.3%, to €476.2 million for
the year ended December 31, 2020, from €470.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase
was primarily due to higher selling prices and volumes, largely offset by an adverse currency effect. Deliveries
increased in all businesses except Precision Coating, where they decreased significantly primarily due to the
impact on the aerospace industry. Advanced Solutions experienced a strong demand for medical and life science
products and demand growth for tap backings, tea and coffee materials and fibrous meat casing materials,
partially offset by weakened demand for specialty release liners due to low aerospace activity. Demand for
Advanced Solutions products was supported by the launch of Trustshield Biological, a personal protective
apparel medical fabric designed to shield against hazardous pathogens and our partnership with BUFF, a
producer of sport and lifestyle accessories, for the supply of replaceable filter media in face masks.

- Industrial Solutions

Net sales in the Industrial Solutions business area decreased by €81.8 million, or 10.7%, to €683.9 million
for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €765.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This decrease
was primarily due to lower selling prices and an adverse currency effect. The lower selling prices were, in part,
driven by pulp price decline during this period. We experienced a growth in demand for release liners for labels
and improving demand for industrial grades following a weaker second quarter in 2020. There was also a
recovery in demand for electrotechnical and steel interleaving papers in the fourth quarter of 2020 and an
improvement in demand for coated papers, particularly in Brazil, after a decline in the second quarter. We also
completed the investment in a new power co-generation plant at the Turin site in Italy.

97


-----

- Food Packaging & Technical Solutions

Net sales in the Food Packaging & Technical Solutions business area decreased by €27.8 million, or 4.8%,
to €554.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €582.4 million for the year ended December 31,
2019. This decrease was primarily due to lower delivery volumes, particularly in the Technical business and an
adverse currency effect. Average selling prices were also lower and were partly impacted by a less favorable
product mix. Demand for food processing and packaging continued to improve in 2020, following a mild
rebound in restaurant traffic later in the year. There was robust demand for parchment cooking and baking papers
in North America and flexible packaging products sold in grocery stores. Demand for specialty papers in
industrial and construction applications rebounded in the fourth quarter of 2020.

- Decor Solutions

Net sales in the Decor Solutions business area decreased by €49.9 million, or 11.9%, to €369.7 million for
the year ended December 31, 2020, from €419.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This decrease
was primarily due to significantly low delivery volumes in the second quarter of 2020, lower selling prices and
an adverse currency effect. The lower selling prices were driven by declining raw material prices (titanium
dioxide and pulp). After a market recovery from 2019 in the first quarter of 2020, demand for decor paper
dropped at the end of March, following the closures of retail furniture outlets as a result of the COVID-19
pandemic. In the second half of 2020, there was a strong market recovery, following their re-opening. Similarly,
there was broad-based downtime for decor paper customers and end-customers from mid-March to mid-June but
strong recovery in demand in the second half of 2020. While demand in office and shop furniture was weak,
there was strong demand in the home furniture and home renovation segments during the summer and fall
driving orders in the second half of the year.

_Cost of goods sold_

Cost of goods sold for the year ended December 31, 2020 decreased by €274.7 million, or 10.8%, to
€2,269.5 million, from €2,544.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This decrease was primarily due
to lower raw material, production costs, energy costs, delivery expenses and other variable costs due to our
€50 million cost savings program that was initiated in 2020 and focused on variable cost reduction through
procurement savings and other improvement actions was completed ahead of schedule and exceeded targets.

_Sales and marketing expenses_

Sales and marketing expenses for the year ended December 31, 2020 decreased by €11.5 million, or 16.8%,
to €56.7 million, from €68.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to
COVID-19 related fixed-cost savings in the year ended December 31, 2020 and inclusion of integration costs
related to Expera and restructuring costs, in the year ended December 31, 2019.

_R&D expenses_

R&D expenses for the year ended December 31, 2020 increased by €5.8 million, or 37.8%, to €21.0 million,
from €15.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to increased R&D
depreciation and decrease in R&D project capitalization.

_Administrative expenses_

Administrative expenses increased by €2.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, or 1.3%, to
€151.6 million, from €149.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to
cost inflation and costs related to the sale of the fine arts paper business and the Tender Offer, partially offset by
COVID-19 related fixed-cost savings.

_Other operating income_

Other operating income increased by €33.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, or 159.9%, to
€53.8 million, from €20.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to a
gain from the sale of the fine arts business in Arches, France and an increase in government grants comprising
mostly of energy subsidies and other government incentives, partially offset by a reduction in gains on sale of
emission rights and other environmental rights in the year ended December 31, 2020.

_Other operating expense_

Other operating expense increased by €6.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, or 11.6%, to
€62.4 million, from €55.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. The increase was primarily due to
higher impairment loss related to machinery and equipment in Stenay, France, an old gas turbine in Turin, Italy
and a right-of-use asset office building in Sweden.

_Share of profit in equity accounted investments_

Share of profit in equity accounted investments remained stable at €0.2 million.

_Net financial items_

Net financial items decreased by €5.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, or 11.3%, to an
expense of €45.7 million, from an expense of €51.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This decrease
was primarily due to a decrease in net interest expenses by €11.1 million due to lower interest rates and a
currency exchange loss of €2.2 million.

_Net result_

Net result increased by €61.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, or 187.7%, to €94.5 million,
from €32.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily as a result of the factors discussed above.

 - Decor

After a long period of destocking and lower end-use demand, demand for decor paper recovered in the
fourth quarter of 2019. Due to weak demand and eroding raw material prices, price pressure and competition
were significant in 2019. Net sales in the Decor business area increased by €14.2 million, or 3.5%, to
€422.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, from net sales of €407.9 million for the year ended
December 31, 2018. The increase was mainly due to the acquisition of Caieiras in October 2018. Net sales in the
Decor business area decreased by €29.8 million, or 6.6%, to €422.1 million for the year ended December 31,
2019, from net sales of €451.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2018 as presented based on internal
management reporting giving effect to the impact of the acquisition of Caieiras as if it had been consolidated in
the results for the full year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was mainly due to lower sales volumes.
While prices fell during 2019, reflecting a decrease in key raw material costs, the average selling price for the
year was stable. The positive impact of lower variable costs was offset by increased fixed cost per ton.

- Filtration & Performance Solutions

Demand for filtration products, and transportation especially, remained at a low level in Europe and the
Americas, while improved in Asia. In construction-related markets, demand for plasterboard, flooring and other
glass fiber tissue end-uses remained solid, while the wallcoverings market in Europe weakened. Net sales in the
Filtration & Performance Solutions business area increased by €3.5 million, or 0.5%, to €665.6 million for the
year ended December 31, 2019, from €662.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. The increase was
mainly due to the acquisitions of Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras in October 2018. Net sales in the
Filtration & Performance Solutions business area decreased by €7.0 million, or 1.0%, to €665.6 million for the
year ended December 31, 2019, from €672.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018 as presented based
on internal management reporting giving effect to the impact of the acquisitions of Expera Specialty Solutions
and Caieiras as if these had been consolidated in the results for the full year ended December 31, 2018. Lower
sales volumes were partially offset by higher selling prices, an improved product mix and a favorable currency
effect.

101


-----

- Industrial Solutions

Demand for release liners improved for some grades in the second half of 2019, while the market
environment remained competitive. Demand for electrotechnical insulation and interleaving papers remained
stable, while demand for specialty pulp improved during the fourth quarter. The markets for abrasive backings
and coated products were weak with improving signs for coated products in Brazil towards the end of the year.
Net sales in the Industrial Solutions business area decreased by €9.1 million, or 1.4%, to €653.5 million for the
year ended December 31, 2019, from net sales of €662.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. Net
sales in the Industrial Solutions business area decreased by €37.8 million, or 5.5%, to €653.5 million for the year
ended December 31, 2019, from net sales of €691.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2018 as presented
based on internal management reporting giving effect to the impact of the acquisitions of Expera Specialty
Solutions and Caieiras as if these had been consolidated in the results for the full year ended December 31, 2018.
This decrease was mainly due to lower volumes in the paper businesses and lower selling prices for specialty
pulp.

- North America Specialty Solutions

Demand for food processing and packaging papers was stable in 2019, while the markets for industrial and
technical specialty papers remained soft. In the release liner segment, demand in commodity grades remained
weak and was impacted by new capacity and intensified competition, while demand for coated products
remained relatively solid. Net sales in the North American Specialty Solutions business area increased by
€506.1 million, or 373.7%, to €641.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, from net sales of
€135.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. The increase was mainly due to the acquisitions of Expera
Specialty Solutions and Caieiras in October 2018. Net sales in the North American Specialty Solutions business
area increased by €15.5 million, or 2.5%, to €641.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, from net sales
of €626.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2018 as presented based on internal management reporting
giving effect to the impact of the acquisitions of Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras as if these had been
consolidated in the results for the full year ended December 31, 2018. The increase was driven by higher selling
prices and a favorable currency effect. Deliveries were lower in 2019.

- Specialties

In the Food Packaging business, demand for parchment papers for food processing and packaging remained
weak in 2019. Beverage markets improved and demand for fibrous meat casing materials remained strong.
Demand for tape backings in Europe and North America was weaker in 2019, while it continued to be strong in
Asia. In the Advanced Liquid Technologies and Medical businesses, demand remained mostly robust. Net sales
in the Specialties business area decreased by €3.8 million, or 0.7%, to €561.0 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019, from €564.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. Net sales in the Specialties
business area decreased by €19.3 million, or 3.3%, to €561.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, from
€580.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2018 as presented based on internal management reporting
giving effect to the impact of the acquisitions of Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras as if these had been
consolidated in the results for the full year ended December 31, 2018, as higher selling prices were more than
offset by lower deliveries.

_Materials and supplies_

Materials and supplies for the year ended December 31, 2019 increased by €109.7 million, or 9.1%, to
€1,317.8 million, from €1,208.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was mainly due to
the acquisition of Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras, which was partially offset by decreased raw materials
prices in the Decor business area and a lower cost of pulp in the second half of 2019, and lower volumes in all
business areas, which in turn was partially offset by the impact of raw materials pricing in other business areas.
Materials and supplies for the year ended December 31, 2019 amounted to 45.2% of net sales for the year ended
December 31, 2019.

_Other operating expenses_

Other operating expenses for the year ended December 31, 2019 increased by €128.6 million, or 21.8%, to
€718.1 million, from €589.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to
the acquisition of Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras as well as higher energy costs and was partially offset
by changes to leasing and rental costs due to the implementation of IFRS 16. Other operating expenses for the
year ended December 31, 2019 amounted to 24.6% of net sales for the year ended December 31, 2019.

_Employee benefit expenses_

Employee benefit expenses for the year ended December 31, 2019 increased by €130.7 million, or 28.9%, to
€583.1 million, from €452.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to

103


-----

the acquisition of Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras as well as an increase in wages and salaries, statutory
social expenses and pension expenses due to an increase in the number of full-time equivalent employees over
the period, which partially offset by decreases in other long-term incentives and indirect employee costs.
Employee benefit expenses for the year ended December 31, 2019 amounted to 20.0% of net sales for the year
ended December 31, 2019.

_Depreciation, amortization and impairment_

Depreciation, amortization and impairment for the year ended December 31, 2019 increased by
€42.3 million, or 31.6%, to €176.2 million, from €133.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This
increase was primarily due to the acquisition of Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras. Depreciation,
amortization and impairment includes depreciation and amortization arising from purchase price allocation of
€52.1 million in 2019 as compared to €34.7 million in 2018.

_Net financial items_

Net financial items for the year ended December 31, 2019 increased by €26.2 million, or 103.5%, to
€51.6 million, from €25.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to
higher net debt during 2019 as a result of the acquisition of Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras. Net
financial items includes net interest expenses of €47.6 million, a currency exchange gain of €2.8 million and
other financial expenses of €6.7 million, in each case, for the year ended December 31, 2019.

_Net result_

Net result for the year ended December 31, 2019 decreased by €10.1 million, or 23.5%, to €32.8 million,
from €42.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily as a result of the factors discussed above.

€71.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €61.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2019,
representing 10.4% of net sales in 2020 as compared to 8.0% in 2019, mainly due to lower costs that were
reduced partly as a result of our cost savings program, which more than offset lower selling prices.

_Food Packaging & Technical Solutions_

Comparable EBITDA in the Food Packaging & Technical Solutions business area decreased by
€0.9 million, or 1.7%, to €52.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €53.4 million for the year
ended December 31, 2019, representing 9.5% of net sales in 2020 as compared to 9.2% in 2019, due to lower
sales, volumes and averages selling prices and an increase in fixed costs partly driven by maintenance activity.
The increase was partially offset by lower variable costs.

_Decor Solutions_

Comparable EBITDA in the Decor Solutions business area increased by €3.1 million, or 9.1%, to
€37.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, from €34.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2019,
representing 10.2% of net sales in 2020 as compared to 8.2% in 2019, due to lower variable costs, partly driven
by higher raw material efficiency, which more than offset the impact of lower selling prices and lower volumes.

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

**_Overview_**

Our principal cash requirements consist of Capital expenditures related to investments in operations and
maintenance, upgrades of existing facilities and servicing financial indebtedness and paying taxes.

Our principal sources of liquidity, prior to the Initial Settlement Date, were and are expected to be cash
flows from operating activities and short-term and long-term loans and financing. Following the Initial
Settlement Date, our principal sources of liquidity are expected to be cash flows from operating activities and
financing cash flows from drawings under the Revolving Credit Facility and committed and uncommitted lines.
The availability of the Revolving Credit Facility, will be subject to certain conditions. See “Description of Other
_Indebtedness.”_

Our ability to generate operating cash flows depends on operating performance, which in turn depends to
some extent on general economic, financial, industry, regulatory and other factors, many of which are beyond our

108


-----

control, as well as other factors discussed in “Risk Factors.” We believe that, based on our current level of
operations as reflected in its results of operations for the year ended December 31, 2020, cash flows from
operating activities, cash on hand and the availability of borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility and
committed and uncommitted lines will be sufficient to fund operations and capital expenditures and to debt
service for at least the next twelve months. The ability of our subsidiaries to pay dividends and make other
payments to us may be restricted by, among other things, the amount of distributable reserves, legal prohibitions
on such payments or otherwise distributing funds to us, including for the purpose of servicing debt. Losses or
other events could further reduce the net equity and distributable reserves of our subsidiaries.

The financial impact of the pandemic on us was relatively limited in 2020. We have taken numerous actions
across the organization to cushion the short-term financial impact of the expected decline in delivery volumes
and to support our liquidity position, including the implementation of temporary layoffs, reduction of working
hours and the minimization of the use of external personnel and services. We also reduced spending and
postponed certain projects. Members of the Executive Management Team and the CEO took a 50% and 100%
reduction, respectively, on one month’s salary during the second quarter. The Board of Directors also decided to
forgo their compensation for one month in the second quarter. Savings from these actions were approximately
€24 million in the year ended December 31, 2020.

We anticipate that we will maintain a level of debt in line with or not too far from, our opening leverage, for
a period after the Transaction and our ability to generate future financing cash flows will be limited by the
Indenture and the Senior Secured Credit Facilities, which may have important negative consequences for you.
See “Risk Factors,” “Description of Other Indebtedness” and “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—
_Limitation on Indebtedness.” In addition, any additional indebtedness that we incur could reduce the amount of_
our cash flows available to make payments on our then existing indebtedness, including under the Notes, and
increase our leverage.

The proceeds from the Offerings of the Notes will be used as set forth under “Use of Proceeds.”

_Net cash from operating activities_

Net cash from operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2020 decreased by €31.6 million, or
11.0%, to €255.1 million, from €286.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. The net cash during the
year ended December 31, 2020 was primarily supported by the improved result for the period. Working capital
also decreased although not as significantly as in 2019.

109


-----

Net cash from operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 increased by €195.1 million, or
213.1%, to €286.7 million, from €91.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to a
reduction in net working capital, including positive changes in trade and other receivables, inventories and trade
and other payables.

_Net cash from investing activities_

Net cash used in investing activities for the year ended December 31, 2020 decreased by €95.0 million, or
55.7%, to €75.4 million, compared to €170.4 million used in the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to
the sale of the fine arts paper business in Arches, France in 2020 and a decrease in purchases of property, plant
and equipment and intangible assets.

Net cash used in investing activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 decreased by €597.9 million, or
77.8%, to negative €170.4 million, compared to €768.3 million used in the year ended December 31, 2018,
primarily due to a decrease in payments for acquisitions in 2019 as compared to 2018. The acquisitions of Expera
Specialty Solutions and MD Papéis’ Caieiras were completed in 2018 for cash consideration of €524.9 million
and €95.0 million, respectively.

_Net cash from financing activities_

Net cash used in financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2020 decreased by €72.7 million, or
71.0%, to €29.7 million, compared to €102.4 million used in the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily as a
result of primarily the receipt of proceeds from the Pension Loan and a new term loan and lower repayments of
drawings than in 2019.

Net cash from financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 decreased by €688.3 million, or
117.5%, to an outflow of €102.4 million, from €585.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily
due to the partial repayment in 2019 of a facility maturing in 2021 and the receipt of borrowings in 2018 from
drawing of certain bank facilities in order to fund the acquisitions of Expera Specialty Solutions and MD Papéis’
Caieiras. This decrease was partially offset by the receipt of proceeds from the hybrid bond issued in 2019.

detailed implementation plan and time schedule is under development.

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Financial Risk**

In the ordinary course of business, we are exposed to a variety of financial risks, including credit risk,
funding risk, liquidity risk and market risk.

Our global risk management focuses on uncertainty in the financial markets and aims to minimize potential
adverse effect on our profits. We actively work to reduce the effects of these risks through preventive measures
and, when such preventive measures are not available, we occasionally hedge or insure the risk. Our board of
directors and audit and sustainability committee oversee our risks, and set and approve a treasury policy that
seeks to establish guidelines on how finance and treasury operations and financial risk are managed. Our
executive treasury committee monitors and manages financial risk, while our treasury manages risk
operationally, identifying and evaluating risk. If necessary, measures to mitigate such risks are also identified and
taken. See also “Risk Factors.”

**_Credit Risk_**

Financial instruments that could potentially expose us to counterparty risk consist primarily of trade
receivables, cash and cash equivalents and derivative financial instruments. We are exposed to counterparty
credit risks from financial transactions and customer credit risks.

113


-----

_Financial transactions counterparty credit risk_

Financial transactions counterparty credit risk refers to our exposure under financial contracts arising from
the deterioration of the counterparties’ financial position. In order to minimize this risk, we have the following
guidelines in place in the group finance policy: (i) only entering into transactions with leading financial
institutions and with industrial companies that have a high credit rating (preferably BBB or higher), (ii) only
investing in liquid cash funds with financially secure institutions or companies (preferably BBB or higher) and
(iii) requiring parent company guarantees when dealing with a subsidiary of a rated company.

_Customer credit risk_

Customer credit risk is applied centrally in compliance with existing credit risk management policies and
managed locally in each subsidiary. The principles of customer credit risk management and review are defined,
including thresholds for stopping deliveries to customers in case of overdues. Customer credit exposure is
controlled through credit limits. We employ credit insurance as an additional assurance and other means for
securing payments such as trade finance products.

**_Funding Risk_**

Funding risk refers to the risk that we do not at all times have access to financing or financing at an
acceptable cost. This may arise should we become too dependent on a single source of financing, or if the
maturity structure of our debt portfolio is too concentrated. In order to mitigate funding risk, we aim to spread
our debt across different lenders, different maturities and different forms of financing.

We have outlined the following guidelines in our treasury policy, which aim to mitigate the funding risk.
Historically, we have aimed to ensure that not more than 50% of our debt portfolio will mature in the same
12-month period and the average maturity of the long-term finance should be at least two years. In addition, we
also aimed to avoid the inclusion of financial covenants in all types of financing agreements. Following the
Transactions, we will amend our treasury policy to reflect the debt instruments of the Issuer and their respective
durations, including the Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the Notes. The Notes and the Senior Term Facilities
will mature within seven years and the Revolving Credit Facility matures six months before the Notes. The
covenants and other terms of the Notes and the Senior Secured Credit Facilities are described more fully under
“Description of the Notes” and “Description of Other Indebtedness—The Senior Secured Credit Facilities
_Agreement.”_

**_Liquidity Risk_**

Liquidity risk is the risk that we will not have sufficient funds to pay foreseen and unforeseen expenditures,
including our ability to service and repay our financial liabilities. In order to mitigate this risk, our treasury
monitors our cash pools, bank agreements and liquidity to ensure at all times that there is sufficient liquidity. The
liquidity situation is monitored in such way that we at all times have sufficient liquidity. Our cash accounts are
included in the cash pools.

**_Market Risk_**

Market risks includes currency risk, interest rate risk and commodity risk.

_Currency Risk_

Due to our global operations, we are exposed to currency risk. Currency risk refers to the risk that
fluctuations in the foreign exchange market will negatively affect our cash flow, net result and equity. Currency
exposure, defined as all unhedged exposure in foreign currency, is split into two types of exposure: transaction
exposure and translation exposure. See note 19 to the 2020 Financial Statements for further information on
currency risk and the use of derivative instruments and hedging activities.

_Transaction Exposure_

We manufacture and sell our products globally and are, therefore, exposed to transaction risk. Transaction
exposure arises from commercial and finance-related transactions and payments in a currency other than an
operation’s functional currency (i.e., from internal purchases, sales between manufacturing units and market
companies, external sales and purchases as well as from financing transactions in foreign currencies).

Firm commitments to acquire businesses may also expose us to foreign currency transaction risk.

114


-----

Foreign currency cash flows are hedged on a net exposure basis in accordance with the rules set out in the
Group’s treasury policy. Our risk management strategy in terms of currency risk is to hedge 75% (+/-10%) of the
forecasted cash flows for a period up to nine months if the total exposure to forecasted net flows of foreign
currency exceeds the equivalent of 2% of the total turnover of the company. We use forward contracts to hedge
this commercial foreign currency exposure and apply cash flow hedge accounting. The forward contracts’
maturity is materially reconciled with the timing of the forecasted sales and purchases. As of December 31, 2020,
the fair value of the forwards under hedge accounting was €4.2 million. In 2020, we booked a loss of
€2.1 million to the cash flow hedge transferred to 2020’s result in OCI. We have not historically booked material
ineffectiveness from the hedging relationships, however, ineffectiveness might arise from timing differences.

In addition to using derivatives for hedging, we also employ practical actions in order to reduce the currency
risk. The number of currencies used in intercompany invoicing is minimized and where possible, our treasury
will match foreign exchange cash flows within the Group.

At the end of the reporting period, the hedge ratio for the forecasted cash flows for the next nine months,
including indirect exposure embedded in pulp prices and other adjustments, was approximately 72% as of
December 31, 2020 as compared to approximately 74% as of December 31, 2019 for U.S. dollars and
approximately 82% for SEK as of December 31, 2020 as compared to approximately 67% as of December 31,
2019 and approximately 71% for GBP as of December 31, 2020, which was initiated during 2020. The exposures
in other currencies are limited and not hedged. Outstanding nominal amounts as of the end of 2020 for these
forward contracts were $35 million, SEK 720 million and GBP 16 million, respectively.

Ahlstrom-Munksjö has provided financing (or received deposits) to (from) its foreign subsidiaries which
have been hedged by using forward contracts as of December 31, 2020. Hedge accounting is not applied to these
relationships. The nominal amounts of the loans were $5 million and CNY 25 million, and the nominal amount
of the deposit is JPY 661 million. Additionally, the Company hedges an external loan with a nominal amount of
USD 35 million. These amounts correspond to the nominal amounts of the forward contracts, which have a
maturity of three months and are adjusted according to the open balances. These forward contracts are recognized
at fair value with changes in fair value through the exchange gains and losses within the financial items. The fair
value for the forwards was €0.0 million as of December 31, 2020.

_Translation Exposure_

Our income statement and balance sheet are both exposed to foreign exchange fluctuations, as these affect
the translation of subsidiaries’ assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies.

We have historically aimed to minimize currency risk related to translation exposure by aiming to balance
assets and liabilities of subsidiaries so that the foreign exchange risk is minimized in the consolidated balance
sheet. Due to the long-term nature of net investments, we have not normally performed equity hedging.
Following the Transactions, we expect to naturally hedge U.S. dollar translation risk by designating the USD
Notes and the USD TLB Facility as hedges of our net investments denominated in U.S. dollars.
