_Interest Rate Risk_

Interest rate risk refers to the risk that changes in interest rates would have a negative effect on our results
and could affect our long-term competitiveness. There is a risk of interest rates moving both upwards and
downwards. Following the Initial Settlement Date, on an as adjusted basis for the Transactions, the Notes, which
will represent a majority of our debt, will be at fixed interest rates. The Senior Secured Credit Facilities will be at
variable interest rates, which for loans denominated in euros is essentially fixed when the reference interest rate
is below zero, due to the interest rate floor. We regularly monitor our debt portfolio for changes in interest rates.
In order to mitigate interest rate risk, our risk management policy states that our debt portfolio should have an
average fixed term interest of two years with a tolerance of one year. Following the Transactions, we will amend
our treasury policy to reflect the debt instruments of the Issuer, including the Senior Secured Credit Facilities and
the Notes. The Notes and the Senior Term Facilities will mature within seven years and the Revolving Credit
Facility matures six months before the Notes. The covenants and other terms of the Notes and the Senior Secured
Credit Facilities are described more fully under “Description of the Notes” and “Description of Other
_Indebtedness—The Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement.”_

_Commodity Risk_

Commodity risk refers to the risk that changes in the cost of raw materials (such as pulp and titanium
dioxide) and energy (such as electricity, gas, oil, etc.) have a negative effect on our results or competitiveness.
We periodically evaluate our exposure to fluctuations in commodity prices.

To mitigate commodity risk exposure, we hedge commodity exposure in line with the Group’s treasury
policy. In accordance with this policy, commodity hedging should have a maximum duration of three years and
can cover up to 50% of forecasted consumption during the first year, 40% of forecasted consumption during the
second year and 30% of forecasted consumption during the third year. All hedging transactions are to be related
to a specific project, customer agreement or other directly identifiable business risk in order to avoid speculative
hedging. As of December 31, 2020, we did not have any outstanding commodity derivatives.

**Critical accounting policies**

The preparation of our consolidated annual accounts and related disclosures requires management to make
estimates, judgments and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in our Financial Statements. Management
must judge and develop estimates for the carrying values of assets and liabilities which are not easily obtainable
from other sources. The estimates and associated assumptions are based on historical experience and other
factors considered relevant. Actual results could differ from those estimates.

We periodically review these estimates and underlying assumptions. We recognize the effects of revisions
to accounting estimates in the period that estimates are revised if the revision affects only that period, or also in
later periods if the revision affects both current and future periods. The significant estimates, accounting
judgments and related assumptions for the accounting issues concerned are detailed below.

_Business acquisitions_

Business combinations are accounted for using the acquisition method. The cost of the acquisition is
measured at the fair value of consideration transferred comprising (i) fair value of the assets transferred,
(ii) liabilities incurred to the former owners of the acquired business, (iii) equity interests issued as purchase
consideration, (iv) fair value of any contingent consideration arrangement, and (v) fair value of any pre-existing
equity interest in the subsidiary, if applicable.

Identifiable assets acquired and liabilities and contingent liabilities assumed in a business combination are,
with limited exceptions, measured initially at their fair values and any non-controlling interest in the acquired
entity on an acquisition-by-acquisition basis either at fair value or at the non-controlling interests’ proportionate
share of the acquired entity’s net identifiable assets. Acquisition-related costs are expensed as incurred and
presented as other operating expenses in the income statement with the exception of costs directly attributable to
the issuance of equity instruments that are deducted from equity, net of tax. Any excess of the consideration
transferred over the fair value of the net identifiable assets acquired is recorded as goodwill.

The application of the acquisition method requires certain estimates and assumptions to be made, especially
concerning the fair values of the acquired intangible assets, property, plant and equipment and the liabilities
assumed at the acquisition date, and the useful lives of the acquired intangible assets and property, plant and
equipment.

116


-----

Measurement is based to a large extent on anticipated cash flows. If actual cash flows vary from those used
in calculating fair values, this may materially affect our future results of operations. In particular, the estimation
of discounted cash flows for e.g., customer relationships, technology based assets as well as trademarks and
tradename are based on assumptions concerning, for example, (i) assumptions related to long-term sales
projections and margin development, (ii) determination of appropriate discount rates, (iii) estimates related to
customer retention rates, and (iv) estimates related to appropriate market based royalty rates.

For significant acquisitions, the fair valuation exercise on the acquired assets and assumed liabilities is
carried out with assistance from independent third-party valuation specialists. The valuations are based on the
information available at the acquisition date taking into account the provisional adjustment period allowed under
IFRS of 12 months.

_Share-based payments_

The long-term incentive share based plans have been accounted for as equity settled share-based payments.
This is based on a judgment made by us that the plans will be rewarded in the form of shares and not settled in
cash.

The fair value of the rewards granted in the long-term incentive-share based plans have been estimated at
the grant-date based on the probability of TSR (market) reaching specific thresholds at the end of the
performance period. In order to calculate the probabilities, the most important assumptions that have been made
in the probability weighted value model comprise of required rate of return and annual TSR volatility.

The expense recognized in Employee benefit expenses is based on management’s estimate of the likelihood
of achieving the Comparable EBITDA performance criteria and the estimated number of participants remaining
in the scheme when the vesting period ends.

At the end of each period, management estimates the likelihood of achieving the comparable EBITDA
performance criteria and the expected retention rate for participants in order to calculate the expense for the
current period and the change in the amount recognized in equity. In order to estimate the likelihood of achieving
the comparable EBITDA criteria management considers our comparable EBITDA performance against the target
to date and the forecast for the remainder of the performance period. Management estimate the number of
participants that they expect to remain in the scheme at the end of the vesting period by reviewing the number of
participants remaining at the end of each period, and the expected number of these participants who will remain
at the pay-out date, considering the historic rate of our staff retention.

_Deferred tax assets_

The utilization of deferred tax assets is dependent on the reversal of deferred tax liabilities and generation of
future taxable profits. We estimate possibilities to use deferred tax assets based on current business plans. We
periodically evaluate status of ongoing tax audits and disputes and positions taken in tax returns with respect to
situations in which applicable tax regulation is subject to interpretation. It makes a revaluation of the amounts
recorded, where appropriate, on the basis of amounts expected to be paid to the tax authorities. Because we
operate in complex international tax environment, significant degree of judgement is used in identifying
outcomes of tax audits and disputes and uncertain tax positions.

_Key assumptions used in goodwill impairment testing_

The management makes significant estimates and judgements in determining the level at which the goodwill
is tested and whether there are any indications of impairment.

The calculations of the value-in-use are based on cash flow projections, which require assessments and
estimates from the management. The most significant estimates concern development of net sales and EBITDA
including estimates for market prices of pulp and cost levels of main raw materials and energy as well as
determination of the weighted average cost of capital (“WACC”) used to discount cash flows. Management tests
the impacts of changes in significant estimates used in forecasts by sensitivity analyses. COVID-19 has increased
the uncertainty related to cash flow projections as the final impact will depend upon the duration and severity of
the pandemic. In our WACC calculation, we have included an alfa factor amounting to 2.0% to mitigate the risks
relating to future cash flow projections and to the impact of the pandemic.

_Estimates and judgements related to other intangible assets_

For information on the estimation of useful economic life of an intangible asset, see note 8 to the 2020
Financial Statements.

117


-----

_Estimates and judgements related to property, plant and equipment and other intangible assets_

We have tangible and other intangible assets with definite useful lives the values of which are presented in
note 12 to the 2020 Financial Statements. The assets are tested for impairment when there are events or changes
in circumstances indicate that the carrying value may be impaired (i.e., a triggering event). The recoverability of
these assets is based on market assumptions and managements estimate of future cash flows. Changes in
assumptions and failure to meet certain earnings targets could result in impairment. We have considered
triggering events due to COVID-19 and other events and tested the assets for impairment accordingly. For more
details, see note 8 to the 2020 Financial Statements.

_Estimates and judgements related to right-of-use (“ROU”) assets_

We have open ended lease contracts and contacts with extension options. Management uses their best
estimate according to the existing information available to evaluate the most likely end date for these types of
contracts. Changes in the estimated end dates impact the amount of ROU asset and lease liability booked in the
balance sheet.

_Inventory obsolescence_

If the net realizable value of inventory is deemed lower than the cost, then allowance is established for
inventory obsolescence. The amount to be allocated to inventory obsolescence is based on an estimation of the
net realizable value of inventory.

_Defined benefit obligation_

We have various pension schemes in accordance with local practices in different countries. The pension
arrangements are classified as either defined contribution plans or defined benefit plans. The schemes are mostly
funded through payments to insurance companies or trustee-administered funds according to local regulations. A
defined contribution plan is a pension plan under which we, and also typically the employees, pay fixed
contributions to an insurance company. We have no legal or constructive obligations to pay further contributions
if the fund does not hold sufficient assets to pay the pension benefits to the employees. Contributions to defined
contribution pension plans are recognized as expense in the period when they incur. All pension plans which do
not meet the criteria for defined contribution plans are defined benefit plans. Defined benefit plans typically
define a fixed amount of benefit that an employee will receive after retirement and for which the company is
responsible.

Our net obligation of defined benefit plans is calculated and recorded separately for each pension scheme
based on calculations prepared by independent actuaries. The present value of defined benefit obligations is
determined using the projected unit credit method. The net liability recognized in the balance sheet is the present
value of the defined benefit obligation at the end of the reporting period less the fair value of the plan assets. The
discount rate used to determine the present value of the defined benefit obligation is equal to the yield on high
quality corporate bonds or, if not available, government bonds.

The interest rates of the high-quality corporate bonds are determined in the currency in which the benefits
will be paid with a similar maturity to the obligation.

Our net obligation in respect of long-term service benefits, other than pension benefits, is the amount of
future benefit that employees have earned in return for their service in the current and prior periods.

Pension calculations under defined benefit plans include several factors that rely on management estimates:
the discount rate used in calculating pension expenses and obligations for the period, the rate of salary increase
and the rate of future discretionary bonuses decided by the insurance company. Changes in these assumptions can
significantly impact the amounts of pension liability and future pension expenses.

_Environmental_

Environmental provisions are recorded based on current interpretations of environmental laws and
regulations. Such provisions are recognized when it is probable that an obligation has arisen and that the amount
of the obligation can be reliably measured. The amount recognized is the present value of the estimated future
expenditure determined in accordance with local conditions and requirements.

The estimates used in determining the provisions for environmental costs are based on management’s
expectations of, for example (i) timing and scope, (ii) future cost levels and (iii) laws and regulations enacted at
time of the restoration works.

118


-----

The timing of the environmental costs depends on the expected useful lives of our sites. These range from
50 to 70 years. In measuring the future cost levels, we estimate future costs and adjusts these for the effect of
inflation, cost-base development and discounting. The estimated costs are based on current laws and regulations
in place at the time of making the provision.

We utilize a third-party consultant to estimate both the closure and long-term care costs for the landfills. The
estimate is based on the area finally to be capped and the capping materials and activities required along with the
permit and regulatory requirements for closure and post-closure maintenance. These costs are reviewed
periodically by our environmental experts and by a third-party consultant.

Because actual outflows can differ from estimates due to changes in law, regulations, public expectations,
technology, prices and conditions, and can take place many years in the future, the carrying amounts of
provisions are regularly reviewed and adjusted to take into account any such changes. The discount rate used is
reviewed annually.

**INDUSTRY**

**_Overview_**

We produce fiber-based high-performance materials used across a number of niche markets. Although our
offering is fiber-based, the markets we serve have different characteristics compared to commodity paper
markets. The end-markets we serve are more advanced and include medical and healthcare, food and beverage,
and high-performance industrial markets. These markets are generally growing faster than GDP and are
supported by global macro trends such as demographic development and urbanization, globalization,
sustainability and climate change, and digitalization, electrification and automation. In contrast, commodity
paper typically serves newsprint, printing and writing end-markets, which have experienced declining volumes in
the past years. In high performance materials end-markets, our products typically serve critical functions and
provide superior technical performance for our customers, for example, medical fabrics used to construct surgical
gowns and drapes, and face masks, grease-resistant food packaging materials without the use of fluoro chemicals,
or formaldehyde-free abrasive backings. High-performance materials products are sold at significantly higher
price points (€1,000-30,000 per ton as compared to €500 per ton for commodity products), higher margins and
require more investment in research and development compared to commodity paper. The contracting terms in
these markets are also different and allow for significant portion of raw-material pass through.

_Filtration & Performance Solutions_

Filtration & Performance Solutions comprise Filtration, Nonwovens, Glass Fiber Tissue and Abrasive
markets.

_Filtration: The market has been growing at CAGR of approximately 2-3% since 2014, driven by more_
stringent emission regulations globally, and the increasing number of vehicles and buildings, notably in China.
The Filtration market can be split into Automotive & Transportation (42% of value) and Industrial (58% of
value). In Automotive & Transportation, the after-market segment accounts for more than 80% of sales, which
protects the business from the cyclicality of new vehicle sales. Our main competitors are Hollingsworth & Vose,
Neenah and Lydall.

123


-----

Key demand drivers are the steady growth of vehicle fleets, notably in Asia Pacific, driving aftermarket
sales and stricter emission standards globally requiring higher-performance filtration materials. The rise of
electric vehicle offers opportunities (e.g. battery separators, new filter applications) but is not expected to have a
significant impact on revenues due to the company’s strong exposure to aftermarket and to the heavy-duty
vehicles segment.

_Nonwoven: Our market exposure can be divided into plasterboard and high-end wallcover. The plasterboard_
market is growing by approximately 5% per year supported by a shift from paper to glass fiber due to better
performance (e.g. it is weather-proof and thereby allows interior construction work to start before completely
finishing the outside).

The high-end wallcover market is growing at approximately 2-3%, due to strong growth in digital
wallcovering in Europe, North America and Asia. Growth is driven by the availability of personal and trendy
designs. The market has seen positive impact from the COVID-19 pandemic due to an increased share of
spending on home decoration. The consolidated market requires deep production technology know-how to ensure
quality.

_Glass Fiber Tissue: The market is growing by 3-8% driven by commercial and residential construction,_
increased spending on renovations as well as technology advancements and sustainability aspects. In North
America, demand is also underpinned by substitution from other flooring reinforcements such as mineral felt.
The market is consolidated as products are complex and knowledge-intensive. We predominately operate in the
flooring category in which we are a market leader.

_Abrasive: The market is expected to grow in line with GDP, 2-3%. The main drivers of growth are wood-_
working in the furniture industry and automotive aftermarket industries. The market is cyclical due to the large
industrial end-market exposure however that is partly offset by the exposure to furniture. The Do-It-Yourself
segment has been and is expected to continue to be the fastest growing segment in the market. We are a market
leader ahead of our principal competitor, Neenah.

_Advanced Solutions_

Advanced Solution Business Area comprise Liquid Technologies, Beverage & Casing, Medical, Tape, and
Precision Coating markets.

_Liquid Technologies: A high-growth market growing at approximately 7% CAGR, driven by point-of-care_
diagnostic, increase spending in testing for environmental and health monitoring and trend of customized drugs
that require DNA tests. The market has limited cyclicality given resilient end-market exposure. The market is
expected to benefit from significant tailwind due to COVID-19 as there will be additional need for serological
tests. Danaher and Ahlstrom-Munksjö are the two largest competitors in the market.

_Beverage & Casing: The market is growing by 3% per year driven by sustainable tea bag and casing_
materials and single-serve coffee solutions. The main driver behind the tea category growth is further penetration
of teabags in the Asia Pacific region and for the coffee category a switch to paper coffee pods in Europe and the
United States because of conveniences and more environmentally conscious customers are driving the growth.
The market is consolidated with Glatfelter holding a number one position.

_Medical: The market has seen a strong positive effect from COVID-19, with market growth expected to_
double from historical level of 2-3% up to approximately 5%. Market growth has been supported by rise in
infection prevention standards and high-risk surgeries, as well as penetration of sterilization. We believe these
growth drivers are stable and linked to fundamental trends such as increasing medical spending, aging
population, and supports the resilience of the market. The market is fragmented. We hold a position of one to
three globally with Berry being a market leader.

_Tape: The market is expected to grow above GDP driven by increased use of fiber based tapes in China and_
rest of Asia, and increasing level of e-commerce. The market is cyclical due to heavy reliance on construction
and automotive industries; however, the cyclicality has been more than offset by the increasing demand for
packaging tape. The market is very concentrated. We hold a leading position globally.

_Precision Coating: The market is expected to grow 3-8% per year mainly driven by increased adoption of_
co composites in automotive and aerospace industries. The market is cyclical as a consequence of the heavy
reliance on the automotive and aerospace industries. The market is consolidated. We primarily supply the
aerospace industry through sales to converters.

124


-----

_Industrial Solutions_

The Industrial Solutions business area comprises Insulation, Release Liner and Coated Specialties markets.

_Insulation: The market is growing by approximately 1-3% driven by grid renovations due to increased_
renewable energy sources incidence, investments in the Asia Pacific region and increased electric vehicle
penetration. The market’s large exposure to infrastructure makes it resilient to economic cycles although large
one-off projects could lead to some volatility in demand. The market can be divided into cables, transformers and
bushings. We hold a number one to two position in electrotechnical papers segment globally. In transformers,
Weidmann is the market leader, while we have a more limited presence.

_Release Liner: The market is growing at approximately 4% per year mainly driven by an increasing demand_
for release liner used in labels, hygiene products and tapes. The market is resilient to cyclicality due to the
diversified end-industry exposure. We are a market leader in this strategic segment in Europe. The Asia Pacific
region is expected to outgrow the broader market, supported by a growing middle-class population. UPM is the
market leader.

_Coated Specialties: The market is expected to grow at 2-4% per year mainly driven by adoption of pressure-_
sensitive labels and increasing product safety regulations. The market is predominately exposed to primary
consumer goods (e.g., foods and dairy) which results in limited cyclicality.

_Food Packaging & Technical Solutions_

Food Packaging & Technical Solutions comprise of Food Packaging, Technical and Parchment markets.

_Food Packaging: The market we are exposed to is growing 1.5-2.5%, below the broader food paper market_
which is growing 2.5-3% due to our lower exposure to plastic-to-paper substitution and lower Asia Pacific
exposure.

_Technical: The market is growing at 1-2% per year as a result of exposure towards segments growing in line_
with GDP such as industrial and construction.

_Parchment: The market is growing at 1-2% mostly driven by food applications, which represent_
approximately 75% of volumes. Non-food applications include textile tubes, tape and film cores, and furniture
laminates. Market growth is supported by tailwinds related to sustainability, for example vegetable parchment
compared to quilon-coated papers in the United States baking market. Parchment is a specialty product with
attractive differentiation due to superior performance in terms of heat resistance, grease resistance and
re-usability compared to other alternative products. Our Parchment business holds a number one position
globally in the baking and cooking strategic segment.

_Decor Solutions_

The decor market is growing at approximately 3% per year but is a cyclical market due to its end-market
exposure such as construction and furniture. Demand is driven by residential home starts, commercial building
projects and renovation activity as well as rapidly growing middle class in developing markets. We hold a
number two to four position globally in the decor market and our key markets are Europe, North and South
America and selected export markets. Overall, the market is expected to grow broadly in line with GDP, with
China and Asia Pacific regions growing faster than other markets.

**BUSINESS**

**Overview**

We are a global leader in the production of high-performance fiber-based materials for a variety of
consumer and industrial end-uses. Our products are used in a broad range of industrial applications and
consumer-driven products and processes, ranging from everyday consumables, health care and life sciences,
homebuilding and furniture, industrial goods and transportation. Sustainability is central across our businesses,
and with our product offering we facilitate a sustainable everyday life by providing solutions with better
performance, safer materials, fewer resources and a lower environmental impact. Our net sales, operating result,
net result and Comparable EBITDA were €2,683.3 million, €176.2 million, €94.5 million and €334.2 million,
respectively, for the year ended December 31, 2020 and our As Adjusted EBITDA was €412.6 million for the
year ended December 31, 2020.

We produce fiber-based materials from pulp and other fibers, and then typically sell such materials to
converters who incorporate them in their end-products. We also produce certain end-products ourselves. Our
product offering includes filter materials, release liners, food and beverage processing and packaging materials,
decor papers, abrasive and tape backings, electrotechnical insulation paper, glass fiber materials, medical fabrics
and solutions for diagnostics, and a range of other specialty materials and pulp for industrial and consumer enduses. We develop our products in close cooperation with customers and other stakeholders in the value-chain,
making use of our high technical expertise and broad experience. We design our custom-made and tailored
materials with a high degree of differentiation to meet and exceed specific customer demands concerning quality
and functionality, adding value for customers.

We target niche markets that benefit from value-based pricing and require technical specialization making it
more challenging for new market entrants. As a niche player, identifying trends and developing new customer
solutions are critical for our business. We have a strong focus on innovation and aim to regularly refresh our
offering and to improve sustainable functionality and design. Our recent innovations include FortiCell[®] launched
in 2020, a new range of fiber-based solutions for energy storage applications using amongst others our DISPRO
foam-forming technology, Extia[®] Protect, a comprehensive range of materials for face masks using fine fiber
technology, and BioWeb[®] and Fiber+ ranges, which use renewable biopolymer polylactic acid for producing
biodegradable and compostable tea bag materials. Our sales from New Products increased to 12% for the year
ended December 31, 2020.

We serve a diverse customer base with more than 6,000 customers in over 100 countries. For the year ended
December 31, 2020, 37% of our sales were to customers in the consumer goods sector, 27% in the homebuilding
and furniture sector, 14% in the transportation sector, 11% in the industrials sector and 11% in the health care
and life sciences sector. For the year ended December 31, 2020, our top-five and top-ten largest customers
generated 13% and 19% of our net sales, respectively.

We manufacture our products globally and have 45 manufacturing plants and converting sites in 14
countries. We consume commodity pulp as part of the manufacturing process. Our commodity pulp consumption
was approximately 1,200 thousand tons for the year ended December 31, 2020. Our pulp exposure was reduced
by approximately 500 thousand tons of our own pulp production during that same period, which includes 185
thousand tons of market pulp production at our Aspa pulp mill in Sweden that is sold to third parties. We believe
that our global manufacturing footprint represents a competitive advantage and would be challenging for new
market entrants to replicate given its specification and scale. Our manufacturing sites are equipped to provide and
apply innovative technology, including FluoroFree[®] capabilities (providing grease resistance without
fluorochemicals), Parchmentizing technology (transforming cellulose to give it plastic-like qualities) and fine
fiber technology with multi-row spinning, which was recently adapted to also produce face masks. We delivered
a total of approximately 1,570 thousand tons of materials in the year ended December 31, 2020. We organize
delivery of our products directly to many of our business-to-business customers using third-party transport
service providers.

We were formed by the merger of Ahlstrom Corporation and Munksjö Oyj on April 1, 2017, which created
a global leader in the production of high-performance fiber-based materials. Our two predecessor companies
have a long history in the Finnish and Swedish forestry and paper industry. Since the merger, we have grown
significantly through the acquisitions of the Caieiras specialty paper mill in Brazil and Expera Specialty
Solutions in North America, each in October 2018.

We are a leading producer of specialty, high-performance fiber-based materials which contribute to a more
sustainable everyday life. Our specialty products have attractive price points and margins, as we are generally
able to set prices based on value, as compared to the cost-plus pricing of commodity products. In addition, the
specialty, high-performance market is growing in line with the increasing customer focus on health, safety and
sustainability, on which our business is focused, with an expected annual growth of approximately two to five
percent. This growth rate is particularly attractive when compared to commodities. The following table illustrates
the attractive price points based on the higher average selling prices and margins, market growth and average

Sustainability is central across our business. In response to increasing customer focus on sustainability and
demand for sustainable products and solutions, we design and launch solutions with better performance, safer
materials, fewer resources and a lower environmental impact. We provide sustainable and safe food packaging
and focus on compostable and biodegradable solutions. Our mineral oil barrier paper, paraffin wax-free paper,
FluoroFree[®] technology providing fluorochemicals-free grease-resistant papers, tea-bags, flushable wipes and
other products directly cater to a market trend towards more sustainable solutions and respond to stricter food
safety and chemical regulations. We also produce “Plastic Free” products such as plastic-free tea bags, singleserve coffee and casing materials, GenReleaz[™], cards for collection of bio samples, and our CelluStraw[™] an
alternative to the plastic straw. Our “Plastic Free” products provide alternatives to single-use plastics alongside
improved packaging functionality. We also produce recyclable products that help support the circular economy
by reducing waste. We believe increasing customer awareness towards health and safety is also partially driving
the market for our formaldehyde free papers, water purification filter media using its proprietary Disruptor[®]
technology, air and liquid filtration products, facemasks and other products.

Our businesses are also characterized by a high level of technological, customization and qualification
requirements as is required to effectively compete in our relevant markets, which we believe makes it more
challenging for new market participants. Technical and engineered products, in particular, involve manufacturing
complexity, R&D and investment and heightened environmental and safety standards. We operate a global
manufacturing platform, in which we have made significant investments over the prior year, that grants us a
competitive advantage over competitors and that may be hard for competitors to replicate. Product designs for
specific customer specifications, in particular, often require joint product development with the customers and
sometimes take several years to develop. In addition, many of our products require rigorous certifications and/or
long qualification processes, such as certifications for products destined for the aerospace industry and customer
qualification standards for composite release liners and high technical specifications for filter media solutions,
which help to protect our businesses from both conversion risk and other market players. In the year ended
December 31, 2019, we had customers covering 17% of our net sales with whom we had a relationship of over
10 years, demonstrating our ability to produce specialty, high-performance materials to the degree of specificity
and with the certifications that they require.

**_Limited exposure to raw material cost and proven pricing power_**

We have a structured and systematic procurement process and have been able to improve our margin over
variable costs (“MOVC”) during 2020 despite volatility in pulp prices due to the low price sensitivity of our
products and by ensuring commercial excellence, business development, innovation and product development,
cost efficiency and productivity and optimizing our business processes and investments. Our MOVC per ton was
€674, €660, €699 and €721 on average in each of the years ended December 31, 2017, 2018, 2019 and 2020,
respectively. Our cost base is primarily variable, with variable costs, such as fibers, including pulp, other raw
materials and energy, constituting 65% of our total costs for the year ended December 31, 2020, as detailed
below:

Our commodity pulp consumption was approximately 1,200 thousand tons for the year ended December 31,
2020. Our pulp exposure was reduced by approximately 500 thousand tons of our own pulp production during the
year ended December 31, 2020, which includes 185 thousand tons of market pulp production at our Aspa pulp
mill in Sweden that is sold to third parties. We are typically able to pass through a portion of, or, depending on
the business, the entirety of, any increases in the cost of pulp to our customers by increasing the selling prices of
our products. We typically include contractual or indexed pass-through clauses in our contracts with customers.
For the remainder, we have a strong historical track record of being able to pass through price increases to our
customers, which is possible due to our strong market positions, our exposure to attractive and niche specialty
markets, our value-based pricing approach and the low price sensitivity for many of our products. This low price
sensitivity is the result of our products often being a vital part of our customers’ finished goods and as a result
constitute a relatively low proportion of the overall cost thereof. In addition, our products often perform a key
niche function in the finished good, in contrast to commodity paper, further contributing to low price sensitivity.
The specialized nature of our products also aids in our ability to pass-through increases in raw materials prices as
often they are difficult to replace or substitute. The natural hedge from our own pulp production, combined with
the low price sensitivity of our products and our strong ability to pass-through pulp price increases to customers,
helps to ensure that our profit and cash flows are highly resilient from swings in pulp prices. For instance MOVC
per ton remained relatively stable between 2017 and 2018, decreasing only by 2% or €14 per ton, even though
pulp prices increased by 30% during that period.

129

In addition, in 2020, we focused on increasing margins and improving overall profitability by initiating cost
savings program. Our €50 million savings program focused on variable cost reduction through procurement
savings and other improvement actions was completed ahead of schedule and exceeded targets. We believe that
our largely variable cost base provides intrinsic resilience to downturns. In response to the COVID-19 pandemic,
we were also able to achieve temporary fixed cost savings of approximately €24 million in the year ended
December 31, 2020, respectively, as a result of measures, such as implementation of temporary layoffs, reduction
of working hours and the minimization of the use of external personnel and services, reduced spending,
postponement of projects and temporary salary decreases. The following chart shows our quarterly performance

**_Diversified business model across customer-base, end-markets and geographies_**

We provide our products and solutions to a diverse base of over 6,000 customers engaged in a variety of
industries, including healthcare & life sciences, engineered industrial products, transportation, food & beverages,
consumer goods, construction and furniture, across more than 100 countries. Our top ten customers generated
19.0% of our net sales in the year ended December 31, 2020, with no single customer representing more than
10% of our net sales. Our top one hundred customers generated 48.3% of our net sales in the year ended
December 31, 2020. Our products serve diverse end markets, which makes our business inherently resilient. In
addition, our products are widely used in industries that are less cyclical and the end-markets for some of our
businesses, such as Medical and Liquid Technologies, are noncyclical, further enhancing our resilience. While
Europe and North America constitute 43.2% and 34.7% of our net sales in the year ended December 31, 2020,
we have also strengthened our presence in South America with our recent acquisition of Caieiras in 2018 and are
currently exploring strategic opportunities in the Decor business in China in order to benefit from market
opportunities and for purposes of managing our portfolio.

Having a diversified business model with high pass-through and internal pulp production provides stability
across macroeconomic cycles as we are cushioned from negative industry trends through our exposure to
multiple industries, which allows greater predictability of overall earnings and growth and resilience to
downturns. For example, the results of operations of each of our predecessors, Ahlstrom Corporation and
Munksjö Oyj remained largely stable during the global financial crisis that began in 2008. Similarly, our
Comparable EBITDA of €334.2 million during the year ended December 31, 2020 was 6.8% higher than the year
ended December 31, 2019, in spite of the global slowdown caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, though net sales
for this period decreased by 8.0% due to adverse currency effects, lower selling prices and a less favorable
product mix. While some of our businesses such as Filtration, Decor, Technical, Insulation and Precision Coating
were negatively impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, our Medical business (particularly due to increased
demand for face masks), Liquid Technologies and repurposed activities in our Filtration business, outperformed
prior periods. Diversified exposure in terms of customers, end-market and geography, with high pass-through and

130


-----

internal pulp production, where net short pulp position also mitigates cyclicality, given pulp prices typically are
low when macro activity is low, also contributes to our resilience.

**_Historical high Cash conversion together with strategic deployment of capital to create future capacity_**

We have a track record of profitable growth and free cash flow generation. Our Comparable EBITDA for
the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020 was €277.7 million, €312.9 million and €334.2 million,
respectively. Our Free cash flow for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020 was €205 million,
€225 million, and €254 million, respectively, and our Cash conversion during the same period was 74%, 72%
and 76%, respectively. During the same period, our Capital expenditures were €160.1 million, €161.1 million and
€117.5 million, respectively, our Capital expenditures to net sales ratio was 7%, 6% and 4%, respectively, and
net cash from operating activities was €91.6 million, €286.7 million and €255.1 million, respectively. We believe
that this level of capital expenditure is higher than our long-term Maintenance capital expenditure, which
management estimates to be approximately 3% of net sales per annum, and reflects a temporary, elevated level of
capital expenditures targeting growth in order to better position us to capture further market share. Since 2017,
we have been progressing with our €200 million strategic investment program, which includes investments in
13 projects, aimed at allowing us to increase and improve our production capabilities and providing us with an
opportunity to grow, while retaining attractive cash flows. Of these 13 projects, 11 have been completed, while
the remaining are scheduled to be completed during 2021 and 2022.

A significant proportion of our Capital expenditures in 2018 and 2019 were related to projects undertaken in
the Filtration business in Madisonville, United States, the Abrasive business in Arches, France, the Parchment
business in San Severin, France, and the Coated Specialties business in Jacareí, Brazil, and a boiler and pulp line
rebuild in our plant in Billingsfors, Sweden, part of the Insulation business. Given these significant investments
in increasing capacity and improving manufacturing capabilities, we believe our production facilities are
relatively well-invested and that we are well-positioned to support future growth. We estimate that our
Maintenance capital expenditure is approximately 3% of our net sales, and we estimate that approximately
€90 million of annual capital expenditures (including IT spending) are required to maintain the competitiveness
of our current portfolio which supports our product capability.

**_Significant Transformation Opportunity Leveraging Bain Capital’s Experience from its portfolio company,_**
**_Fedrigoni_**

Bain Capital has a strong track record of driving cost savings and improvements in margin, while at the
same time growing its portfolio companies both organically and through targeted acquisitions. Bain Capital is the
majority shareholder of Fedrigoni, a leading European manufacturer and distributor of pressure sensitive labels
and luxury papers, demonstrating extensive and relevant experience of achieving operational improvements in
the same sector similar to the planned strategies for the Group. Since Fedrigoni’s acquisition by Bain Capital,
Fedrigoni’s sales growth have accelerated, and adjusted EBITDA has doubled, with a focus on increasing organic
growth, successfully integrating a number of bolt-on acquisitions, as well as driving significant operating
improvements through pricing, procurement and operating efficiencies. Fedrigoni has also improved their passthrough of cost of raw materials through pricing optimization. Through competitive sourcing, volumes
optimization and reallocation, volumes planning, supplier cooperation, as well as contract optimization,
Fedrigoni achieved meaningful savings on procurement spend. In addition, through value engineering and recipe
optimization, overall equipment effectiveness debottlenecking, maintenance, repair and operations optimization
and energy efficiency, Fedrigoni achieved meaningful savings on direct costs baseline. Based on Bain Capital’s
tested playbook from Fedrigoni, our Sponsors have identified over €200 million of profit improvement
opportunities and we expect to action approximately €30 million of such opportunities in the next 18 months.

**_Experienced management team with proven execution capabilities supported by our Sponsors_**

We benefit from the industry expertise and know-how of our experienced senior management team, which
has an average of 20 years of experience across the fiber-based materials and forestry industries and provides

chief executive officer and chief financial officer, who has held senior finance roles in several major companies
across a variety of industries. They are supported by our heads of function and our heads of each business area.

Our management team has been instrumental in our growth since the merger of Ahlstrom and Munksjö and

**Strategies**

We and the Sponsors have developed the following strategies:

**_Invest for long-term growth across the business_**

We operate in attractive niche specialty markets and our businesses are well-positioned to capture growth in
their respective markets. All of our sixteen businesses hold leading positions in their strategic segments, with a
majority holding positions as global leaders, while others hold positions as regional leaders. The average market
growth rates of many of the underlying market segments we operate in are growing at or above underlying GDP
rates prior to the COVID-19 pandemic and we expect these markets to continue to grow in the medium-to longterm. We plan to build on this position and capture further market share and to accelerate our growth. We invest
in innovation and product development and we operate extensive research and development capabilities in each
business area. Since 2017, we have been progressing with our €200 million strategic investment program, which
includes investments in 13 projects, aimed at allowing us to increase and improve our production capabilities and
providing us with an opportunity to grow, while retaining attractive cash flows. We plan to continue to drive
growth through selected investments where necessary in our businesses or regions in which we see profitable
growth opportunities.

**_Increase focus on environmental and sustainable specialty materials in line with customer preferences_**

The specialty, high-performance market is growing in line with the increasing customer focus on health,
safety and sustainability with an expected annual growth of approximately two to five percent. Increased
customer focus on environmental and sustainability concerns is causing a significant shift in the preferences for
specialty materials across applications and end uses and continues to drive growth. We believe that we can
significantly benefit from this trend in the mid-term, given our focus on specialty fiber-based materials and our
existing portfolio of sustainable, plastic-free and circular economy focused products. Our new product
development is focused on products that make a positive contribution to sustainability. We will continue to
develop sustainable products focused on moving towards alternatives to traditional plastics. We plan to capitalize
on these opportunities and emphasize the position of our business as an environmental and sustainable leader in
our market segments.

**_Focus on profitability and opportunities to drive further margin improvements_**

We believe there is a significant opportunity to increase profitability by driving further margin
improvements. Prior to the Transactions, we focused on increasing margins and improving overall profitability
with a €50 million savings program targeting variable cost reduction through procurement savings and other
improvement actions, which was completed ahead of schedule and exceeded targets. The Sponsors intend to
continue and expand upon the implementation of certain of our cost savings initiatives from which we expect to
derive significant cost savings and improve our margins. Bain Capital is the majority shareholder of Fedrigoni, a
leading European manufacturer and distributor of pressure sensitive labels and luxury papers. Based on Bain
Capital’s tested playbook for the specialty materials market, as evidenced by the increase in sales and
improvements in the pass-through of cost of raw materials by Bain Capital’s portfolio company, Fedrigoni, we

132


-----

see significant opportunity to further increase the profitability of the business, through areas such as
procurement, pricing, operational efficiency and general cost optimization. In addition to management’s cost
savings program, our Sponsors have identified over €200 million of profit improvement opportunities and we
expect to action approximately €30 million of such opportunities in the next 18 months. See “—Summary
_Consolidated Financial and Other Information—As Adjusted Data of the Issuer.”_

**_Portfolio management through selective acquisition, divestment and other investment opportunities_**

We will continue to consider selective acquisition and divestment opportunities on an on-going basis as they
arise in order to manage our portfolio to focus on enhancing our profitability. As part of our long-term
investment strategy, we continually evaluate potential acquisitions to grow our business in the market segments
we operate, capture market share and accelerate growth. For example, we are currently exploring opportunities to
acquire or invest in Minglian, a Chinese company comprising a greenfield decor paper plant in the city of
Xingtai, Hebei Province, China in order to increase our presence in China, which is the largest decor market. In
addition, we are actively considering strategic alternatives in relation to our entire Decor paper business,
including any potential ownership in Minglian, where one of the options being investigated is the possibility of a
divestment of the Decor business. Our mid-term objective is to refocus the business on higher value segments,
and increase presence in areas where we hold stronger, more differentiated positions.

**History**

**_History of Ahlstrom and Munksjö_**

We were created through the merger of Ahlstrom Corporation and Munksjö Oyj on April 1, 2017. The two
companies trace their roots back to the mid-1800s and the companies have a long history in the Finnish and
Swedish forestry and paper industry. Ahlstrom Corporation was incorporated in Finland in 1908 and traces its
origins to the saw mill, iron and shipping family business of Antti Ahlström established in 1851. The Munksjö
paper mill was founded in Sweden in 1862. On November 7, 2016, the boards of directors of Munksjö Oyj and
Ahlstrom Corporation agreed on combining the two companies and entered into a combination agreement and
executed a merger plan pursuant to which Ahlstrom Corporation would be merged into Munksjö Oyj. The merger
created a global leader in sustainable and innovative fiber-based materials, with leading positions in our main
product areas. The combination strengthened the combined company’s balance sheet allowing room for further
growth and also laid the basis for improved cost efficiencies and the realization of synergies. We have made
significant acquisitions since the merger as described below.

**_Acquisition of Caieiras_**

In April 2018, we entered into an agreement to acquire MD Papéis’ Caieiras specialty paper mill in Brazil
from the Formitex Group, an industrial conglomerate active in the paper, chemicals and panel board industries.
The acquisition strengthened our offering and production platform in South America, and provided attractive
growth opportunities, synergies and further production optimization opportunities for the longer term. The
acquisition was completed on October 17, 2018 for a cash consideration of €96.7 million.

**_Acquisition of Expera Specialty Solutions_**

In July 2018, we signed a share purchase agreement with Specialty Papers Holdings, L.P. pursuant to which
we acquired Expera Specialty Solutions, a U.S. based specialty paper producer. This bolt-on acquisition
expanded our presence in North America and further strengthened our offering of advanced custom-made fiberbased materials. The acquisition was completed on October 10, 2018 for a cash consideration of €524.9 million.

**_Exploring Strategic Alternatives for Decor Business_**

We are actively considering strategic alternatives in relation to our Decor paper business, including
investigating the possibility of a divestment of the Decor business. We are also exploring options to acquire or
invest in Minglian, a Chinese company comprising a greenfield decor paper plant in the city of Xingtai, Hebei
Province, China following the signing of a non-bind letter of intent in 2019. The transaction is subject to further
due diligence, structuring and agreeing final and binding transaction agreements. COVID-19 related lockdowns
and travel restrictions have delayed the negotiations and signing of the transaction, which could happen as early
as during the first half of 2021.

**Business Operations**

**_Overview_**

We are organized into five business areas and reporting segments that are further divided into 16 businesses
as listed below:

   - **Filtration & Performance Solutions: Filtration, Nonwovens, Glass Fiber Tissue, Abrasive**

   - **Advanced Solutions: Liquid Technologies, Beverage & Casing, Medical, Tape, Precision Coating**

   - **Industrial Solutions: Insulation, Release Liners, Coated Specialties**

   - **Food Packaging & Technical Solutions: Food Packaging, Technical, Parchment**

   - **Decor Solutions: Decor**

Our organizational structure promotes our core capabilities and aligns the business characteristics and
targets of each business area. It enables us to strengthen our capabilities in areas of product development and
innovation, global key customer account management and service, product and production technology as well as
process improvement and production optimization. The current organizational structure came into effect in
January 2020 and has resulted in production-related benefits. The structure also serves reporting and governance
purposes.

We manage our businesses with lean group functions such as sourcing, IT, legal and compliance, finance
and human resources. Each business is accountable for its operational and financial performance. Meanwhile, the
Group sets the strategic direction, decides on our priorities and resource allocation and provides support and
economies of scale for the businesses. Recently, we have focused on cross-business collaboration, identifying
new potentials in effective know-how, technology sharing and production optimization.

**_Filtration & Performance Solutions business area_**

Filtration & Performance Solutions comprised 23.4% of our net sales and 34.8% of our Comparable
EBITDA, in each case, excluding the impact of Other and eliminations for the year ended December 31, 2020.
The Filtration & Performance Solutions business area includes the Filtration, Nonwovens, Glass Fiber Tissue,
and Abrasive businesses, with estimated market sizes of €1,200 million, €190 million, €160 million and
€200 million, respectively.

134


-----

_Filtration_

The Filtration business develops and produces high-performance filtration materials from natural or
synthetic fibers or a combination of both for engine oil, fuel and air, cabin air, as well as industrial air, used in
vehicles or for industrial purposes. The Filtration business also produces applications and is further developing
fiber-based solutions for hybrid and fully electric vehicles. In transportation applications, sales come primarily
from the aftermarket. In industrial end-uses, sales are primarily generated by indoor air and cleanroom
applications as well as gas turbine air intake applications.

In response to the COVID-19 pandemic during 2020, the Filtration business has also utilized production
lines to produce face mask materials due to high demand caused by COVID-19. For instance, its Extia[®] Protect
portfolio, launched in May 2020, consists of a full range of face mask materials, including civil, surgical and
respiratory face masks.

The largest customer sectors are the automotive, heavy truck and heavy-duty vehicles industry and the
energy and general industry. The Filtration business operates globally and holds a position of one to two globally
in engine and industrial filtration materials.

_Nonwovens_

The Nonwovens business offers a wide range of nonwoven materials used for various applications,
including automotive interiors, plasterboards, hygiene, wallcover and wipes. The Nonwovens products range
includes nonwovens backings, reinforcements and composite materials for automotive interiors, reinforcements
for plasterboard, wetlaid specifically designed nonwovens for apparel, fabric care, hygiene, and wallcover
materials, nonwovens for use as a base material for wound-care and wipes products.

The largest customer sectors are the automotive, building, hygiene, and printing industries. Key markets for
the Nonwovens business are Europe and Asia. The Nonwovens business holds a number one position in high-end
wallcoverings in Europe and Asia.

_Glass Fiber Tissue_

The Glass Fiber Tissue business produces glass fiber tissue primarily for flooring applications and a range
of building and transportation-related end-uses. The largest customer sector is the construction and building
materials sector. The Glass Fiber Tissue business targets global markets and holds a number one position in
flooring applications globally.

_Abrasive business_

The Abrasive business produces specialty papers used as backings for abrasive products used in industrial
and do-it-yourself sanding applications. It offers a broad range of backings, from multipurpose paper to latex,
antistatic and high mechanical resistant paper, as well as materials for oil-based impregnation. The Abrasive
business also includes printing and surface treatment known as E2P for different backings.

The Abrasive business’ end customers include furniture manufacturers, automotive manufacturers and
workshops and industrial companies. The Abrasive business targets global markets and holds a number one
position in paper backings globally.

**_Advanced Solutions business area_**

The Advanced Solutions business area comprised 17.5% of our net sales and 17.9% of our Comparable
EBITDA, in each case, excluding the impact of Other and eliminations for the year ended December 31, 2020.
The Advanced Solutions business area includes the Liquid Technologies, Beverage & Casing, Medical, Tape and
Precision Coating businesses, with estimated market sizes of €400 million, €350 million, €830 million,
€400 million and €250 million, respectively.

_Liquid Technologies_

The Liquid Technologies business produces high-quality filters for laboratory sample preparation and life
science diagnostics materials that are used by laboratories and manufacturers of rapid test kits, and to highperformance media that has the ability to efficiently remove a wide range of harmful contaminants. Each of these
product lines involve separate and specific machinery and complex production capabilities.

135


-----

The key products of the Liquid Technologies business are:

   - _Filtration solutions for laboratory and life sciences: these include laboratory consumables such as_
extraction thimbles for the analysis of environmental pollution, pH indicator papers suitable for the
determination of pH and glass and quartz microfiber filters suitable for different kinds of
environmental analysis. The business also offers life science and diagnostics applications, such as a
product line for specimen collection and products suitable for lateral flow applications, including
conjugate release pads and single layer fibers suitable for the separation of plasma for small volume
blood samples and components for rapid test kits used in diagnostics.

   - _Liquid purification: these include filter media suitable for water purification, which can be used in a_
wide range of applications, such as refrigerators, whole house filters, countertop, tap and under counter
filters, water dispenser ice machines and food and beverage preparation. The business also offers filter
materials for cooking oil and milk filtration for the fast food industry and a selection of food and
industrial liquids processing applications suitable for, among other things, producers of alcoholic, soft
drink, and fruit juice beverages as well as a product range that covers all types of milk filters. We
consider ourselves as a pioneer with our alternative technology in the fiber-based water purification
product segment. Our proprietary Disruptor[®] technology is creating many new application
opportunities across the entire spectrum of water filtration.

The primary customers for filtration solutions include laboratories, laboratory consumables and equipment
suppliers and life science instrument and materials manufacturers. The primary customers for liquid purification
products include industrial end-users and water purification equipment manufacturers, including municipals.

The Liquid Technologies business targets global markets and holds a number two position globally.

_Beverage & Casing_

The Beverage & Casing business produces material for tea bags, coffee pods and food casings with a focus
on sustainability. The teabags portfolio includes both heat sealable and non-heat sealable teabag lines. The coffee
filter solutions portfolio includes single-serve coffee materials and solutions for the most common capsules
systems, for both filter coffee and espresso. The business also produces fibrous meat casing materials.

The Beverage & Casing business’ end customers include tea bag and coffee capsules manufacturers, as well
as food packaging suppliers. Key markets are in Europe and North America, while the business is global. The
Beverage & Casing business holds a number one to three position in tea bag, single-serve coffee solutions and
meat casing materials globally.

_Medical_

The Medical business produces medical fabrics used in sterile barrier systems, drapes, gowns, facemasks
and sterilization wraps, all used primarily in surgery but also in cleanrooms and laboratories.

The Medical business’s range of single-use sterile barrier systems are made of either nonwovens or papers
and they are designed to reduce the risk of healthcare acquired infections and used for products such as wrap,
overwrap, tray liners and paper for packaging sterilized medical devices. The medical fabrics used in drapes and
gowns are single-use fabrics designed to protect patients, surgeons, and surgical staff from viruses, bacteria, and
fluids, while being comfortable to wear at the same time. The Medical business also offers lightweight and
breathable nonwovens for use as inner and outer facemask cover stock.

Its primary customers are marketers, converters and laminators, who supply end-user products to medical
and health care segments. The Medical business targets global markets and holds a number one to three position
globally.

_Tape_

The Tape business produces tape backings to masking, packaging and specialty tape manufacturers used in
the construction and automotive industries as well as packaging applications for e-commerce and for specialty
purposes. The Tape business’ primary customers are tape manufacturers. The business operates globally and
holds a number one position globally.

_Precision Coating_

The Precision Coating business produces a variety of release liners for specialty markets, including fiber
composites, medical and tape. The Precision Coating business focuses on technically demanding applications

136


-----

that leverage our integrated specialty paper production and coating expertise. Precision Coating continues to
expand its capabilities to meet the stringent guidelines for the aerospace and medical markets.

The Precision Coating business’s primary customers are composite manufacturers. Key markets are in North
America. The Precision Coating business holds a number one to three position in North America.

**_Industrial Solutions business area_**

Industrial Solutions comprised 25.1% of our net sales and 20.9% of our Comparable EBITDA, in each case,
excluding the impact of Other and eliminations for the year ended December 31, 2020. The Industrial Solutions
business area includes the Insulation, Release Liners and Coated Specialties businesses, with estimated market
sizes of €250 million, €1,300 million and €2,200 million, respectively.

_Insulation_

The Insulation business supplies electrotechnical insulation materials to manufacturers of transformers and
high voltage cables globally. It also produces thin papers used as interleaves, textile print masking papers as well
as finish foils and balancing foils under the brand Spantex[TM]. The Insulation business also produces specialty
bleached and unbleached long-fiber cellulose pulp.

   - _Electrotechnical paper: These include creped or smooth grades supplied to manufacturers of_
transformers and high voltage cables, where they are used for electrotechnical insulation.
Electrotechnical paper is a vital component in the manufacture of submarine cables with high demands
on the paper’s insulating property, mechanical and chemical purity, strength and flexibility. The
primary customers for electrotechnical insulation papers are cable manufacturers, producers of
equipment for power transmission and distribution and wire producers for transformers.

   - _Thin papers: These are delivered to the steel, aluminum and glass manufacturing industries, which use_
them as interleaves between different layers of the products. Thin paper is also used in the textile
industry to protect machinery from excess dye. The thin paper offering also includes grades used as
base paper for one-time carbon.

   - _Spantex[TM]_ _finish and balancing foil: These include durable edge-banding foils, balancing foils that_
protect chipboard against moisture and varnished or pattern-printed ready-to-use foils. Balancing foils
protect the product from moisture damage and keep it from changing shape. They are also used to
balance the tensions that arise when veneer or high-pressure laminates are applied to a particle board.
Finish or priming foils remove irregularities, seal the surface and provide a substrate for painting on a
wood-based panel.

   - _Specialty pulp: This is long fiber cellulose pulp manufactured at a dedicated unit in Sweden and_
supplied to a number of industrial users in diverse sectors. Elementary chlorine free bleached pulp is
used for specialty paper, hygiene products, graphic paper, printing and writing paper, coated paper,
cardboard paper, transparent paper and passport paper as well as for specialty pulp applications such as
molding compounds. Unbleached kraft pulp is a specialty pulp mainly produced for electrotechnical
papers since it is pure and with a very low conductivity. End products for specialty pulp include
electrotechnical paper, board, hygiene paper and grease-proof paper.

The Insulation business targets global markets and holds a number one to two position in electrotechnical
papers globally.

_Release Liners_

The Release Liners business produces papers that, after coating of silicone from its customer, can be used to
carry self-adhesive labels or for manufacturing and assembling adhesive materials and components in industrial
processes.

Glassine release paper and supercalendered release paper are highly technical products and use similar
production technology, but are favored across different end-markets, with glassine being preferred in Europe and
supercalendered being preferred in North America. They are primarily used as carriers for self-adhesive labels in
the retail, consumer and durable goods industries, as well as carriers of technical adhesive materials and
components applied in the aeronautical, electronic and medical industries.

Clay-coated release liners are relatively less complex products and are used in self-adhesive graphics,
mainly for wide-format advertising on a range of surfaces, as well as in point of sales or exhibition
communications.

137


-----

The primary customers are label manufacturers and printers. Key markets are Europe, North America and
selected export regions. The Release Liners business holds a number two position globally.

_Coated Specialties_

The Coated Specialties business manufactures face-stock coated label papers, flexible packaging papers for
fast-moving consumables and processed foods, as well as office, printing and writing papers. Coated specialties
also include sublimation papers used for textile transfer printing. In the textile transfer printing process, thin print
paper is first printed and then the ink is gasified and transferred to polyester cloth using heat.

The Coated Specialties business’s largest customer groups are industrial converters within flexible
packaging and self-adhesive laminates applications. Key markets for the Coated Specialties business are Europe,
South America and Asia. The Coated Specialties business holds a number two position in coated specialty papers
in South America.

**_Food Packaging & Technical Solutions business area_**

The Food Packaging & Technical Solutions business area comprised 20.4% of our net sales and 15.4% of
our Comparable EBITDA, in each case, excluding the impact of Other and eliminations for the year ended
December 31, 2020. The Food Packaging & Technical Solutions business area includes the Food Packaging,
Technical and Parchment businesses, with estimated market sizes of €1,400 million, €1,600 million and
€200 million, respectively.

_Food Packaging_

The Food Packaging business offers a broad range of specialty papers and capabilities for quick service
restaurants, food processing, cooking and baking, and flexible packaging markets. Ahlstrom-Munksjö has made
enhancements to its technology platform that includes a product range of grease-resistant papers for common
fast-food packaging, food wraps, biscuits and microwave popcorn bags, without the use of fluorochemicals. Our
products also include LamiBak[™], a product that enables the use of release liners in an entirely fiber-based
container certified for food contact.

The Food Packaging business’s largest customer sector is converters of packaging materials. Key markets
are North America and Europe. The Food Packaging business holds a number one to three position in North
America.

_Technical_

The Technical business produces specialty products used for a wide variety of industrial and construction
applications. The product portfolio includes glass interleave papers, saturating bases, laminating bases, and other
industrial packaging fiber-based solutions. The product offering often involves a high degree of technical
complexity and customization.

The main end-customers for these products are glass and construction materials manufacturers. Key markets
are North America and selected export regions. The Technical business holds a number one to two position in
North America.

_Parchment_

The Parchment business produces a broad portfolio of solutions for food and industrial applications. The
product portfolio includes cooking and baking papers, panliners, baking-trays and molds and food packaging
papers for fresh and greasy foods. Furthermore, parchment is used in the textile tube and furniture laminate
industries as well as in radio frequency identification and printed circuit board and copper clad lamination. The
Parchment business operates in a small, niche market segment as these products are highly differentiated.
Production of parchment products requires very specific equipment due to the technical complexity of sulphuric
acid-based processes.

The Parchment business’ largest customer sector is converters of packaging materials. Key markets are
Europe and North America. The Parchment business holds a number one position globally in the baking and
cooking strategic segment. We are generally considered to provide among the highest quality products in this
segment.

Decor Solutions business area includes the Decor business, which comprised 13.6% of our net sales and

Decor business.

The Decor business’s main product offerings include decor paper, print base paper, pre-impregnated paper
and thin print paper.

   - _Decor paper for high- and low-pressure laminates offers high color consistency and technological_
features for efficient impregnation. It is a type of surface material for decorative applications mainly
used in laminated furniture, flooring and interior applications both for technical purposes (surface
resistance) and esthetical purposes (colors and patterns, for example to provide the appearance of wood
or other materials). After impregnation and lamination (by a customer), decor paper becomes durable
and achieves the surface properties that make it suitable for use in environments involving rough wear
and tear. Decor paper is used in kitchen furniture and worktops, office furniture and building facades.

   - _Print base paper is white or solid colored decor paper that is ready for printing. Following printing and_
lamination (by a customer), the product is mainly used for laminate flooring and furniture.

   - _Pre-impregnated paper is a partly pre-impregnated foil base paper offering high internal bond level_
and high printability results, which are suitable for finish foil applications. Pre-impregnated paper is
suitable for upgrading surfaces that require moderate scratch and wear resistance. After printing,
lacquering, and gluing onto wood substrate by the customer, the finished product is suitable for
furniture, doors, laminate flooring, as well as roof and wall covering applications.

   - _Thin print papers are thin, lightweight papers used for applications requiring a large amount of text to_
be printed on the smallest space possible and on both sides of the paper, while still offering excellent
printability, high opacity and good processing properties on printing and folding machines. These are
used primarily by the pharmaceutical industry for patient information leaflets, cosmetic leaflets and
other packaging inserts and outcerts. The material is also suitable for certain books, literature and
timetables.

The Decor business’ primary end-markets are furniture manufacturers and construction material producers.
Key markets are Europe, North and South America and selected export markets. The Decor business holds a
number two to four position globally.

**Competition**

We focus on selected niches of the fiber-based solutions market where it believes that it can produce and
sell products at a price premium because it addresses customers that require specific know-how and customized
products. We focus on collaborative innovation with customers to provide customer-specified products optimized
for manufacturing and end-product requirements. We do not compete primarily on price, as we believe that the
strongest competitive factors in our markets are product portfolio, technical competence, service and quality as
well as delivery capability.
